Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report that the vertical boiler at Gordon Indian Residential is leaking; the engineer says it should be retubed. The water at this place eats out the tubing.

This boiler was retubed in Regina once before by a firm named Springatein & Davidson, the principal took it in on a truck and got it done in half a day as this firm is equipped to give a rush job. Another time it was done by another firm who sent a man to do the work at the school.

Will you please advise me if the work can be done, and what firm to employ.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

March 29 1940.

Dear Sir:

When I was at the Gordon Indian Residential School yesterday the principal told me that the septic tank is going out of business, he has been having a lot of trouble keeping it working. The tank was put in years ago before the present building was constructed.

I knew little about septic tanks, and cannot give any estimate of probable cost if we dig into it.

If you think the engineering branch at Prince Albert, which assists us sometimes regards water systems, could check up this system, I would be obliged if you could ask them to send along one of their men. There is no special rush about this matter, but if our sewage systems get out of order we may run into typhoid trouble.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Ottawa,
April 3, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the septic tank at the Gordon's Residential School.

As you are aware our estimates for the fiscal year 1940-41 have not yet been considered by Parliament and at the present time I am unable to state what amount will be available for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Gordon's School. I am hoping that we will be able to secure an amount of $700.00 for this school but cannot say definitely at the present time if this amount will be allowed. In the event of our securing it it will be necessary to charge against this appropriation the amount incurred in repairing the boiler. Consequently you will see that there will not be any large amount for other expenditures and our appropriation during the present fiscal year will be so limited that it will be impossible to expend more than specifically provided for each residential school.

However, I am arranging with the Surveys & Engineering Branch to have one of their officers visit the school and report on the septic tank system but both the Principal and yourself should point out to this officer when he reaches the Gordon's School that the funds are extremely limited and that only very necessary repairs to the septic tank system should be considered.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. J. W. Waddy,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Ottawa,
April 3, 1940.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School

The above-mentioned school is situated 7 miles from the town of Punnichy, Sask., where the Indian Agent, Mr. J. W. Waddy, resides.

Mr. Waddy has just reported that the septic tank at this school is giving considerable trouble and he suggests that one of your officers visit the school and inspect it.

I should appreciate it if you would arrange to have this work done as soon as weather conditions permit and have your officer submit a report for our consideration. It should be pointed out to him that the funds at our disposal this year are extremely limited and consequently only the urgent repairs to the septic tank should be considered.

Director.
Punnichy, Sask.

April 22 1940.

Dear Sir;-

I have the honor to report that the principal of the Gordon Indian Residential School has asked to be supplied with some galvanized pipe which will be used when required to keep the water system in shape, he says the pipes keep plugging up with sediment from the water.

Enclosed please find estimate of cost of the items he asks for, they amount to $128.95.

Knowing that you are short of funds I just forward the request without any recommendation, though I know he would probably make use of the pipe if it is supplied.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
April 26, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to the request of the Principal of the Gordon's Indian Residential School to be supplied with galvanized pipe.

As you state in your letter the funds this year are limited and consequently the Department does not wish to incur any expenditure that could be avoided. However, I should appreciate it if you would state definitely if, in the event of these pipes being ordered, the use of them would possibly avoid subsequent heavy expenditure in connection with the water system. If so, I am inclined to feel that it would be advisable to secure them. It should be understood, of course, that in the event of the pipe being purchased the cost of it will be taken from the amount that may be provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the Gordon's School.

An early reply would be appreciated.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J. W. Waddy,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Punnichy, Sask.
May 13 1940.

Dear Sir;-

Re letter 121-1-5 of April 26 last regards pipe asked for by the principal of the Gordon Indian Residential School, I beg to say I have talked this matter over again with the principal and the engineer and I think it best that the pipe be supplied if possible. The engineer says he keeps on putting in pipe all the time and keeps the water system in shape, the water here corrodes the insides of the existing pipe. Therefore I would be obliged if you could have it supplied.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
May 17, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection Sewage System at Gordon's Residential School, Punnichy, Sask.

Accompanied by the Indian Agent, Mr. J.W. Waddy, and the school principal, Mr. R.W. Freyling, I inspected the sewage disposal plant at the above school on July 10th.

Mr. Freyling stated that the odor from the septic tank and from its outlet into a small slough was very bad at all times, that the septic tank had become so filled that three pumpings were necessary to remove the sludge last year and that at times the sewage backs up into the school building due to the tank and outlet tiles becoming plugged. He stated also that they had upon several occasions had to dig up the outlet tiling to remove broken tiles which were obstructing the flow.

I found upon looking into the tank that the bell siphon was not operating. The sewage was escaping through the overflow vent. The concrete insides of the tank appeared to be in bad condition. The soil of this locality and especially that region occupied by the disposal field is a very heavy clay—quite unsuitable for the efficient operation of a disposal field.

Upon examination of the plans of this septic tank received from your office I find that allowing for an accumulation of sludge to a depth of two feet there remains for effluent capacity an area 4' x 6' x 15' = 208 cu.ft. = 1800 gallons. At least a capacity of twenty gallons per capita is necessary in the effluent volume. This old tank when working with an unobstructed disposal field system would be good for 90 persons. Mr. Freyling stated that the maximum population contributing to this sewage system was from 136 to 150. The present tank is not only too small but is working inefficiently due to lack of permeability of the soil of the disposal field and to a stoppage of the flow due to crushed or broken field tile.

I would therefore make the following recommendations. (a) That a new steel tank be purchased and installed. This tank to discharge into the slough through a straight line of 6" tile. That an inexpensive homemade chlorinator costing about $10.00 be installed to pre-chlorinate the sewage and thus remove all odors and that the old tank be cleaned out and the main tile outlet to the slough be relaid and broken or unsuitable tiling removed. This old system then to be used for laundry waste disposal.

(b) If there is insufficient funds to carry out the above recommendation I would then advise as an alternative that the old system be thoroughly cleaned as to both septic chambers, concrete be repaired where necessary, and all
main tile lines be dug up, examined and replaced with new tiles where necessary. To this system should also be added the small home made chlorinator specified above.

The following is an estimate of cost for the labour and material to carry out the above recommendations.

Re Lister Generating Engine.

Answering your letter regarding Batteries for above. This same condition has been present since the instalment, and in 1932 Mumford Medland's expert, Mr. Montgomery, was here for I think three days, and if my memory is correct he said that there was not anything that could be done to eliminate the overcharging when the Large Engine is carrying the charge used for the laundry, which is on Mondays and Wednesdays.

The engineer at present, George Ryan, carries a Second Class Certificate, but this trouble has nothing whatever to do with the Engineer, Staff or anyone else. It is the engine. The Chief Provincial Government Engineer, when I was speaking to him for the services of an engineer said there was not any real need for other than a Fireman's Certificate.
for our plant, but I have always had a 1st or 2nd certificated Engineer. The fact that your attention has been drawn to this matter is from my own complaint, as the attached letter explains. Knowing that the cells were warped, I spoke to Mr. Waddy, asking if he had any guarantee on file, as I had only heard it verbally. Eventually the Sales Manager of Globelite came and looked the batteries over, with the same remark, that it was the engine. He did not just drop in on his own accord, but through the complaint made by myself.

I have spent all kinds of money trying to remedy this condition, and have had experts from Regina, Lestock, and many electricians, one of whom said he could right the trouble. On asking how much it would cost, "Oh, not more than fifty dollars." I said I would give him $50.00 on this guarantee if it proved successful. He installed an additional rheostat, but to no purpose. I am not an electrician or an engineer, but from the first I could see no other way to offset this overcharge, (which is the sole trouble) than to disconnect the generator from the engine shaft (if it is possible), whilst using the power for laundry.

To impress upon you there is not any reason to suppose there is laxity on my own part or on the part of any of the Staff, or that any inference of waste or extravagance is justified, I will mention that in my ten years of service I will have an average of being on duty at this school from 5:45 to 6 o'clock A.M. until 8 o'clock P.M. without rest during the day except on Sundays, -one hour later rising bell.

To improve the condition of the Batteries in question, and also to prove my interest, I have had an estimate (which is attached) for the installation of a Gas Engine, which would eliminate the Lister Engine entirely from the laundry power, and so overcome the battery trouble,
so that the life of the battery would then be ten years instead of five years. Knowing that the cost of the septic tank was very much less than it was estimated, and that you had an appropriation for that $700, I thought perhaps the balance could be assigned for this purpose.

In conclusion I will add that I fully realize that the responsibility rests with myself, not the Staff. If waste of any kind is noticed, it doesn't matter if in Engine Room, Kitchen or with School Supplies, Drugs etc., a check is made, and the fact that I carry a surplus from the Per Capita Grant is proof of there being little waste here.

I forgot to mention that the Globelite Manager told me he was going to take up the matter of the engine with Mumford Medland, of Winnipeg. There is not anything wrong with the engines. We have your letter of February 15, advising that you have had your Lister Lighting unit checked over and it was found to be in good condition.

What we were chiefly interested in was to have the plant so that the battery would automatically cut out of the circuit when it became fully charged. The way you are operating now, as we understand it is that you have no automatic control cutting out the battery when it becomes charged. The result that it is cycled everyday whether it needs it or not, and given a particularly heavy charge when it is necessary to operate the laundry.

An experienced engineer who is thoroughly familiar with operating the plant and the batteries could control this over charging to a large extent, but it would require a certain amount of attention during the time the plant is charging, but your real solution would be automatic control.

This is one of the chief reasons why we suggested the Mumford Medland Co. Ltd., checking the plant because they could make certain recommendations that would prove beneficial.

Dear Sir:

As requested by you I have today visited the Gordon's Indian Residential School, and have checked over the Lister electric lighting plant and the Globelite batteries. My findings are as follows:

(1) The Lister Lighting plant is in very good condition, both mechanically and electrically, and has the proper facilities to control the output of the generators.

(2) That the 240 ampere hour 50 cell Globelite battery is in very bad condition and un-economical to operate in as much as it will not take the charge. It appears that the positive plates have shed badly, and the negative plates are in a very unusual condition for this type of battery. They are swelled and spongy and have a fungi-like substance protruding from them.

It appears to me that there is something wrong with the electrolyte in these batteries, and must contain some substance detrimental to the plates, such as Iron or some other soluble mineral. I took the matter of the kind of water
used to replenish the evaporation; which Mr. Eayling and the Engineer, and find that nothing has been used but supposedly pure distilled water, kept in glass containers and purchased from the bottling works at Yorkton, Sask., which should not contain minerals.

From my experience I would say that the batteries do not show signs of serious overcharging for a normal battery, but if there is, as I suspect, minerals in the electrolyte which would close the pores of the plates, they would be unable to take a normal charge.

I am of the opinion that, considering the possible output of the generators, and the amount of current used at the school, that a larger capacity battery should be used. I would recommend that the batteries should be replaced with a 300 Ampere hour capacity size, and that you have the electrolyte analyzed at the time of installation. In this way I am sure you would get much longer service and better satisfaction, for as I have already mentioned, this Lister plant has every facility to give a battery the best of care.

I have adjusted the Governor on the larger unit in order to generate a little lower voltage than it had previously been delivering.

Yours truly,

Alex. Shaw.

Dear Sir:

Re: Globelite Batteries.

You will have received the result of the analysis of Electrolyte by Milton Hersey Co., Winnipeg through the Globelite Company. I will draw to your attention their notation on the assumption of Globelite that Well Water had been used and presumably the cause of the present condition of the Batteries. I want to point out that they (the Globelite) have not any reason whatsoever to suggest such, and I have the right to think that the foreign matter found was not there when the sample was taken from this School. The Sask. Provincial Laboratories findings of the only water we use here for every purpose does not contain these solids shown by Milton Hersey Co., the copy of which is attached.

Since I received the above report from Mr. Waddy, I forwarded to Provincial Laboratories a sample of acid taken from various Batteries just in the same way as that when taken from the School and forwarded to Globelite, the only difference that the sample I sent was to the Public Provincial analyst and that to Winnipeg to the party interested. I also forwarded a sample of Distilled Water used when the Batteries called for addition, the report of both being attached. This water is purchased from Yorkton Bottling Co.

The inference by the Globelite Co. that Well Water was used leads me to think that something happened to the
sample reaching Winnipeg. There is not any water at all near the Batteries here but the Distilled Water mentioned, and I have just as much right (being responsible for everything here) to think there was interference in Winnipeg (and more so) than they have to suggest before the analysis by Milton Hersey that Well Water had been used in this School's Batteries.

Helli and Cameron, Regina, I believe gave the guarantee for the Batteries, but there does not seem to be any word from them, and it is usual for the company supplying to investigate such a complaint of inferior goods and help to satisfy a customer, more especially where such a sum of money is involved.

I don't think for a moment that they, Helli & Cameron ever saw these Batteries, but naturally benefited by the sale, and I would suggest that they also approach the Globelite Co. and use pressure to remedy the complaint, as Helli and Cameron are the firm from whom direct purchase was made.

The department (and rightly too) are always reminding us of the absolute necessity of strict economy which grants me to suggest that such a matter as this with the most definite proof of Faulty Production, force the replacement of these Batteries in their entirety, or a very substantial concession.

In conclusion I imagine that even the Globelite Co. could make an error, and the whole trouble could come from the Electrolyte before being put into the Glass Containers.

This is a lengthy report, but is the only way to give the real honest facts of this serious trouble. The Batteries are in bad shape right now.

Dear Sir:

Re: File 121-1-5

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter April 10th with regard to the 56 Cell 110 Volt Globelite Battery in the Gordon Residential School at Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

We agree with you that you have not had anywhere near the guaranteed service of five years from this battery, in fact the actual life received from the battery is approximately 24 months and we are prepared to credit you with three years unused service on the purchase price of a new battery. That is to say, the battery is guaranteed for five years and we will allow 3/5 of this as a credit. The Department will only be asked to pay for the actual service received from the battery and these are the customary terms outlined in our guarantee.

We feel there are many reasons why this battery didn't stand up and give the service you have a right to expect, and when we say this we are not shirking our responsibility; and the fact we are willing to adjust on the basis of the actual service received from the battery is ample proof of this.

As we pointed out in a previous letter your plant is connected up in such a way that you are charging and cycling the battery every day whether it needs it or not and on days when you operate the laundry charging is continuous while the laundry is in operation. These combined circumstances have resulted in the battery being constantly overcharged.

We, of course, have brought this to the attention of Mr. Waddy and the Principal of the school and they are quite aware if they are to establish ideal operating conditions, it is necessary to have an automatic voltage control attached to the lighting unit.
which will automatically cut the battery out of the circuit when it becomes fully charged. You perhaps know the ideal operating conditions of any lighting unit can only be achieved when you have rest periods for four or five days. That is to say, a battery should be large enough to carry the load without charging for a period as stated above and it is only reasonable to expect the longer the battery carries the load without charging, the greater will be the life of the battery.

The school Principal mentioned to the writer it has been necessary to change engineers frequently and it is very difficult to obtain the service of experienced engineers, more particularly engineers who are familiar with lighting units. This, we believe, in some measure has affected the efficiency of the battery.

We feel definitely sure of this because if there were any impurities it would naturally show up in other batteries manufactured at the same time and we have not experienced any trouble of this nature.

We draw these various points to your attention Mr. Hoey not because we wish to avoid the issue but so that conditions of this kind can be guarded against occurring in the future.

Report on the Gordon School

I wish to inform you that I have just returned from a trip to the Touchwood Agency, and the first place visited was the Gordon School. The last time I visited this school was about twelve years ago.

In company with the Principal and the Indian Agent I inspected the Institution from top to bottom and also looked over the out-buildings. The school, as a whole, is in first class state of repair and is well kept. I found everything in order and the furniture and equipment well taken care of.

There was some correspondence last Summer about the primary classroom, which was being operated in the basement, but upon seeing it I have a very much different opinion about it. A partition of V joist was put up to separate the classroom from the playroom, and at the top of the partition there is a transom that can be opened. The floor of the basement is only a foot below ground level so at the front of the classroom the bottom of the window is just about 1½ ft. above the floor, which gives this room ample light and ventilation.

There were about 101 children present at the time of my visit. The Principal did not know that I was coming, therefore he had no opportunity to make any preparations for my visit. I was there for lunch and went into the dining room and saw the meal being served. In my opinion these children are well fed and well. There was no one sick at the School. They have lots of milk, as they were milking 14 cows when I was there, and have several more to freshen. They have about 50 head of cattle and also keep pigs and chickens. In addition to this they have several good teams of work horses.

The Principal showed me his books and the financial standing of the School is good. Mr. Frayling is a real good business man and everything is purchased......
everything is purchased wholesale, taking full advantage of the discounts. A lot of interior repairs have been carried out from year to year by the Principal but the exterior of the School, such as window frames and doors, etc., is weather-beaten and will require painting sooner or later. The outside buildings also need painting. However, whether this can be carried out or not is immaterial. I was informed that the batteries on the lighting plant in the School are being replaced.

I noticed that a lot of work has been done around the grounds, such as fixing up driveways and the road into the School, planting trees and hedges, etc., during the last few years, and in conclusion would say that this is a very well managed establishment.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Lighting Plant, Gordon's Indian Residential School.

In reply to your memoranda of May 21st and June 11th relative to the above, I may say that the matter has been given very careful consideration. It was referred to our Engineering and Construction Service who in turn took it up with Mr. Snelson who was personally familiar with the situation and this has resulted in some delay.

A brief review of the situation indicates that a 56-cell, 252 Ampere-hour Globelite battery guaranteed for five years, was purchased in January, 1939, and after about two year's service was in very poor condition.

The matter was investigated as thoroughly as possible but from the evidence produced it appears to be impossible to state definitely whether the fault lay in the electrolyte used or in the battery supplied. An analysis of the electrolyte showed that it contained harmful impurities and it was suggested that as calcium and magnesium salts were present, well water had been added to the cells. Principal Grayling, however, states that only distilled water obtained from a bottling company in Yorkton has been used. Analyses of this and the water used for ordinary purposes at the school showed no impurities which would be harmful to the battery.

The Globelite Company claims also that the failure is the result of continued overcharging while operating the motor-driven laundry equipment, but Mr. A. Shaw,
investigating on behalf of the school, states that the lighting plant is in very good condition both mechanically and electrically, and has every facility to give a battery the best of care. Both Mr. Shaw and the Globelite Company have recommended the use of a battery of larger capacity, 300 to 360 Ampere-hours. We believe that this would ameliorate the situation but might not remedy it, as operating conditions would remain the same.

In your memorandum of May 21st you advised that the Indian Agent and the Principal of the school suggested that a 5-H.P. gasoline engine be purchased to operate the laundry machinery. This would relieve the batteries of this load, and Mr. Shaw offered to install this complete for $186. If overcharging was the cause of the failure, this would be a remedy, and if the failure was due to other causes the reduction in load would tend to increase the life of the batteries.

Mr. Snelson pointed out that since the combined output of the two engines now installed at the school is 20½ H.P., it would not be economical to eliminate the 5 H.P. motor and incur the first cost and operating charges of another gasoline engine. Instead he recommended that the wiring at the switchboard and where necessary in the powerhouse be so arranged as to permit cutting out the battery entirely during the time that the heavy laundry motor is in operation. This could be done by sending the current directly into the distribution system through a line bypassing the battery. By such an arrangement the battery would be at rest during the day, or when most heavy work is done with the motors, and would serve mainly for lighting purposes. Mr. Snelson estimates the cost of such re-wiring with switches, and including labour, at $100.

After due consideration the Chief Engineer, Mr. Mills, has recommended that advantage be taken of the Globelite Company's offer of a credit of three-fifths of the original cost of the battery representing the unused portion of the guaranteed life, and the purchase of another 252 Ampere-hour battery to be used for lighting purposes only, and a gasoline engine, as mentioned above, to operate the laundry equipment. The estimated cost of both would
be $596.40, less 60%, or $238.56, together with $186.00 for the gasoline engine installation, making a total cost of $424.56. It might be noted that this is less than the Globelite Company's offer to supply a new 360 Ampere-hour battery at a cost of $450.00 f.o.b. Winnipeg.

We concur in Mr. Mills' recommendation, though with some reluctance as the installation of another gasoline engine will cost $86.00 more than a re-wiring job and will be another item of mechanical equipment to operate and maintain. However, in view of the fact that the difference in cost is not very great, and after considering past experience and all the circumstances, we consider that this is the best policy.

In this connection I would recommend that a careful record be kept of the internal condition of the new batteries as to amount of distilled water introduced, charge as determined by suitable hydrometer, deposition of sediment, etc., and that the plant engineer give the battery the exact care specified by its makers. Distilled water should be secured from only most reliable dealers.

J.M. Wardle,
Director.
Ottawa, July 18, 1941.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Lighting Plant, Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Sask.

I desire to refer to Mr. Jackson's memorandum of May 7, in connection with our requisition for a set of batteries for the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

It has taken some time to obtain the desired information, one reason for this being that the Surveys and Engineering Branch, to whom the matter was submitted, considered it necessary to have one of their field men visit the school. Advantage was also taken of Mr. Doucet's visit to western Canada to have him go to the Gordon's school and make a careful check of the mechanical plant. For your information I enclose a copy of the report of the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

Mr. Doucet found that there is no 5 horse power motor at this school. Up to the present the laundry has been operated by means of an overhead shaft from the 14 horse power Lister and not from the batteries, as intimated by Mr. Nelson. This evidently has been causing the overcharging.

On his return Mr. Doucet discussed the whole matter with officials of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, and it is considered that the following action will meet the situation satisfactorily:

1. Take advantage of the Globelite Company's offer of a credit of 3/5 of the original cost of the battery, representing the unused portion of its guaranteed life, and the purchase of another -
another 252 ampere-hour battery, to be used for lighting purposes.

With our requisition of May 5 there was included the Globalite Company's letter of April 14, 1941, in which this offer was made.

2. Operate the laundry equipment from the 6½ horse power Lister instead of from the 14 horse power. This can easily be done by changing the drive pulley from the 14 H.P. Lister to the 6½ H. P. Lister and shortening the drive belt. In addition, the electrical generator should be disconnected from the 6½ H. P. Lister and operated indirectly by means of pulleys and belts.

I might add that the school management has recently engaged a new engineer, whom Mr. Doucet interviewed. It is believed that this engineer is fully competent to handle the equipment. However, specific instructions are being issued to him.

I trust that this memorandum supplies the information desired by Mr. Jackson and that immediate arrangements will be made to supply a new battery on the terms mentioned above.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 12th instant and previous letters with regard to the batteries and low pressure boiler at the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

For various reasons beyond our control, it has taken some time to decide on the type of battery required at the Gordon's School, but we have now made a decision and the Purchasing Branch is arranging to secure a new set of batteries at the earliest possible date.

The whole electrical equipment should be re-adjusted. This will necessitate operating the laundry equipment from the 6½ H. P. Lister instead of from the 14 H. P. Lister. Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 121-1-5 of the 17th instant received by Air Mail in connection with the battery and electrical equipment at the Gordon's School, Punnichy.

As soon as I received your letter I wired Mumford Medland Limited and received a wire in reply stating that Mr. Range, of the Globelite Battery Company should be in Punnichy the next day. Also, Mr. Medland now informs me that he got in touch with the Globelite Battery Company immediately and they had received a Night Letter from Punnichy the day before stating that Mr. Range, their traveller, was in Regina. Mr. Medland then telephoned Mr. Range here and asked him to go to Punnichy, which he did. Dear Sir:

With further reference to file 121 - 1 - 5, and at the request of Mr. Christianson, the writer made a special Trip to the Gordon Indian Residential School at Punnichy to examine the battery and equipment that is claimed was giving trouble. This special Trip was made under some very trying conditions as the Highways were all snowbound. However we realize that we have many installations with the Government and our policy has always been to render quick and satisfactory service.

The report covering this inspection is as follows:

The battery was found to be in an excellent condition and in our opinion there was no foundation for grounds to complain. The fault was not in the battery or the equipment but rather in the manner in which the electrical system is being operated. In the first place the writer was advised that it was necessary to keep charging the battery for several days to bring the specific gravity of the solution up to 1.275. Our instructions definitely state that the full charged specific gravity is 1.250. The operator of the plant as well as Mr. Frayling, the Principal of the School, were ignorant of the fact that the specific gravity should be 1.250 instead of 1.275.

When the writer asked Mr. Frayling and the Engineer to produce the instructions that were sent along with the battery, they could not find same and as an excuse stated that they had not received any. We are definitely sure that these instructions were sent with the new battery. We are forwarding another copy today.
fact that the engineer tried to bring the specific gravity up to 1.275, resulted in considerable unnecessary running of the plant and regardless of how long the charge was continued the gravity would not come up over the 1.250 mark.

The plant that is being used at this school consists of Lister automatic equipment. Apparently the operators have not been operating this plant automatically but rather confined same to manual operation. Mr. Freyling stated emphatically that the reason for not operating the plant automatically was due to the fact that the switch-board was not right and the automatic features could not be used. The writer questioned this and had the plant started up on several occasions by turning on a load which automatically started the engines. When this load was shut off the engines stopped automatically. This was done several times and proved to Messrs. Freyling and Waddy that there is absolutely nothing wrong with the automatic operation.

We further understand that peak loads at night run from 30 to 40 Amperes and on various occasions the engines were not being operated to carry this load which resulted in the entire load being thrown over on the battery.

Again our instructions definitely state that the engine and plant should be run when loads exceed 22 Amperes for manual operation. From this you will readily understand that the peak loads that run from 35 to 40 Amperes are far in excess of what we recommend for a maximum discharge from this size battery. At this heavy peak load it is impossible for the battery to carry this heavy load for more than 4½ to 5 hours without a very serious voltage drop causing a very noticeable dimness in lights.

It was pointed out to Mr. Freyling as well as Mr. Waddy that if the school wishes to continue with manual operation, their present battery is too small as their heavy loads when taken from the battery exceed by far that which is recommended.

Our recommendation is that the plant be run automatically for which it was originally designed. We would further recommend that an alteration be made to the equipment whereby the battery will carry larger loads before the engines cut-in to take care of the peak loads. At the present time the equipment is set so that the engines will automatically cut-in as soon as the load exceeds approximately 200 Watts, and the engines will continue to operate until the load again drops to 200 Watts before they stop. We would suggest that the relays be adjusted so that the engine will cut-in at around 500 or 600 Watts and continue to carry loads in excess of this with a surplus for recharging the battery and then cut-out when the load again drops to this point of 500 to 600 Watts.
In other words, this would mean that the battery would carry the small loads and the plant would take care of the heavy loads. Then if it is found that this operation will not keep the battery fully charged, an extra charge can be given on days when the laundry is being operated to compensate for any such loss.

It was also pointed out to the writer that the school is burning out electric light bulbs as fast as they install them. This responsibility rests entirely on the operator of the plant as the plants are equipped with Rheostats to control the voltage. By permitting the voltage to rise up to 145 and 150 Volts which has been the case, it is only reasonable to expect that electric light bulbs will burn out.

Mr. Christianson from the Department of Indian Affairs in Regina, Saskatchewan, has requested the writer to get in touch with the Mumford-Medland Company of Winnipeg, who are the people who installed these plants, to send their service man to Punnichy to check over the plants as well as the switch-board and also arrange for alterations on one of the plants for laundry operation, as per sketch sent by your Department.

We have contacted the Mumford-Medland Company and they are immediately getting in touch with Mr. Christianson but as stated before, to our knowledge the automatic features on this plant are operating quite satisfactorily with the exception that alteration be made whereby the battery carry somewhat heavier loads before the engines cut-in. Of course there are some parts of the switch-board not in the very best of condition, such as the contact fingers on the clapper coils. These are very badly burned and should be replaced. Also the fuses should be replaced because the present ones have all been plugged.

We trust that we have covered this situation fully and we might suggest that if the plant is not operated as per our recommendations outlined in the foregoing paragraphs, we cannot assume any responsibility for the battery.

Yours truly,

GLOBELITE BATTERIES LIMITED.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the LISTER Fully Automatic Lighting units at the Gordon Anglican Indian Residential School, Punnichy. As you know, the trip was made by the writer to check and report on the condition of these units, as well as the advisability of following out the suggestions of disconnecting the generator from the engine of the smaller unit, and by a series of pulleys and belts, drive the generator disconnected and the engine to be reconnected through a series of pulleys to drive the laundry equipment.

In dealing with this suggested change as per the Department Engineer's suggestion, we do not agree with it at all in that the automatic features of this particular unit would have to be disposed of. This in turn disrupts the automatic features of the second and third unit. Secondly, the existing load of the school can be carried 90% of the time by the small unit which the Department proposes disturbing, resulting in the larger unit having to be operated. This involves additional gasoline, oil, double the amount of parts, etc., which greatly increases the general upkeep and operation of the plants.

Thirdly, it places the school where they have only one unit as a source of electrical supply which, in my estimation is not adequate for this type of an institution, for in the event of failure of the remaining unit, if this plan was carried out, this would result in the lighting supply having to be drawn from the battery, which would only take care of it for a very short period of time, and this would have
a damaging effect on the battery due to the excessive load.

We now submit our proposal, together with a rough sketch of the installation of same, in the space available: Instead of disconnecting or disturbing the present lighting system in any way from the present, that an additional gas engine be installed to take care of the laundry equipment. This will eliminate the problem of excessive charging of the batteries during the time the laundry equipment is being used. In other words, the laundry equipment will be a self-contained unit and in no way included with the existing lighting system.

Our suggestion is to use a light high speed air cooled motor with a reduction clutch, and why we recommend this type of engine is to minimize the amount of space required by the engine.

We attach a blueprint as previously mentioned, covering the stand and location of the stand for the above type of engine, and we quote separately on a suitable engine together with stand and fittings.

With reference to the condition of the electrical equipment as found by the writer. To our knowledge the electrical system (and when we say electrical system we refer to the switchboard and the electrical contacts, etc., on same) has never been adjusted or serviced since around 1933, and we would point out that this in our opinion is wonderfully good service for this type of equipment. We found the various clapper switches and solenoid coils, etc., needed minor adjustments. It also necessitated the replacement of one coil and two carbon brushes. Various contacts were dirty, which were cleaned, and after checking the board over carefully it then functioned very satisfactorily.

The position the Board was found in was that at times the automatic would work quite satisfactorily but at other times due to the condition of various contact points, etc., would not function as it normally should. Therefore it was getting to the point where it could not be relied on 100% with regard to automatic starting and stopping.

With reference to the batteries. As you no doubt know, there has been installed a new set of batteries at this school. Suitable instructions have been issued by the Globelite Co., and the writer gave all the information he could on the proper upkeep and care of the batteries to the present operator.

It would appear to us that one source of the difficulty at the school in regard to the battery failures has been the
fact that the laundry equipment was driven off the engine of the large electric generating unit. This resulted at times in an overcharge of the batteries which would have its most damaging effects during the summer months, and if our suggestion for driving the laundry equipment is carried out, this would eliminate this difficulty.

With reference to Mr. Frayling, Principal of the School. We have only this to say, we believe Mr. Frayling is very conscientious and worries considerably about the various equipment in the school, and it is not to be expected that he should be a qualified man in all phases of the school activity. Therefore he has to rely somewhat on his engineers for the care which is given the various equipment. This care it is possible has not at times been 100%, and in this we refer to the batteries only. What we mean is that considerable care is required to properly take care of a battery in regards to charge and discharge, cycling, and over-charge, and is something that has to be taken care of at regular intervals.

However, Mr. Frayling was very interested to get all the particulars in regards to this and no doubt will be in a better position to know if his engineers are carrying out his instructions.

We trust we have covered the existing conditions at the School to your satisfaction and are sorry for the delay, but the writer did not get back to Winnipeg as early as anticipated.

Yours very truly,

MUMFORD, MEDLAND, LIMITED,

Mr. Christianson, Chief Supt. of Agencies, and Mr. Waddy, Indian Agent, are right here and can reach this school in very short time. If either of these gentlemen complain of my seeming neglect, or inability to cope with the position which I have held for eleven years I will endeavour to work on a line they suggest. And again considering that supervision of schools is a part of their many duties, they should be better able to know or inform you than one sitting in an office some 1600 miles distant.

It is not my wish to be personal but when being written to in the strain recently used, and not forgetting that the position of principal demands respect, and that I am going to have irrespective as from what source, and I am sure you would if in my place.

Officials. I will then admit being neglectful, but not before.

Dear Sir;

The Venerable Archdeacon J.K. Irwin has forwarded me your letter to him dated Dec. 4th 1941, with an enclosure of a copy of a letter from Globelight Co. Ltd.

I mailed to you via "Air Mail", a letter answering the Globelight letter of November 28th, which should have reached you not later than the 30th, four days before your letter to the Archdeacon. My letter of explanation is such, that a copy might have accompanied the Globelight letter, which would perhaps have conveyed a not so neglectful impression. I mention this instance as it seems to me that any other opinion or suggestion is accepted but mine. I am on the spot all the time and know what is what; the other man comes along and runs off a line of stuff that is taken for fact instead of with suspicion; he sells the goods, I point out the defects, and get nothing but grief for doing what I am supposed to do i.e. look after the interests of the school and study economy.

Reverting to the question of economy; it is through my interest and suggestion of allowance that the Department saved $378.00 on the present batteries: the former batteries cost $630.00 and the present ones $252.00. A mistake is also made regarding batteries supplied to the school: those recently installed make the third set in eleven years, and on the guarantee with these it should be 1946 before renewing.

Mr. Montgomery (Mumford & Medland expert) recently here, in his report recommends the use of an additional unit for laundry service: this was suggested by myself (tho' not an engineer) years ago; which is somewhat a proof that I am not entirely ignorant of the condition, or so lax in my duty and interest as might be
For considerable time it seems that an absolute effort has been on foot from some source to do nothing else but find fault with this school and myself, and from various correspondence, that this school costs the department far more than any other Residential School. One cost far in excess of anything here is the recent new roof on the Muscowequan R.C. School; entailing I would imagine, some $1,500.00 to $1,600.00; and this on a more recent structure. (Our roof has leaked and been repaired without mention). It makes me wonder if the Principal of this R.C. school is censored to the same degree as myself when renovations are needed.

Every instruction given by the Department as to this school has been carried out; economy is enforced in every detail. Take the water question of some two years ago; I had an estimate from Smith Bros. & Wilson for a contract not to exceed $1,700.00: you will know what it cost; I believe nearly three times this figure! Where is economy? The Buildings here, School, Barns, Root House, etc., etc., are second to none in the Dominion so far as upkeep; and the yearly interior decorations have never cost the Department one cent.

I appreciate your having written the Venerable Archdeacon; he being a past principal of this school knows much of the difficulties that arise, but not to the same extent as myself, as funds during his term were more plentiful than since 1930.

May I conclude with the request that past correspondence be well perused before sentence is passed; as I firmly believe any Judge of the British Courts would exonerate me from all blame in this matter after the evidence on the Department files since 1933 was examined. It makes me think that if one sat in the office all day and let things take their ordinary course it would be more agreeable: But when one has a sense of honor for ones duty it is a difficult matter to just sit still and be satisfied. It is most hurtful to know that someone is always having a dig at you for some unknown reason, and doubly so when there is no foundation for such, as in this lighting plant complaint.

In duty bound I am compelled to write this letter that the Lord Bishop of Qu'Appelle, and the Venerable Archdeacon should fully know the strained conditions under which I am working, and your misconception of my endeavour to carry out the duties of a Principal.

Yours truly,

With reference to yours of the 13th inst. in connection with the Lister Automatic Lighting Units at the Gordon Indian Anglican Residential School. To familiarize you somewhat with the automatic equipment at this school, the operation of the units is as follows:

The small unit will start up at a certain wattage and the setting as to the amount of wattage can be varied. After the small unit has reached its total capacity the large unit starts up. The little unit then stops. The large unit carries the load until such time as it becomes fully loaded. Then the small unit starts up and they both run together on the peak loads. As the load starts to reduce the first plant to stop is the little one. As a further reduction in the load takes place the big unit stops and the little one starts, and the little unit continues to operate until such time as the load drops below the wattage setting of the relays.

With this information you will readily see that disturbing any portion of the connections of one or other unit disturbs both units as they are inter-connected. This is why we are opposed to the plan of disturbing the existing set-up in any way from present.

With reference to your suggestion of a switch on the batteries so that they can be discontinued when the large unit is operating the laundry equipment. This again disturbs the automatic relays, etc., for you must have a nominal charge going through into the batteries and the voltage of the unit...
running must be sufficiently high to also operate the various automatic coils, so that to add a switch to disconnect the batteries cannot be done.

The only alternative that we can offer is that during the days that they are washing that the rheostat on the large unit be turned back to the lowest point possible at which the automatic relays, etc. will still continue to function. This would possibly mean that at this lowest point there would still be approximately 5 amp. of a charge into the batteries. If the school can arrange the special charging of their batteries so that during this period of washing this charge, or even a greater charge can be utilized without damaging the batteries, then they could possibly get about 80% satisfaction from these arrangements. We believe that this is possible and that they would get about 60% satisfaction. During the writer's visit he outlined this possibility to the present engineer.

We trust the above covers the questions raised in your letter.

Yours very truly,

MUMFORD, MEDLAND, LIMITED,

DIRECTOR

This Branch has recently had considerable correspondence with the Principal of the above-mentioned school in regard to several matters affecting the management of the school over a period of several years. This Branch understood that your engineers did not approve of Mr. Swan's suggestions with which the Principal of the Gordon's School concurred. On the other hand a review of the correspondence with your Branch leaves us with the impression that your engineers decided upon a different plan which eventually cost considerably more than the one suggested by Mr. Swan.

In view of our understanding of the matter, and the very definite statement now made by the Principal of the Gordon's School, I should appreciate your reviewing the whole matter and commenting on the Principal's recent statements.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Water Supply, Gordon's Indian Residential Schools.

In reference to your memorandum of the 27th instant transmitting a copy of a memorandum from Dr. McGill regarding Principal Frayling's criticism of Departmental action in installing the intake for the water supply, I might say that the Principal's statement that the Departmental project was an absolute failure is not understood by our officers. If the Principal is referring to the original Departmental proposal then same cannot be said to have been a failure because it was never carried out in its entirety. If the Principal is referring to the work as constructed by the Department then his statement is not understood by our officers as the system, as installed, has functioned satisfactorily up to the date of inspection by Mr. Wallace last fall and the extract from the Principal's letter to the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch does not make any statement regarding any unsatisfactory functioning of the system at the present time.

Reviewing this project briefly, as you are aware from previous memoranda, Mr. Swan's proposal was to construct a concrete well with perforated wall and lead the water to it through a trench filled with gravel and sand to act as a filter. His estimated cost for this was $1,700.00. Mr. Dempster's proposal was similar but had the added feature of a five-inch pipe line laid in the bottom of the trench under the gravel fill. This proposal was preferred because it provided the advantage of a more assured supply. There is said to be considerable silt in the water which might in time interfere with the flow through the gravel bed. The estimated cost of this scheme was $2,850.00. If from this figure the estimated cost of the pipe installed, amounting to $400.00 as given in Engineer Dempster's estimate, is deducted, then $2,250.00 is obtained as Mr. Dempster's estimate for the same scheme as Mr. Swan estimated at $1,700.00.

With reference to the Principal's statement that if Mr. Swan's scheme had been accepted it "would have cut down the costs very considerably" it is obvious that this could only be the case on the assumption that the work could have been carried out for Mr. Swan's original estimate. In this connection Mr. Swan's information was evidently erroneous as Engineer Dempster in his report dated October 7th, 1938, states as follows:

"With reference to the water supply for the above school, the area of the lake from which the water is taken is approximately twenty-four acres as compared to thirty-five acres mentioned by Mr. Swan. The enlarged plan shows the survey of the lake and also the profile of the lake bottom taken by Mr. Lasoroka. You will note that Mr. Swan states that a depth of twelve feet is found at forty or fifty feet from the shore line. From Mr. Lasoroka's soundings it can be seen that a depth of twelve feet is reached at a distance of one hundred feet from the shore."

February 11th, 1942.

This will acknowledge receipt of your memorandum of January 30th, quoting the opinion of the Principal of the school that the water supply available and fit for consumption will be exhausted in about 1½ years.

This matter has been discussed with officers of our Dominion Water and Power Bureau, but they are unable as yet to predict any definite improvement in water runoff conditions in the area concerned, for the immediate future, although they are hopeful that such will take place.

As far as any other possible water supply is concerned, your attention is drawn to my memorandum of August 23rd 1938, transmitting a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, and a copy of a report prepared by Mr. Dempster. Mr. Dempster considered it practicable to bring water from Fort Lake, a distance of about 3½ miles, at an estimated cost of about $10,000.00, through a 2-inch pipe laid on the surface of the ground.

The estimated cost of this pipe alone was $6,600.00, which might be insufficient at present prices. Even if $10,000.00 or more could be secured for such a project, it would appear doubtful if authority could be secured for the purchase of so much steel for this purpose under present conditions.

It would therefore seem that the only course is to leave the matter in abeyance for the present, in the hope that increasing rainfall will take care of the school's needs.

Dear Sir:

You will recall I reported to you some time ago that the Venerable Archdeacon Irwin called at this office after visiting the schools in the Qu'Appelle Diocese. He reported on certain matters that were not satisfactory to the Indian committee, and amongst these was the water situation at the Gordon school.

Last Thursday afternoon I visited this institution with the new agent, Mr. R.S. Davis, who was transferred from Carlton to Touchwood, and while there we went over the water situation at the school.

To go back a few years, when the first institution was abandoned and a new school was going to be built, which later burnt down, we drilled several wells. This is only from memory but I know on several occasions I was at the well site where they were drilling and we spent a great deal of money on dry holes, finally arriving at the conclusion that it was impossible to find water by drilling. Therefore the present site between two small lakes was chosen.

There is no need for me to go into a long-winded report as you have the blue prints of the water situation at the school on file in Ottawa. The lake is approximately 300' from the school and an intake has been built in the lake where the water flows through gravel and is pumped up to a large underground tank beside the school. From there the water is pumped on to a large pressure tank in the basement and this pressure tank supplies the building with water. At one end of the pressure tank there is a filtration tank and from there the water flows through the pipes into the building. Therefore you will see by this that everything has been done to safeguard the water. The Principal admits that once in a while there is a little odour from the water but he has had samples analyzed by the Provincial Government here in Regina and the water has been found to be satisfactory for human consumption.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Since the school was built the lake....
Since the school was built the lake has gone down a great deal, in fact several feet. This is due to the extremely dry weather we experienced for over ten years. Last Summer, however, the lake was continually rising and is now 19" from low level. If we have a quantity of snow this Winter no doubt it will continue to rise. This lake is probably one mile to one mile and a quarter in circumference and hills surround it on practically all sides sloping gradually towards the lake. Therefore you will understand when there is a heavy rain or snowfall the water from these hills runs into the lake. No cattle or horses are watered in the above lake as there is another small lake on the opposite side of the school that furnishes the water for the livestock that are kept at this institution.

I think our Branch has done everything in its power to safeguard the water supply and have taken the only means possible to supply the school with water. If the lake in question went dry or the water became polluted, it would be a question of closing the school because, as I have said before, it was found impossible to locate water by drilling in the vicinity of the location of the school. However, as the water is 19" higher than it was last year, with extremely heavy rains similar to those we had during the past summer and probably some heavy snowfalls, it should not be many years until the lake again reaches its high level.

Therefore, in my opinion, Providence will very likely take care of the water situation at the Gordon School for many more years to come, particularly since the rainy seasons seem to be on again. This last Summer was the wettest we have experienced for years.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,

Dear Sir:

Re Water Supply Lake

In 1942, I gave you figures and amount of water which supplies this school for all its needs, the normal daily consumption is around 3000 gallons per day. The attached sketch will enable the Department Surveyors to gauge how long the supply will last.

In January 1942, no. 4, paragraph of my letter respecting the water question, and the failure of the project under the contract given to one Mr. McDiarmid, Regina, when the "CRIBBING" broke, is shown in the sketch, the intake pipe that was supposed to aid the system is now in dry gravel, and the cement well has six feet of water, that being our whole supply. Your reply to my report was that you had forwarded the information to the Water Department, to date nothing has happened.

In case of FIRE, we have little protection, apart from the daily needs. I am bringing this again to your notice, to cover myself in case of happenings.

Yours truly,

Principal.

TOUCHWOOD AGENCY -

Gordon Reserve -

Gordon's School - is in excellent condition and well managed. The barns, machine sheds, stables, are in the best possible condition - nicely painted and the barnyards, spotlessly clean. There is a very fine root-house - large and in good condition. About 500 bags of potatoes still available, but there is no market for them, as there is a surplus in the district. Mr. H.W. Frayling deserves a great deal of credit for what has been accomplished. Trees have been planted, which makes the whole appearance attractive. He engages senior Indian boys at $35.00 a month to work during the holidays and by constant supervision gets a great deal of work done.

One of the large storage water-tanks - approximate capacity 2500 gallons - has sprung a leak. As at many other schools they are placed in positions without thought of future repairs that might have to be done. Agent Davis forwarded a request to Mr. Christianson to have the tank repaired during the summer holidays. Mr. Christianson wrote back that after consulting with repair houses in Regina the tank must be dismantled and sent to Regina. He instructed Mr. Davis to have Mr. Frayling take the tank out of the building. To do this - first a tank, similar size, mounted above, would have to be moved - then the cement foundation of the school - about 2 ft. thick - would have to be torn away, almost big enough for a team of horses to pass through. How ridiculous! I asked Mr. Davis to make enquiries of men in the district suggesting that most likely the tank could be opened from the inside and sealed up again without dismantling. After he obtains this information he will submit his request direct to Ottawa, as it is imperative that this work be done before school opens.

Water - at the school may be a problem in the next few years. The small lake from which the water is obtained is gradually receding.

Dr. Simes introduced me to Mr. G.M. Bushel, who is a member of the school diocesan committee of the Anglican Church. He told me that there was an agitation started to remove Mr. Frayling. It seems that the Anglican Priest at the school got the Indians to sign a petition, or rather an ultimatum, that Mr. Frayling be removed. If not, they would not send their children to school and would ask the Roman Catholics to take over the school. Indian problems and a rebellious Priest make a good combination.

J.K. Morris, Welfare Division

Memorandum:

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re:- Water Supply, Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

On October 16th last the writer visited the above school to gain further information regarding its water supply. The following conditions were noted:

The water level in both the lake and well stood at elevation 90.0 feet indicating a drop of 1.2 feet since April 20th of this year. A pumping test was made similar to that carried out last spring. It took approximately one hour to lower the water from elev. 90.0 to elev. 85.5 (i.e., bottom of outlet pipe) in Chamber "A" and to elev. 86.5 in Chamber "B". As was the case this spring, all inflow to the well occurred through the lowest row of holes at elevation 85.7; this row of holes runs full and with considerable force. It was discovered that the upper rows of holes below water level were not plugged within the wall of the well so it would appear that the filter gallery is clogged above the lowest row of holes.

It was learned from the engineer of the school that during this fall, for average consumption of water, it was necessary to pump the well twice daily to maintain the school reservoir full. This spring one pumping operation was sufficient. An attempt was made to see if the 6" G.I. inlet pipe could be utilized to draw water from a greater depth. The wooden plug covering the end of this pipe within the well was removed but no flow occurred, indicating either a plug at the other end of the pipe or the pipe clogged with earth or some other material. To make use of this pipe it would appear necessary to excavate part of the filter gallery in order to remove any plug or clean the pipe, as the case may be. This would entail excavating possibly 60 cubic yards of gravel, some sheet pile work, and dewatering a portion of the gallery. There is at present about 5 feet of water over this pipe. The above operation apart from being expensive, would only draw water from a greater depth of 0.9'. It is feared that should the above work be done in cold weather the filter bed would freeze during operations and thus cut off the supply completely.

(Sgd.) O. J. Storsater.

D. B. Gow, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Department of Mines and Resources,
332 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
November 7, 1944.

Memorandum:

Re: Water Supply, Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Saskatchewan

Attached is a copy of a report, in duplicate, dated November 3rd by Mr. O. J. Storsater, a member of the staff of the Water Power Bureau in Winnipeg, relating to the water supply at the above school.

In a covering letter, dated November 3rd, Mr. Gow states as follows:

"You will note from this memorandum that the elevation of the lake has dropped 1.2 feet since April 20th of this year and that the water supply situation has accordingly deteriorated considerably throughout the year. It would appear, however, that there is ample water supply at the present time and that the lack of flow through the upper rows of holes into the well was not caused by frost penetration. We are hopeful, therefore, that a continuous water supply will be available for the Institution throughout the coming winter. However, no assurance can be given that failure of the water supply will not occur."

It is now apparent that the filtration gallery is choked with silt, except for a seam which supplies water to the lowest row of holes in the well. When this seam finally silts up, no water will reach the well.

As the pressure of water entering through the lowest row of holes is relatively high and as the ice will tend to keep the silt from being stirred up, total failure of the water supply is unlikely to occur this winter although, of course, no definite assurance can be given in this connection. However, unless there is a heavy fall of snow this winter and rainfall next year, there is a possibility of failure next year due to the low water level in the lake, combined with windy weather, which might result in the complete silting of the gallery, or the formation of so much ice that the amount of available water might be considerably reduced during the winter and early spring.

Enc.

Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,

The telephone line from the edge of the Reserve to the School is in very bad condition. Yesterday the telephone was off for several hours, and on investigation we found a post down, rotted away and there are several other posts in a similar condition, and it is very evident that the line will very shortly be altogether out of order, for this and several other defects. The telephone is a convenience and necessity for the School as well as for the Indians on the Reserve who constantly use it, especially in the case of sickness. I shall be very grateful if you will take this matter up with the Department of Indian Affairs. GORDON'S SCHOOL

This school has gone down a lot and Mr. Dance has had a lot of trouble with staff as he took over when all the trouble was on switching Principals etc., during the school year, something which should never have been done until the start of a new school year. Since he has taken over he has improved conditions as far as farming goes as he has put in more crop and done some summerfallow, and if given half a chance will no doubt make a success of it as he is very interested in his work and is very energetic. However it is very hard for a man of 57 to make over a position like this without previous experience, and in my opinion is a job for a younger man.

The education of the children is the same as it was before, absolutely no improvement has been made. This was one of the things I understood the Department was anxious to get rid of Mr. Frayling for. However, in my opinion, the children of this school have been, and are now receiving, as good an education as children in any other boarding school.

Considerable repairs are needed and will have to be done in the near future. However this school is in wonderful condition for the amount of money spent on it by the Department in the last 12 years. Anything that was done up to the present has been paid for mostly out of school grant. The new water tanks are on hand and will be installed as soon as I can get men to do the work.

Re: WATER SUPPLY, GORDON'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
AT FUNNIHAY, SASKATCHEWAN

An inspection of the water supply system at the above-mentioned institution was made on June 20th and 21st by the writer.

Present Water Supply System:

1. The present lake level was at 80.2 on June 20th - 0.2 ft higher than on Oct. 16, 1944. A chart showing the lake levels since 1932, based upon the data available, is attached hereto. There is apparently sufficient water available to supply the school another year and possibly longer. It is probable that so long as the lake level is at elevation 88 or higher there will be an adequate supply of water.

2. The chief complaint against the present supply is that during certain seasons the taste and odour of the water are offensive, due to stagnation of the water in the lake. Analyses of the water have been obtained from time to time and have never found it unfit for use. On June 21st the water was quite good with no appreciable taste or odour. Recent heavy rains probably were responsible for its comparatively good quality.

Recommendation

The construction plans dated Jan. 31, 1939, show the gravel bed extending down to 6' above the bottom of the intake well or elevation 84.7, while the lowest row of holes according to Mr. O.J. Stenner's plan of April, 1944, is at elevation 84.7. We should therefore suggest drilling an additional row of holes at elevation 84.7. If this does not result in a substantial increase in the rate of inflow, the 20 ft. length of C.I. pipe could be made use of as an additional intake pipe. I would suggest rupturing the end of this pipe furtherest from the well with a light charge of dynamite, well tempered. This pipe is of no use at present so it may as well be broken if it is of advantage to do so. The explosive charge could be inserted from the well end of the pipe with a flexible leading stick. The cost of this work depends on the skill of the labour, but with even the most experienced should not be more than $50.00 for material and labour, plus the cost of engineering supervision if this is considered necessary.

Alternative Water Supplies

Spring - 1/2 miles south - There is a spring or well located about 1/2 miles south of the school. This was visited and found to be an unribbed well about 4 feet deep in very stony ground. The well was partially bailed out and the rate of inflow measured as 1900 gals per day. This rate is probably higher than could be maintained without lowering the water table. There is no visible flow of water or seeps go away from the area containing this well, although the ground is about ten feet lower 500 ft. to the north west. This well has been used by several Indian families for the past two or three years, summer and winter, without lowering the water level. A stadia traverse, using vertical angles for elevations, was run from the intake well by the Lake. The spring was found to be 3100 ft. south and 1200 ft. east of the intake well at the lake and to be at elevation 127, using same datum as for the lake levels. The intervening country is rolling and a location survey would have to be run before an estimate could be made of the costs of trenching and laying pipes for a gravity line.

At the request of the principal of the above-mentioned institution, an inspection of the septic tank was made on the occasion of my visit to the school on June 20th and 21st.

The septic tank was found to be operating satisfactorily at the time of inspection, but during the late winter the outlet pipe became clogged to such an extent that there was no discharge from the system. The tank was pumped out and the outlet cleaned, but after a short time the same thing occurred again. The cause of the trouble is apparently due to the absence of a submerged outlet from the tank to the discharge pipe. There was an elbow in the original installation but it has been corroded and dropped off. The concrete walls of the tank are also showing the effects of long exposure to the septic sewage. I estimate that 50% of the concrete is gone (that is, disintegrated) in the section exposed to view.

Recommendation

Installation of a new elbow by inserting a pipe of smaller size into the outlet pipe for a distance of approximately 2 feet, with an elbow and 12" length of pipe attached to the other end to hang down into the tank.

A new tank will probably have to be built before many years have passed, and I do not consider it economical to incur much expense on repairs to the existing tank. I would suggest that $20.00 be made available for this repair work.

Fort Lake - Was investigated some years ago and turned down as a source of supply. The water level in this lake is said to be some feet lower now than at the time of that survey so I did not visit the lake on this trip.

The supply of water in the lake is sufficient in quantity to supply the school for a year if the proposed alterations to the well intake are carried out. It is very desirable that a more satisfactory supply adequate for drinking and cooking purposes at least be developed. As a new supply for all purposes will probably be necessary eventually, it is doubtful if developing a separate supply for drinking can be justified economically unless done at a nominal cost.

The spring 1-1/2 miles south of the school referred to above, is certainly not large enough to supply all requirements. The cost of piping this water to the school for drinking purposes alone could not be justified.
