In further reference to the above subject concerning the questions brought forward in Mr. Mills' letter to you of August 1st:

Shallow wells might be developed in the locality by intensive exploration and testing with an auger but it is my opinion that several of these would be necessary to supply the school. Each would probably have to be located in a separate drainage basin to insure continuity of supply so it is not likely that one pipe line would serve more than one well. I do not think open ditches for carrying the small quantities of water involved would be practicable as most of the water would be lost by absorption into the soil. The topography in this locality is rolling with poorly developed natural drainage. In running the survey from the well, 1½ miles south, four undrained depressions were crossed varying in elevation from 95 to 114, and five intervening summits varying from 139 to 146 in elevation; which is fairly representative of the country south of this school. The school itself is on high ground and I do not believe any well water could be found which would run to the school by gravity. In any scheme using shallow wells, I would suggest conducting the water to the concrete well in preference to the lake as sufficient water to raise the lake level materially is not likely to be found.

In considering the water supply lake again, I have come to the conclusion that the reason for the continuous decrease in water level is that the school's requirements plus evaporation, exceed the inflow from runoff plus precipitation. This excess has caused a decrease in water level averaging about 6 inches per year since the erection of the school.

An estimate of the annual inflow from runoff can be made as follows:

Annual evaporation, at least ........................................... 30 inches
School use, annually @ 6,000 gallons per day = 8 acre feet
from 30 acre lake or .................................................. 4 inches
(less annual precipitation (long term mean, Regina, Yorkton, Alask) ........................................... .14 inches

With no inflow lake would drop .................................... 20 inches
Average annual drop in W. L. ........................................ 6 inches

Hence average inflow per year is ..................................... 14 inches

The present area of the lake is about 20 acres, an inflow of 25 acre-feet is indicated for the average year, which is about 3 times the consumption at the school.

D. B. Gow, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Department of Mines and Resources,
532 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
At present the depth of water in the lake is about ten feet and algae and weed growth cause an objectionable deterioration in the quality of the supply during certain periods of the year. The problem then is to confine the lake or a portion of it to an area sufficiently small that the evaporation loss will not be serious and sufficiently deep that weed and algae growth will not be a nuisance. One method of doing this would be to construct a dugout or reservoir at the side of the lake. A reservoir 40 feet wide and 290 feet long at the bottom, at elevation 60, with 3 to 1 earth slopes extending upward to elevation 100, would hold about 700,000 cubic feet or 15 acre-feet of water below elevation 80, the level of the lake bottom. About 60,000 cubic yards of material would have to be removed from the lake shore and bottom and deposited in the form of levees about 250 feet off shore to construct the reservoir. The surface area of the water in the reservoir at elevation 80 would be about 1.5 acres, so that the evaporation loss would be about 4 acre-feet per year in the reservoir.

If this reservoir were constructed, I would not anticipate that it would hold all the water in the lake and the two would be at about the same level, connected by either a culvert with a control gate or by a porous gravel gallery through the earth fill. The advantage of the reservoir would be its greater depth, comparative ease of controlling weeds and algae, and consequently better quality of water. It also seems probable that it would offer a permanent solution to the water supply problem, although it would be costly. No field information was obtained for this proposal. If it is considered, information on soil conditions, cross sections of the lake shore, sounding, etc., will be necessary.

Re the filter gallery. Although the gravel feeding the upper rows of holes is partly clogged with silt, the water is entering the well from the lake with sufficient ease to supply the school without difficulty. I suggested drilling extra holes lower down in the well to increase the flow from the lake and also to safeguard the supply against the action of frost during the winter as it is probable that the W.L. will be lower next winter than it has ever been in the past. Replacement of the gravel or cleaning it would be expensive as it would have to be done below the present water level. It does not seem economical to do so at present when the source of water supply is in doubt.

I have no information on the gate which was designed to cut off the flow into the well. I did not see it in the well. In any case the flow could be stopped if it is necessary to do so, by driving wooden plugs partially into the holes. The plugs could be pulled out afterwards.

G. M. Lyon,

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA

I have to report that I visited the Gordon's Indian Residential School yesterday in company with Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Touchwood Agency, and I find the water situation there is bad. In 1936 a system of a coffer dam and sand and gravel filter was installed at the lake near the Gordon's School. The water from the lake filters by gravity through the gravel and sand to a well on the bank of the lake. The depth of the water at the lake has gradually receded to the point where there is only a very small quantity of water filtering into the well. So far as I am aware the only solution is to deepen the well, remove the present gravel, and sand, deepen the excavation 2 or 3 feet, and refill with clean new gravel. The probable cost of new gravel would be in the neighborhood of $200.00. The necessary work would be in the neighborhood of $200.00. This would provide water for washing and bathing purposes if chlorinated. As the water in the lake has not been replenished this year it has lost much depth by evaporation and is very stagnant. It also has quite an unpleasant odor. The staff of the school are complaining that it is making them ill and they refuse to drink it.

About 2 miles away from the school there is a spring which could be dug out, properly cobbled, and covered, thus providing a supply of drinking water. The drinking water from the spring could be hauled to the school in a tank but the school has no tank available for hauling the water.

I would recommend that authority be granted immediately for the expenditure of $200.00 to have a tank constructed for hauling the drinking water. The matter of wash water is also urgent and if funds are available authority should be granted for the work which I have proposed at the earliest possible date as it will have to be done before freeze-up. Mr. Dance and Mr. Davis are preparing requisitions in connection with this and forwarding them direct to Ottawa. This letter, therefore, is only in support of the requisitions which you have received or will receive within a day or so.

I would like to point out that this expenditure which I am recommending is a temporary, urgent measure to meet the present situation but if the lake continues to recede it is quite probable that a further heavy expenditure will be required to solve the water question at the Gordon's School within the next two or three years. In the meantime we can only hope that the snowfall which we can reasonably expect to have this winter will replenish the lake considerably and thereby overcome the loss of water which it has suffered this year. The Gordon's School cost a great deal of money and it is not many years since it was opened. In my opinion it was not erected in the right place in the beginning because small lakes in this country are not dependable as a water supply and this is a very small lake. I had a raft constructed yesterday in order to go out on the lake and ascertain the greatest depth. The greatest depth which I could find was about 8'. I understand that when the school was built the depth of the water was about 14' but 14' in a small lake is not a great deal of water.

I found that both Lister engines at the school are in very bad condition. One is completely out of working order while awaiting some small repairs. The other is working but there is a decided knock in it. This engine may be out of condition at almost any moment. The newly appointed engineer at the school is a man of probably 70 years of age and has had experience in steam engines only. I do not believe he knows as much about the Lister engines as I do. Mr. Davis is writing for authority to have a man by the name of Montgomery come from Winnipeg to overhaul the two engines. Mr. Montgomery is recommended to us as a Lister engine expert and I am informed that he will be able to do all the necessary work.

able to do all the necessary work to put both engines in good repair after he has found exactly what is wrong.

Three cows have recently calved at the school. One of them is not a milk cow at all, the other two are very poor milk cows. The only hope for a milk supply this winter is in the purchase of a number of new milk cows, I would say 8 or 10, which have recently calved or will soon calve. Almost no hay was raised on the school farm this year and Mr. Dance had to buy feed for the cows which he hopes to get, and the horses which he now has. Only 4 of these horses are of much use and more work horses are needed. The farm implements of the school are old and almost useless and will have to be replaced before the farm work can be carried out satisfactorily next year. I do not know whether the Department is prepared to assist the school in the purchase of needed animals and machinery either by grant or loan against school grant to be paid later but assistance of some kind is badly needed to put the school in proper working shape.

It has been customary to grow a supply of vegetables in the school gardens for use at the school. The crop of garden vegetables is almost a complete failure and vegetables will have to be purchased.

Reverend Mr. Dance, the present Principal, took over this school early this year with practically no staff and very little to work with. My impression of Mr. Dance is that he is an able and learned man but no Principal can do a good job in a residential school with as little to work with as Mr. Dance has had. I examined the supply of clothing recently purchased for the children and I find it almost adequate for the coming term. The school staff is complete except the exception of a matron and a cook. There is a Boy's Supervisor but I do not think a very satisfactory one. I am also not satisfied with the present engineer. He should be replaced with a younger man with the necessary qualifications to attend to daily repairs of machinery and other equipment. Most of the flush toilets are not working satisfactorily but all that is needed is cleaning out by a man who understands them.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, 11th September, 1945.

I am enclosing herewith requisition for materials and labour required for overhauling the heating system and flush toilets throughout the building at the Gordon's Indian Residential School, Touchwood Agency. This consists of $218.70 for materials and $250.00 for labour on the heating plant, also an estimated $50.00 for labour on the mechanism of the toilets.

Much of the equipment in this building is getting out of repair. This requisition is concerned with heating pipes which have become corroded with the result that new leaks are appearing every few days in different parts of the building. In addition to leaks in the pipes some sections of the radiators have started leaking, two of them very definitely the result of leaving a window open in the winter time and the heat turned off, resulting in freezing. I think the majority of the leaks are the result of deterioration by age and rusting. It will be necessary to replace all of the pipes which are weak and there are probably sufficient pipes on hand for this purpose. The $250.00 shown as labour is for a plumber who will have to be brought from Saskatoon, the nearest available plumber, and it would require considerable time to perform all the necessary work.

I have been reporting from time to time on this school and I can only add to previous reports in connection with the staff of the school that there is very little improvement. Reverend Mr. Dance, who has been the Principal since last January, has resigned, and the position is being filled by a Reverend Mr. Parry, regarding whom some correspondence has gone to the Department from the Bishop of the Diocese. I am not prepared to say whether he will be an improvement on Mr. Dance or not but I am prepared to say that the Department will be continually paying for new equipment and repairs to old equipment until the school authorities are able to secure the services of a properly qualified engineer and I do not think they will secure one at the amount of $35.00 a month and full maintenance which they are now offering. I have discussed this with the officials of the Diocese on several occasions. They have made a change recently but the man newly appointed will not stay.

I have received a confidential report to the effect that several of the children have lice and several others have Impetigo. The source of my information is authentic and I have no reason to doubt its truth, but I have not visited the school since receiving the report.

In my report of the 6th...........
In my report of the 8th ultimo on this school I mentioned in the last paragraph thereof that the supply of clothing for the winter was almost adequate. When I said almost adequate I had in mind the question of footwear as only a small amount of footwear had been received and Mr. Dance assured me that the remainder of the requirements had been ordered and were expected every day. This footwear has not yet arrived and Mr. Davis, the Indian Agent, tells me that a number of the children are practically without shoes.

In the same report I mentioned that I was not satisfied with either the engineer or boys' supervisor. Both of these have been replaced but with no apparent improvement. The school is still without the services of a suitable kitchen matron and I have been in receipt of complaints from the Indians about the food. Certainly the children are not getting sufficient meat or variety in their food.

With regard to the water situation, which has been the subject of considerable correspondence, and which was referred to in Department letter of the 25th ultimo, No. 121-1-5 addressed to Mr. Davis, the Indian Agent, I am now quite aware that the estimate which I made of $450.00 in that connection was far too low. At the time I made the estimate I had no definite information as to the construction of the filter. I now find that there was a depth of 13' of gravel in this filter which looked to me like probably 4' or 5'. Such a construction would be a large excavation job which can only be done by a dragline because it has to be performed in water and mud. It would cost from $200.00 to $500.00 to get the services of a dragline at the site because there is not one anywhere in that vicinity and the ones which are available in the province are very busy at other work. The excavation would probably cost another $200.00 to $300.00 and the necessary gravel to fill the new excavation plus the cost of re-arranging the pipe to the present well would no doubt be close to $1,000.00.

Instead of attempting to carry out such a project this fall when we are nearly into the winter, Mr. Davis is going to dynamite the gravel in the present filter in order to stir it up sufficiently to let an adequate water supply through for the winter. This will not be nearly as expensive as a new filter system and will probably meet the present urgent need. The Department will be advised further in connection with this phase of the matter as soon as the dynamiting has been done.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

GORDON'S SCHOOL

Mr. Dance the Principal of the school resigned and the new principal is Mr. Perry. He has only just arrived and I am hoping for some improvement.

The Principals appointed since Mr. Frayling left may be good preachers but they know nothing about running a boarding school and the school lacks organization and leadership. In my opinion the school has deteriorated about 70% since a layman was taken away as Principal. If things keep going as they have in the past, the Department will have to take strong action to see that this school is brought up to a higher level.

The general care of the children is nothing like it was when Mr. Frayling was principal.

The new pressure tanks have been installed and engines overhauled. The mechanic from Munford Medland Co. of Winnipeg who overhauled them advised me they were in worse condition than any engines he had overhauled in a boarding school. As soon as I can get the supplies I will dynamite a pipe which is plugged in the drainage pit and when this is done I expect we will have enough water without digging out all the gravel, as was suggested.

As instructed in Department letter of the 19th instant, No. 121-1-5, I visited the Gordon's School on the 23rd instant, meeting Dr. A.B. Simes, Medical Superintendent, there by arrangement and without advising the school authorities that we were going. The delay in reporting to the Department was because Bishop Knowles had some delay in calling together his committee to discuss the question with me. I now have to report as follows:

Examination of the children in the classrooms disclosed the following: 42 had lice in their hair (most of these were girls); 17 had Impetigo; and 2 had Scabies. 36 children were without underwear; 77 had either no stockings or stockings which were not fit to wear; and 43 were wearing shoes which were not fit to wear for one reason or another. Some of these shoes were running shoes, some were laced rubbers, but for the greater part they were leather shoes worn out or nearly worn out.

Examination of the children revealed also that much of the clothing which they were wearing was very dirty and I am certain that the children are not getting regular baths.

In the sewing room there was a great quantity of underwear and stockings waiting to be mended mostly consisting of clothing carried over from last term and partly worn. However, it required only mending in order to render it satisfactory for use. Two good purposes would be served by the mending, first in teaching such work to the girls, and secondly by the teaching of thrift and the care of clothing which Indians badly need.

In order to furnish the Department with some concrete figures as to the clothing needs we visited the store-room where the new clothing is kept. Because the clothing is stored in a small room where it is impossible to sort it in sizes or even in varieties, it was impossible to get a good check of it. I am reasonably certain, however, that much of the boys' underwear is in the larger sizes and there are about 30 small boys without underwear. As well as we were able to ascertain clothing has been bought for the children with little regard to sizes. With many staff changes, as this school has been having, it naturally follows that the new staff member taking over a particular part of the work has no guide other than his or her own powers of observation. Neither the Principal nor the Matron of this school has been there long enough during the last nine months to have learned what variety of clothing is needed. When little boys have learned they have not been successful in passing on to others. For this reason I informed the Matron that she should at once insist upon having a larger room for the storage of the clothing and get it sorted in such a manner that she could tell very quickly the various stocks which were getting low. There is a room adjoining the boys' playroom which is not being used for anything at the present time and which would be quite suitable for this purpose. In previous reports I have mentioned the shortage of footwear at this school. When making enquiries about the footwear twice in the past I was informed by Reverend Mr. Dance, the Principal of the School, that footwear was expected any time and was on order. Now no one seems to be very sure whether this footwear is coming or not. In any case they need both boys' and girls' shoes in all sizes, rubbers for the girls and some kind of waterproofs for the boys to wear when playing and when working around the stables and outbuildings. As stated I examined all the children who were in the classrooms but there were a number of the children at other places who were examined later. A number of these were boys who came from the stables and outbuildings where they had been working. There had been a recent fall of snow and considerable moisture around, and the boys were working in old leather boots.

All had wet feet and there is...........
All had wet feet and there is certainly no waterproof footwear in the school stock. The present Matron had been at the school only one week but was in charge on the day of our visit because the Principal was away. One would naturally expect that with experience of only one week the Matron would know little about the school and should also expect that she would know something about her duties. She did not seem to know what duties, responsibilities, or authority she had and I feel certain that the Principal had not taken the trouble to furnish her with the information. She seemed very willing to learn and anxious to succeed. I believe her previous experience has fitted her for the work but the Principal should not have left the school until the Matron was at least aware of her duties and responsibilities. She did not seem to know that she had a right to tell others what to do and a responsibility to see that her orders were carried out.

As a result of the complete disorganization of this school the children's meals are not managed in a proper manner. There seems to have been no planning whatever in the handling of the food. There has been no kitchen matron permanently in charge since the school opened this term. The result has been that the temporary cook prepared meals from time to time with what happened to be on hand. I tried to ascertain from conversation with the Matron whether the children are actually getting a balanced diet or not. She did not know what the children had been receiving for their meals during the past week but she had prepared the noon meal of that day. It consisted of baked beans, bread, buttermilk, and jam. I intended to be at the school in time to see this meal served but bad roads and delay in leaving the office in the morning resulted in my arriving shortly after noon. However, Dr. Simes and I were present when the evening meal was served to the children. It consisted of the following:

- A very small slice of bologna; potatoes; and bread with a small quantity of lard and a very meager quantity of skimmed milk. This was about one third of a cup each. The Matron told me that the children's supper consists mostly of bread and jam when they have jam. I had criticised this strongly which was probably the reason why they had potatoes and no bologna at this meal. The salt cellar on the boys' table was a 1 lb. jam tin with some holes in the top. I would expect to find this in an Indian house but not in a school where the Indian children are supposed to be taught how these things should be done. There is room in the children's dining-room for another table but instead of installing another table the boys were crowded together at one long table in such a manner that they could hardly move. It is a certainty that the children of this school are not getting enough meat, only a small quantity of skim milk from the separator. No effort whatever is made toward furnishing them with anything in the nature of a balanced diet and the meals are not planned. In addition to a planned weekly menu some effort should be made to make the meal a little bit more attractive and this will not be done until the school has the services of a reasonably well qualified kitchen Matron and the food is purchased systematically. Dr. Simes is going to prepare an inexpensive weekly menu for the school and I informed the Matron that the Department would expect the school authorities to follow this as near as possible.

The bakery and the shelves where the bread is kept were very unclean. I do not know how long it is since these shelves were properly cleaned but I feel quite certain that they have not been cleaned since I saw them the first week that school was opened. The junior classroom is on the third floor of the building. On my previous visit to the school I had noticed that the fire escape door of this room was locked with a padlock. I instructed Mr. Dance, the Principal, to place the key to this padlock in charge of the teacher in order that she could easily remove the children from the classroom in case of an emergency. This has still not been done. As previously stated, the new Principal, Mr. Parry, was away at the time of my visit and nobody present knew where the key to this padlock was. In case of fire or other emergency these small children would have had to go down a narrow stairway three flights to get out of the building.

On the day of my visit the gravel filter which supplies the wash water from the lake was dynamited. This stirred up the gravel sufficiently that an ample quantity of water is going through the filter now for washing purposes for the rest of the winter unless the ice forms so thick on the lake that it will interfere, which is not at all probable.

Nothing has yet been done about drinking water, with the exception that a dam is being constructed to be used for hauling drinking water from the spring. The water question was referred to in my report of the 16th of October and also of the 8th of...
and also of the 6th of September, on this school, and I need not add anything thereto. Mr. Davis is making a request to the Department for authority to make an effort to obtain a sufficient supply of drinking water from a well in the school yard. The man who was present, on the day of my visit, to dynamite the gravel filter, is also an experienced well man and he is of the opinion that a supply of drinking water can be secured at a depth not exceeding 50' and within the school yard.

In accordance with authority contained in your letter of the 18th instant the necessary action will be taken in connection with the heating plant and the mechanism of the toilets as soon as the services of a plumber can be secured.

With regard to the fifth paragraph of your letter referred to the Department will have received Mr. Davis' report in this connection dated October 17th.

With reference to the meeting which was held yesterday with the committee of the Anglican Church, I am sure the committee were quite aware of the need for immediate improvement at the Gordon's School. The engineer has been changed twice recently and is being changed again. A new man is coming at the end of this month and I am not prepared to say whether he will be satisfactory or not because I do not know him. The school authorities have been endeavouring for some considerable time to secure a satisfactory kitchen matron but without success. The Chairman of the committee informed me yesterday that the Selective Service office here in Regina has many similar positions to be filled and few applicants, therefore they have little hope of immediately filling the position with a suitable person. The present Boys' Supervisor is a Mr. S.A. Dodds who was farming instructor at the school and later farming instructor on one of our reserves; and not very satisfactory in either appointments. I have much doubt that he will prove satisfactory as Boys' Supervisor. I think there is a possibility that the new Matron will be satisfactory when she has been properly instructed in her duties. I took much time on the date of my visit to instruct her. This should have been done by the Principal, of course, but apparently he had not done so. However, I believe she now knows what her duties are.

The newly appointed Principal, Reverend Mr. Parry, had been at the school for three weeks at the time of my visit and I cannot see that he has done anything whatever in the way of improvement although I had some hope that he would when he was appointed. If he knows anything about the management of an institution of that size and the direction of the work of his staff in an efficient manner he certainly has not shown it. As he was absent on the date of my visit I did not have a chance to discuss the affairs of the school with him but I discussed them very thoroughly with the Matron and asked her to take notes of everything which I said and to take them up with the Principal as soon as he returned. The committee are also writing the Principal pointing out the various unsatisfactory conditions which I discussed with them. If he does not make an effort to immediately correct most of these unsatisfactory conditions he should not be allowed to remain. I had an interview with Mr. Parry before he was appointed and my discussion with him lead me to believe that he would make a real effort to improve conditions. He certainly seemed to know what was wrong. However, knowing what the faults of the past administration of the school were and having the ability to correct them himself are entirely different things and my present impression is that he lacks this ability.

I believe that a letter from the Department to the Bishop of Qu'Appelle to the effect that present conditions at the Gordon's School cannot be tolerated and that immediate improvement was expected otherwise the school will have to be closed, would be the best course at this time. Mr. Davis and I have both spent much more time in connection with this school than we should have and the work which we have been doing is the work which is regularly done by an efficient school. No matter how much time we put in the school will not be properly operated until they get an efficient Principal.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies, Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, October 31, 1945.

My dear Bishop Knowles:

The department is in receipt of a report dated October 27, 1945, sent forward by Inspector Ostrander immediately following an investigation by him of conditions at the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

It is my understanding that conditions at this institution were discussed by Mr. Ostrander with the members of the committee responsible for the selection of the principal and the employment of the school staff.

It is hardly necessary to state that I have found the subject matter of Mr. Ostrander's report very disturbing. It would be to me and I feel sure it would be to Your Grace very unfortunate if conditions at this particular school became a subject of public discussion, but I am disposed to think in view of the representations that have been made to me on behalf of the pupils in attendance that such a discussion is likely to take place unless we can have an assurance from you and from the members of the committee that this school will be placed immediately in charge of thoroughly qualified and competent officials.

It has occurred to me in view of all the circumstances that it might be advisable to have a thorough educational survey undertaken of the reserve or reserves on which pupils for this school are recruited. As a number of Indian parents seem reluctant to send their children to residential schools, would it be possible to come to an agreement whereby a certain number of the pupils living in close proximity to the school would attend as day pupils? In any event, I feel confident the Minister will want an assurance from me that conditions

.....have been

REPORT ON REPAIRING "LISTER" GAS ENGINES, TYPE "L" AT GORDON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, PUNNICHY, SASK.

Attention Mr. Ostrander. Oct. 1, 1945.

Date: September 25th to 29th, 1945.

Engines were found to be in very poor mechanical working condition, as the cylinder blocks showed water had been present in combustion area of cylinder heads. The valve seats and valves had been badly burned, also quite an area of the blocks in and around the valves had been burned, and there were small cracks showing.

As new cylinder blocks were not available it was necessary to cut valve seats to a maximum, and only a temporary repair can be expected.

The above condition applies to two of the cylinders, with one cylinder only slightly burned. Believe this condition due to engines running at an excessive heat causing head gaskets to leak.

The single cylinder engine crankshaft bearing surfaces were found scored and shaft out of round; one bearing housing was badly cut away, believed caused by bearing failure at some time allowing the crankshaft to rest on housing casting cutting away oil return, causing oil loss at this point. This condition is still present.

One automatic valve release coil requires shop repairs, and same was brought in to Winnipeg to have the work done.

Other repairs made were complete overhaul of both magnetos, fuel pumps and oil pumps.

We recommend the following parts be ordered at once for these units, so that at a later date they could be installed:

3 - Cylinder Blocks complete
3 - Cylinder Heads
3 - Pistons with pins and rings
1 - Crankshaft for single cylinder engine
6 - Valve Tappets and Tappet Guides
Necessary Bearings and Gaskets

I am enclosing herewith voucher for the amount of $2692.49 in favour of M. McNeil, Plumbing and Heating, Saskatoon, for overhauling the heating and water and sewage at the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

The cost of this work was far in excess of the estimate because the plumbers found that nearly everything had to be replaced. The account for materials alone amounted to $1040.30 plus freight and carriage.

With regard to the time of the plumbers in this work there was so much trouble with the water system while the plumbers were at work and the weather was so extremely cold that a great deal of their time was taken in thawing out pipes and trying to keep from damaging the school equipment, the heating plant of which had completely broken down. When the plumbers started work it was necessary to continue, to avoid suffering by the children and school staff as much as possible. During some of the time there was an inexperienced engineer on the school staff who was of little assistance to the plumbers. This also caused some confusion and loss of time.

I am enclosing a letter addressed to me from Mr. McNeil in explanation of the unexpected large expenditure and making an estimate of another $170.00 which will need to be spent as soon as the weather is warm enough and the ground is thawed. Also enclosed is a letter addressed to Indian Agent R.S. Davis by Mr. McNeil in which he makes an estimate of approximately $700.00 of the labour cost in the enclosed voucher as being not directly connected with the work for which he was originally engaged. This refers particularly to time spent thawing pipes and performing other temporary plumbing work in his endeavour to keep the building habitable, during some very cold weather.

I regret the delay in forwarding this account. Some time elapsed from the time most of the work was completed until Mr. McNeil was able to visit the school and make a personal examination of the work. The completed accounts reached me only today after much unnecessary delay by all of those concerned.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

Re: Gordon Res. Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

Enclosed please find invoices in regard to work completed at the above.

We would state that when we first checked this job in January we believed that all that would be necessary would be to increase return mains where necessary and replace some parts of defective return mains, install any necessary defective ballasts in rad traps, install condensation pump, make necessary repairs to closets and clear toilets, install gate valves in each one of the four steam main circuits where they leave the trunk main.

However, the first obstacle we ran into on the plumbing was that there wasn't a valve that would shut off the water and had to resort to shutting off the water at the main valve and take time to repair all the other valves. Then, the closet tanks proved to be in terrible condition, needing considerable repair work.

On working on the heating we found that the mains had actually rotted away in most cases and had to be practically renewed entirely with the exception of a two-inch main through the kitchen which had already been renewed.

At this time the water supply failed and as the engineer could not repair same or determine what was wrong we had to do what we could with it to enable us to continue with our work. After checking the pump and the pipe in the cistern we found that the underground pipe was defective and as we could not then renew this pipe because of frost etc. we installed an overhead line for a temporary hook up which took considerable attention owing to weather conditions etc. This underground line will have to be replaced when the frost is out of the ground and we would recommend that it be replaced with cast iron pipe with universal joints. We continued to have considerable trouble with the water supply as the engineer was unable to get any more than fifteen inches of water in his tanks although he made several trips every day to pump the water. We attempted to clear the line with our steel tape to no avail and considerable time was
lost at this work.

The work on the heating is not quite completed as the ballasts in some of the rad traps have not been checked, and the boiler needs washing out in the proper manner.

One closet bowl has to be installed and one closet must be repaired, and three more floor grates are necessary. This necessary work will cost approximately $170.00. This will place both plumbing and heating in first class working order with the exception of the filter between the tank and supply pipes. This filter needs re-charging and we understand that this is already being arranged for by the engineer.

We remain,

Respectfully yours,

M. McNEIL PLUMBING & HEATING

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 14, enclosing account of Mr. McNeil with regard to work done by his firm at the Gordon's School.

I have discussed this letter on two occasions with the Director, and it is difficult for us to understand why such a heavy expenditure was incurred without complete authority. The total account is $2,692.49 and such expenditure can only be authorized by the Minister. It will be extremely difficult to have this account passed, as the Minister should have been consulted before the expenditure was incurred.

The explanation given by Mr. McNeil is reasonably complete, but in your letter I cannot find any reference to your having been consulted or that the Indian Agent was consulted.

I also note on the voucher, which is signed by Reverend Mr. Parry and Indian Agent Davis, that they quote letters of October 19 and November 19 as authority for the expenditure. While, no doubt, you have these letters on your file, I attach copies of them and would point out that in my letter of October 19 an expenditure of $300.00 was authorized. This was the amount requested in your letter of October 18. In my letter of November 19 no expenditure was authorized; but you were simply supplied with information received from the Purchasing Branch in connection with securing radiators.

The account includes materials amounting to over $1,100.00. You are fully aware of the purchasing regulations

........... and
and, certainly, before any such expenditure was incurred, requisition should have been forwarded and authority received.

The account is therefore being returned, in order that the Principal, Mr. Davis and yourself may explain fully why such a large expenditure was incurred without authority from this office.

Before re-submitting the account, the voucher should be changed and should show distinctly that only $300.00 expenditure was authorized in official letter of October 19.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

With reference to Department letter of the 3rd instant, No. 121-1-S, in connection with the account of Mr. McNeil, Plumbing and Heating, 306-3rd Avenue South, Saskatoon, which I am returning herewith for reconsideration, I failed to mention in my letter that Mr. Davis had received authority by telegram dated January 29th, which read as follows:

"APPROVE EXPENDITURE NOT EXCEEDING ONE THOUSAND DOLLARS FOR MATERIAL AND LABOUR REPAIRING HEATING SYSTEM GORDON'S RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL PROVIDED INSPECTOR OSTRANDER AGREES THAT THIS EXPENDITURE IS WARRANTED STOP MR OSTRANDER CAN PURCHASE MATERIALS REQUIRED"

Following receipt of this telegram Mr. Davis discussed the matter with me and it was decided to proceed as we had waited from the previous October while trying to find a plumber to do the work and in the meantime the heating plant and sewage at the Gordon's School had become in such bad shape that the whole matter was very urgent.

It was realized, of course, that the cost of labour was gradually mounting but one repair led to another and all were so urgent because of the cold weather and the suffering of the pupils and staff that there could be no delay in completing the work at least to the point of immediate necessity for comfort and sanitation. As stated in my letter of the 14th instant Mr. McNeil was asked to keep a record of the time which was put in on work which should have actually been the work of the school engineer and which was not directly connected with the repairing and replacements for which he was hired. He did not keep a record of this but made an estimate of $700.00 as the approximate amount. A third of the pairs proceeded one part after another was found to be in very bad shape needing immediate replacement. It will be noticed in Mr. McNeil's account that he sent many telephone messages in connection with additions to the original order for material. These were all emergency requirements found necessary as the work progressed and there was no point during the course of the work where a correct estimate could have been made to find out exactly what the expenditure had been up to that point or what would be needed for the future. I was therefore placed in the awkward position of having to tell them to continue until the immediately urgent work was completed and the school could be heated sufficiently to prevent further damage.

I realize that this was a very large account to submit with only a part of it authorized but I would like to assure the Department that Mr. Davis and I were in continual touch with the work and while neither of us was anxious to see the cost mounting as it did we were in the position that if we had stopped the work at any point much more damage might have resulted for which we might have been blamed, both damage to the school building and equipment and danger to the lives of those living in the building.

My letter of October 16th asking authority for the expenditure of $300.00, and which was authorized in your letter of October 19th, referred to the need for overhauling the heating and sewage system in a few places. On this authority efforts were made for months to try to locate a plumber who would go to the school and eventually Mr. McNeil, of Saskatoon, made the trip to the school in January. His examination proved that there was much more repair needed than had been originally estimated and Mr. Davis' telegram of the 28th of January, and the Department's reply of the 29th, resulted from Mr. McNeil's estimate of that time.

It was impossible to submit a requisition for the purchase of the material required for this work as no one had any idea of what would be required until the work was well underway and then one.......
work was well underway and then one breakage after another needed immediate replacement to keep the system working to prevent freezing and damage in other places, and while the purchasing regulations permitted me to spend in emergency work only up to $300.00 I am sure that reference to the invoice will indicate that the majority of the material purchased was purchased as found necessary and could not have been requisitioned and purchased in the usual manner through the Purchasing Agent. I considered that this was in order in view of the last sentence of the Department's telegram dated the 29th of January addressed to Mr. Davis.

I have discussed this today with Mr. Davis and he has read this report and agrees with it in substance. If any further information is required from Mr. Davis I am sure he would be pleased to furnish it.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Regina, April 14th, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith voucher for the amount of $2692.49 in favour of M. McNeil, Plumbing and Heating Saskatoon, for overhauling the heating and water and sewage at the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

The cost of this work was far in excess of the estimate because the plumbers found that nearly everything had to be replaced. The account for materials alone amounted to $1040.30 plus freight and cartage.

With regard to the time of the plumbers in this work there was so much trouble with the water system while the plumbers were at work and the weather was so extremely cold that a great deal of their time was taken in thawing out pipes and trying to keep from damaging the school equipment, the heating plant of which had completely broken down. When the plumbers started work it was necessary to continue, to avoid suffering by the children and school staff as much as possible. During some of the time there was an inexperienced engineer on the school staff who was of little assistance to the plumbers. This also caused some confusion and loss of time.

I am enclosing a letter addressed to me from Mr. McNeil in explanation of the unexpected large expenditure and making an estimate of another $170.00 which will need to be spent as soon as the weather is warm enough and the ground is thawed. Also enclosed is a letter addressed to Indian Agent R.S. Davis by Mr. McNeil in which he makes an estimate of approximately $700.00 of the labour cost in the enclosed voucher as being not directly connected with the work for which he was originally engaged. This refers particularly to time spent thawing pipes and performing other temporary plumbing work in his endeavour to keep the building habitable, during some very cold weather.

I regret the delay in forwarding this account. Some time elapsed from the time most of the work was completed until Mr. McNeil was able to visit the school and make a personal examination of the work. The completed accounts reached me only today after much unnecessary delay by all of those concerned.

(Sgd) J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Dear Sir:

Re: Gordon Res. Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.,

Enclosed please find invoices in regard to work completed at the above.

We would state that when we first checked this job in January we believed that all that would be necessary would be to increase return mains where necessary and replace some parts of defective return mains, install any necessary defective ballasts in rad traps, install condensation pump, make necessary repairs to closets and clear toilets, install gate valves in each one of the four steam main circuits where they leave the trunk main.

However, the first obstacle we ran into on the plumbing was that there wasn't a valve that would shut off the water and had to resort to shutting off the water at the main valve and take time to repair all the other valves. Then, the closet tanks proved to be in terrible condition, needing considerable repair work.

On working on the heating we found that the mains had actually wrotted away in most cases and had to be practically renewed entirely with the exception of a two-inch main through the kitchen which had already been renewed.

At this time the water supply failed and as the engineer could not repair same or determine what was wrong we had to do what we could with it to enable us to continue with our work. After checking the pump and the pipe in the cistern we found that the underground pipe was defective and as we could not then renew this pipe because of the frost etc., we installed an overhead line for a temporary hook up which took considerable attention owing to weather conditions etc. This underground line will have to be replaced when the frost is out of the

(Over)
ground and we would recommend that it be replaced with cast iron pipe with universal joints. We continued to have considerable trouble with the water supply as the engineer was unable to get any more than fifteen inches of water in his tanks although he made several trips every day to pump the water. We attempted to clear the line with our steel tape to no avail and considerable time was lost at this work.

The work on the heating is not quite completed as the ballasts in some of the rad traps have not been checked and the boiler needs washing out in the proper manner.

One closet bowl has to be installed and one closet must be replaced and three more floor grates are necessary. This necessary work will cost approximately $170.00. This will place both plumbing and heating in first class working order with the exception of the filter between the tank and supply pipes. This filter needs re-charging and we understand that this is already being arranged for by the engineer.

We remain,

Respectfully yours,

M. McNeil,
Plumbing and Heating.

This school, as you are quite aware, is quite a headache. The whole matter was taken up with you in a separate report some time ago, so I feel it is no use again explaining the matter here. I still get a lot of complaints from the Indians about this school, some of them have advised me that until there is a change they will not let their children go back next year.

The plumbers have been working at the school much longer than they should have been as a lot of the time they were doing work which should have been done by the school engineer.

We struck water about three hundred yards from the school. The well digger advises me there is 4 feet of water in it. The well is 56 ft. deep, and there is a good stream flowing into the well and doesn't think it could be pumped dry with a 1½" pipe. The water is good and should overcome any problems for drinking water at this school.

I have asked the Principal to put a pail and rope on it and use the water for drinking purposes, but at the time of writing they have not taken a pail of water out.

The children are still drinking water out of the taps from water from the lake, and they get water from a spring for the staff. I am getting a pump and jack from Mr. Simpson, File Hills Agency, and have an engine, and as soon as this arrives I will put it in the well and pump the well out and see what flow we have. I will also have the water tested.

The lighting plant engines will all have to be rebuilt this summer. However, before we do this, I believe we should take the matter up with the Saskatchewan Power Commission to see what it would cost to run the power line to the school, a distance of eight miles. If the cost of this would not be too much, I believe it would be the solution to all our lighting problems out there.

R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

We are enclosing herewith a memorandum by Mr. G. M. Lyon of this staff relating to the water supply situation at the above mentioned institution. This memorandum was prepared following an inspection of the conditions and in accordance with the data requested in your letter of April 26th last.

It would appear from Mr. Lyon's memorandum that the water supply situation at this institution has now become rather serious and unless some solution is arrived at shortly, the conditions next winter will be critical. It does not appear as if water supply from Fort Lakes would be a permanent solution of an adequate water supply; and as pointed out in the final paragraph of Mr. Lyon's memorandum, some alternative scheme should be considered and information gathered for estimating the cost of such schemes. It would seem desirable to carry out Mr. Lyon's suggestion that a shallow well be developed and pumped to the school in order to supply a source of drinking water for all members of the institution and that a new pipe line be laid out into Gordon's Lake in order to supply a water supply for other purposes at the institution. Data that should be acquired, according to Mr. Lyon's memorandum, relate to the improvement of the water supply at Gordon's Lake by cleaning out some of the natural water courses leading into it.

It is desirable that the survey work, as covered by Mr. Lyon's estimate, be proceeded with in any event and that the investigation should include data upon which estimates can be made covering the laying of a new line into Gordon's Lake and improving the water courses leading into this lake. We have asked our Ottawa Office to authorize the engagement of two University students for the summer months, and should our request be acceded to, we will be able to detail an engineer and an assistant to this work.

Memorandum:

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re: Water Supply System, Gordon's Indian Residential School, Saskatchewan.

An inspection was made by the writer at the above school on May 17th.

Present Condition of Water Supply:

The water level in the water supply lake at the school was 89.0 on May 17th, compared to a water level of 90.2 on June 20, 1945 - a drop of 1.2 feet. It is likely that it was still lower during the past winter but no definite information in this regard could be obtained.

Last fall, alterations to the intake system into the well were carried out according to information received from the Indian Agent, Mr. Davis. Holes were drilled through the concrete at elevation 84.7, 12 inches below the bottom row but no flow of water was encountered, indicating that the gravel did not extend to this depth as shown on the plan. Then the 6" pipe intake, which was laid near the bottom of the filter gallery at elev. 85.3, was broken by a charge of dynamite. This resulted in a considerably increased flow of water into the well for sometime.

However, during the late winter the inflow into the well decreased considerably and great difficulty was experienced in obtaining sufficient water for school requirements. Mr. Davis said this was due to the school authorities leaving the well without sufficient protection from frost. He had new winter covers made to protect it against frost but some of them were never put in place. The well and the intake system eventually failed due either to frost or plugging up with silt and the school was without water, apparently for about three days. Another intake was laid directly into the lake and the pump moved down to the end of the crib, both entirely open to the weather and consequently had to be drained after every pumping operation. This system successfully operated for the balance of the winter and is still operating, but it is obvious that unless measures are taken to materially raise the lake level before next winter, the well intake will not operate without freezing up and the present uncovered line will not be satisfactory.

The writer endeavoured to have the concrete well pumped out at the time of inspection but the only pump available for this was a hand-operated sludge pump which was inadequate to dewater the well. The water was lowered a foot, however, and returned to lake level in one half hour so that the intake system cannot be plugged up and must have only been frozen last winter.

According to Mr. Davis, only the school staff has been obtaining drinking water from the spring 1½ miles to the south of the school, but the Principal states that the Indian children were also obtaining water from this source.

Future Prospects of Present Supply:

The present water supply will fail completely next winter unless remedial measures are taken. The water level in the lake has receded to elev. 89.0 and will probably be 88.0 by next fall, at which level the concrete well and intake system will be useless in cold weather.

--See Next Page.
Alternative Supplies:

1. Shallow Wells:

During the past winter, Mr. Davis caused two shallow wells, 24 inches in diameter, to be drilled in the vicinity of the school. One in the playground behind the school was put down about 140 feet through clay and encountered no water. The other, about 1,000 feet northwest of the school, encountered water in gravel at 43 feet and was drilled to 65 feet. Subsequently, a boulder fell in and blocked the hole at about 46 feet depth and the 24 inch casing only goes to that depth. On May 17th, there was about 3 feet of water in the hole but the inflow was not sufficient under pumping to furnish even a drinking water supply. The well driller stated, however, that before the hole was blocked by the boulder, he could not bail the well dry with his bailing bucket of about 8 gallon capacity, bailing at the rate of about one bucket in 1½ minutes. I would suggest that this well be cleaned out and drilled to a greater depth in the gravel, if possible, with an 18 inch auger. A perforated pipe or screen should be sunk as a casing for the portion of the hole in the gravel. It seems probable that this well will give a sufficient supply of water for drinking at least. If this well gives a regular supply of water, it is possible that other shallow wells could be drilled and water located which would be sufficient to supply the school's requirements from sources in the vicinity.

2. Fort Lake:

Mr. Dempster's report on replenishing Gordon Lake with water from Fort Lake, which report was prepared in 1928, is self-explanatory but conditions have changed. The writer, accompanied by the Fera Instructor from the school, visited this lake on May 17th, and found not one but two lakes, separated by a height of land about 8 feet above the present water level in the north portion of Fort Lake. This height of land is located where the cutoff, shown as dotted lines, appears on the sketch plan of November, 1937. Whether this cutoff was above water level in 1937 is not clear from the plan but in any case the two lakes, formerly known as Fort Lake, are now about two-thirds their former size - the larger third being the north lake. The sloughs between Fort Lake and Gordon Lake are now all dry land, except slough "A". The old creek bed, connecting this pair of sloughs, is now four to eight feet above the bottom of these dry sloughs so that no runoff is reaching Gordon Lake from its former drainage area further east than slough "G". The Fera Instructor, who is a native of the reserve, told me that this creek ran full every spring in the early 1920's but has not done so for many years.

The estimated cost of making a survey between Fort Lake and the school, taking soundings and etc., is as follows:

| Description                                      | Cost   |
|--------------------------------------------------|--------|
| Clearing lines (possibly two) - preliminary traverse and location line, 20 man-days @ $3.00 | $60.00 |
| Transit survey, assistant - 4 days @ $5.00       | 20.00  |
| Level survey, assistant - 7 days @ $5.00         | 35.00  |
| Soundings (Fort Lakes and Gordon Lake) - 3 days @ $5.00 | 15.00  |
| Rental and transportation for boat               | 25.00  |
| Maintenance - Departmental Engineer - 14 days @ $3.50 | 49.00  |

TOTAL...........................................$204.00

The country to be traversed is all well treed with thick undergrowth except for the sloughs which are open. In midsummer the
foliage is much heavier than in the autumn or spring so that more cutting will have to be done to get a line through. Apparently the engineer will have no skilled assistance whatever so that the surveying itself will be very slow. The above estimate is liberal for these reasons.

3. Shallow Well and Gordon Lake:

One shallow well should be developed and pumped to the school through an underground pipe line. This would involve the continued use of Gordon Lake for a general water supply with a new intake pipe into the lake without filtration. In connection with this scheme, it is probable that the drainage into Gordon Lake from the surrounding country would have to be improved by deepening the old creek channels and possibly ditching across some of the sloughs. There might also be required a dugout at some future date to concentrate the water resources in a small area, if the water level in Gordon Lake continued to recede.

As there may not be sufficient water remaining in the two Fort Lakes to make the pipe line a desirable solution to the water supply problem, I would suggest that alternative schemes should be considered and information gathered for estimating purposes at this time.

(Sgd.) G.M. Lyon.
Memorandum:
Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan

Referring to your notation on a copy of a memorandum from Indian Affairs dated April 26th, we informed Mr. Gow of the necessity for an inspection at the Gordon's School and forwarded him what information was available regarding a proposed scheme to obtain additional water from Fort Lake and we are now in receipt of the following reply:

"We have for attention your letter of April 26th with enclosures with further reference to the water supply at the Gordon's Indian Residential School near Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

"Late in September last, Mr. Davis, Indian Agent at Punnichy, called at our office and was loaned the plans showing details of the present intake and temporary measures for improving the water supply were outlined to him. Mr. Davis agreed to have these measures carried out and we now have your confirmation that the water supply had improved as a result. However, such improvement will probably be only temporary.

"Mr. G. M. Lyon of this staff is leaving Monday, May 13th, to visit our hydrometric stations in the Assiniboine and Qu'Appelle River Valleys and will visit the Gordon's Indian Residential School. Mr. Lyon has visited the school previously and last year prepared a report outlining a scheme for development of an adequate source of water at the present site. This report was forwarded you under date of August 4th last. Mr. Lyon will check on the present elevation of the pond at the school and the present water supply situation. He will also check on Fort Lake and insofar as possible, by observation, will note the possibilities of utilizing water from this lake to augment the present source of supply.

"A preliminary study of the proposals to pump water from Fort Lake to the Gordon's Indian Residential School tends to show that a 5" pipe line will be necessary; that the initial cost will be at least $18,500., that the annual operation costs will be $2,000. and that depletion of Fort Lake will eventually occur.

"Mr. Lyon will also arrange to visit the Lebret Indian Residential School and note the condition of the sewage disposal bed at that place. Upon his return to the office, after his 10-day or 2-weeks trip, Mr. Lyon will prepare a memorandum outlining his observations and a copy of the same, together with recommendations will be forwarded you."

We are prepared to agree with Mr. Gow that the original estimate of $10,000.00 to install an auxiliary line from Fort Lake might have to be considerably increased if the work is done under present conditions. The possibility of eventual depletion of the water in Fort Lake must be considered and that is a matter needing investigation.

You will be advised when a report of the contemplated inspection is available.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director, Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Water Supply, Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Sask.

With reference to your memorandum of April 2nd last, I am enclosing, for your information, copies of memoranda from Mr. Mills, dated May 14th and June 4th, of a letter from Mr. Gow, dated May 29th and of a report from Mr. Lyon also dated May 29th.

It will be noted that in his memorandum of May 14th Mr. Mills states that a preliminary study of the scheme to pump water from Fort Lake to the school indicates that the initial cost will be at least $18,500 and that the annual operation costs will be $2,000 and that there is no guarantee that doing this will be a permanent solution to the water supply problem at this school.

While the survey proposed by Mr. Gow may secure some useful information, it would appear, in any event, that the expense to pump water from Fort Lake is practically prohibitive.

We therefore concur in Mr. Mills' suggestion that the Indian Agent should be instructed to have the well 1,000 feet northwest of the school cleaned out and drilled deeper and if a fair supply of water is secured, a similar well should be drilled in the same general area. While we have no figures on the cost of the well already drilled 58 feet, it is thought the cost of a well 70 feet deep, might be in the order of $400.00.
If these two wells prove to be able to supply a fair quantity of water after they have been in use a few months, the question of pumps and a pipeline to the school can be taken up.

J.M. Wardle

Director.

Further to your letter #121-1-5 dated June 18, 1946, I have had the well at Gordon's Indian Residential School cleaned out. I did not have it sunk any deeper as the flow of water was not strong enough to warrant same.

Mr. Lyons from the Engineering Branch has been at the school for the past ten days to try to locate water.

A well was started west of the lake. It had some water, but not a sufficient supply. When down 30 ft it caved in so we abandoned it and started another about 75 yards from the lake. This well was sunk 14 feet with good prospects of getting a supply, if put down deeper. This hole is all rock and boulders, therefore will have to be dug by hand, making the cost $10.00 per foot. We will also have to board the men. An extra man will have to be hired, and we will have to obtain a pump, to keep the water out while the other men work.

Mr. Lyons and I have discussed the matter and we will keep the work going until we hear from you.

The Engineer's Department will make a full report on Mr Lyon's return to Winnipeg.

Will you please advise me if I am to go ahead as suggested by the Engineer, or will I stop all work until you receive the report from Winnipeg.

It is very hard to get men to do this class of work, and if it is stopped now, I may have trouble getting started again.

Please advise me by return.

R.S. Davis,

Memorandum -
To Mr. D. B. Cowe

Re: Water Supply for Gordon's Indian Residential Schools.

During the period July 1st to 17th, 1946, the writer examined the area around Gordon's School with a view of finding a supply of water to replace the existing supply which filters through a gravel-filled gallery from the water supply lake into a concrete reservoir. This supply failed last winter when the gravel froze to the bottom due to the low water levels prevailing at that time.

Various possibilities have been mentioned in the past for supplementary or alternative supplies, but none have been developed.

Two shallow wells drilled last winter under the direction of Mr. R. S. Davis, the Indian Agent, are shown on the plan.

Hole #1 at elevation 119.8 was drilled 140 feet deep 120 feet west of the school. The drilling was all in clay and no water was found.

Hole #2 at elevation 91.5, 700 feet northwest of the school was drilled to a depth of 68 feet. Four feet of water-bearing gravel was obtained in this hole from 48 - 52 feet. This hole was cleaned out to a depth of 50 feet and the inflow tested during the writer's presence. After standing overnight there was only 1/3 foot of water in the well. This was lowered to 2 feet after bailing out about 20 gallons in half an hour, indicating a low rate of inflow. While this well could supply some drinking water for the school, it is not likely that there would be enough water to supply the whole demand for that purpose.

The writer took soundings in the larger of the two Fort Lakes, the sounding party working from a raft which was located by angle and stadia distance from the shore. A sketch showing the Fort Lakes soundings is attached to this memorandum. The maximum depth of water was found to be 3.6 feet, but the average depth over the area of about 50 acres was only about 2.5 feet, a supply which I considered insufficient to justify any large expenditure of money. No survey was made between Fort Lake and the school.

WATER SUPPLY LAKE.

Soundings were taken in the water supply lake near the school and it was found that the greater part of this lake was about 6 feet with a maximum depth of 9 feet. This is
shown by contours on the accompanying map. As this is the only lake with an appreciable depth of water remaining in the area around the school I was inclined to the belief that there must be a groundwater supply feeding it. Outcrops of gravel and small boulders were noticed on the lake shore in two places, one on the north side and the other on the south side, the latter being only 200 feet from the recently used intake gallery and well. This gravel outcrop was tested with a 4-inch auger to a depth of 2 feet at the lake shore and to 4 feet 75 feet from the lake, it being impracticable to test any lower because of water in one case and stones in the second.

As Indian Agent Davis had some money available it was decided to test cut this area with a well-drilling outfit, using a 24-inch auger. Hole No. 5 was started 200 feet back from the lake at elevation 112.8 (22.6 feet above lake level). The log of the hole is as follows:

- 0 - 14 feet = Yellow clay.
- 14-22 feet = Water-bearing sand containing some clay.
- 22-39 feet = Grey-blue clay with occasional seams of sand.

I estimated the inflow of water into this hole as being about 200 gallons per day, which would be sufficient for purely drinking purposes, but little else. We were endeavoring to deepen the hole in the hope of striking the gravel, but the sand caved in and no further drilling could be done without cribbing so the hole was abandoned, temporarily at least, and the drill was moved down closer to the lake.

Hole No. 4 was started at elevation 102.1 (18.6 feet above lake level), 125 feet back from the shore line. The log of this hole was as follows:

- 0 - 8 feet = Coarse gravel with small boulders.
- 8-15.3 feet = Boulders, gravel and occasional clay patches.
- 15.3 feet = Water horizon.
- 15.3-16 feet = Large boulder embedded in walls of well on 3 sides, with gravel on other sides.

The inflow of the water was about 60 gallons per hour in this hole after the excavation had reached 15 feet below lake level. The work all had to be done by hand after the first 8 feet, so it was very slow. The writer attempted to blast the big boulder at least ten times with some old fuse caps and dynamite which Mr. Davis located in the locality. Only one explosion was obtained, due to the defective fuse and the boulder was broken on one end only.

It was decided then that it was worth while to move over enough to miss this boulder and put down a 4' 6" square cribbed well to a total depth of about 30 feet, which would be about 8 feet below the bottom of the lake. If the gravel continues to go down to that depth, this well should provide a reasonably good supply of water sufficient for the whole school's requirements for a good many years.
There is apparently some inflow of water from the ground to the south, because on July 17th the water level in the well was 68.57 compared to 95.38 in the lake. This water level was taken half an hour after pumping the water out of the well.

I drank some of this water and there was no objectionable taste or odor in it. Whether the quality will remain good after constant use I am not prepared to say, as there may be a much higher percentage come from the lake under these conditions. However, this well seems to offer the best possibilities for a water supply at a reasonable cost yet disclosed.

The sinking of the new well started on July 17th when I left the school and will continue under the direction of Mr. Davis. I don't believe he has sufficient funds to complete this well, which is estimated to cost:

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| Labor, excavation in boulders and water    | $50.00 |
| Well cribbing 1500 F.B.M. - 2" plank      | $100.00|
| Wooden pump for demisting                  | $50.00 |
| Contingencies - 10%                        | $45.00 |

As you are aware the Gordon Eskimo Residential school has been taken over by the Indian Eskimo Residential School commission and as you are no doubt aware this building and school has been getting worse for the last three years until the whole place is in a dirty deplorable condition.

Memorandum

Re: Water Supply - Gordon's Indian Residential School, Saskatchewan

The following has been received from Mr. T.T. Rose of Mr. Gow's staff in Winnipeg, under date of August 21st:

"In view of the early approach of the time for school reopening, the attached memo prepared by Mr. Lyon is forwarded immediately on its completion. Mr. Gow may see fit to further comment on the subject when he returns to the office.

It is considered the "Immediate emergency supply" described on the last page could best be put into effect in a short time as the supply pumped from the lake directly will most likely be at its worst during the next couple of months. This temporary provision could serve while the permanent extension was being installed. After a thorough test period would be enough to show in a week's time, whether the well would supply adequately to fill the school's needs. In that time the chemical state of the water flowing in would be stabilized and an analysis would be typical of a regular supply. Both these points would provide for a final decision whether to proceed with the more permanent installation.

Under present conditions of shortage in material supply, it is best to order for the permanent extension as soon as possible."

A copy of Mr. Lyon's report of August 20th is attached in duplicate along with single copies of the plan, profile and section through the holes.

Mr. Lyon suggests that the gasoline pump be set up temporarily close to the new No.4 well and to be used to test out the supply of water with the aid of some 2" pipe laid on the surface of the ground. It is also proposed to move the electric pump from the school down to the well and set it 9 feet below the ground level to operate the permanent water supply automatically to the pressure tank by means of the present pressure switch. This will entail the construction of a power line for about 800 feet which is a long distance to transmit direct current.

If the gasoline pump can be made to work satisfactorily in the temporary position, we feel that it should be used permanently if possible and thus leave the electric pump to operate in its present location to pump from the concrete storage tanks. We realize that the gasoline pump would operate temporarily at close to its maximum suction head and if it were sunk further in the ground to the 9 foot depth suggested for the electric pump, there might be ventilation difficulties.

Enclos.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

If the water in the well comes mostly from the lake, which seems likely, there is a possibility that the water level in the well will eventually recede unless precipitation should increase and the cycle of dry weather come to an end. A temporary installation seems to be indicated until further observation of the water level can be made.

As 4000 gallons of water are required each day during about 12 or 14 hours the usual consumption will require delivery of practically every gallon which flows into the well during that period and an automatic electric pump which comes into operation intermittently could not be adjusted to provide the peak delivery required at certain specific times without drawing water from a storage tank which could be filled at night when there is no water consumption.

The controlling factor will be the flow into the well and an automatic pump governed by the consumption might not always operate when water is available in the well.

It will thus be evident that two pumps are required, one to pump to the storage tank and the other to pump from the storage tank to the pressure tank when water is required for consumption or to restore the pressure in the pressure tank. A pump started by manual operation might be more satisfactory to handle the water from the well and deliver it to the concrete storage tank.

We will take the above matters up with Mr. Gow and would like to have your reaction to this memorandum.

In the meantime will you please arrange for the transfer of $1200.00 to our Service to cover the recommendations of Mr. Lyon and so that we shall have money to go ahead with this water supply installation as soon as we decide definitely on the installation to adopt.

T.S. Mills
Chief Engineer.
