Re:- Water Supply at the Gordon's Indian Residential School - Saskatchewan.

Since my last memorandum on this subject was submitted, a cribbed well has been sunk alongside auger hole No.4, under the direction of Mr. R. S. Davis, the Indian Agent.

On August 10th, Mr. Davis reports in part as follows:

"I pumped (this well) for half an hour with a centrifugal pump with a 2" stream and brought the water down 4 ft. The water comes in at the rate of 3 ft. an hour. The well is 4 ft. by 4 ft. and there is 10 ft. of water in it".

Using this information, the calculated rate of inflow is 300 gals. per hour or 7200 gals. per day, which is apparently more than sufficient to supply the school's estimated requirements of 4,000 gals. per day. The school has a population of about 15 adults and 110 children during the winter season. No pipes are laid from the school supply to the barn or gardens.

I left instructions to make the well cribbing 4½ ft. by 4½ ft. at the bottom, tapering slightly to the top so that it would be easier to sink the cribbing through the gravel as excavation progressed. If this was done, the above figures will be conservative.

The well is apparently only 23 feet deep if there is only 10 feet of water in it. Mr. Davis did not state and may not know if the bottom of the well is still in the gravel formation. Since the flow of water was apparently increasing as the excavation deepened, it is probable that the formation at the bottom was porous.

It seems safe to assume that a dependable source of water supply has been found which will continue to furnish a supply as long as the lake level remains within two or three feet of its present elevation. If the lake drops more than that, it is likely that the present well will have to be deepened and possibly enlarged as well, before sufficient inflow and storage capacity is obtained. As this may be done more economically when the lake is at a lower level, this operation may be postponed, temporarily at least.

Enclosed is a plan, profile, and section showing the location and details of the proposed works necessary to supply water from the new well to the school.

Extension to existing 3" Pipe Line:

A pipe line, 250 feet long, is necessary to connect the new well to the existing 3 inch line. This connection should be made seven or eight feet from the old pump house and run straight from there to the

It is proposed to enlarge the excavation at the well and construct a pump room below the surface about 5 feet wide, 9 feet long, and 9 feet below the surface. The well crib itself will form one end of this room with a manhole through the roof over the well. The walls should be built with 2 inch plank and covered with a roof 2 feet thick filled with sawdust for insulation. The cost is estimated as follows:

Power line from school to well:

Power at the school is obtained from a diesel engine and generator installation which charges a series of storage batteries which supply power at 110 volts, direct current. To operate an electrically driven pump at the well it will be necessary to run a pole line down to the well from the school, a distance of 750 feet. The estimated cost is as follows:

Pump

At present there is an electrically driven pump installed at the school, pumping from the concrete reservoir into the school's pressure tank. This pump is a Fairbanks-Morse self-oiling, speed 270 r.p.m., pressure 100 lb. per square inch, capacity 1,000 gal. per hour. The power of the motor is probably 1½ H.P. and is supplied at 110 volts, d.c.

It is proposed to move this pumping unit down to the well and install it there to pump direct into the school's pressure tank, using the present pressure switch in the engine room to control its operation. The cost of moving and connecting up is estimated at $50.00.

Bypass around concrete reservoir:

With the proposed pump at the well it will be necessary to bypass the concrete reservoir at the school and pump directly into the pressure tank in the engine room. Provision should be made, however, for filling this reservoir and using it as a standby supply in case of fire.

The pipe lines in this area are all buried and I have no information as to their exact location. However, a new line is needed from the 3" water line, before it enters the reservoir, to the pressure tank. The cost is estimated as follows:

To obtain immediate service from the new well, I would suggest that the present gasoline driven pump of 1,000 gals. per hour capacity be installed about 20 feet from the well in an excavation about 4 feet below the ground level. A two inch surface pipe line from the well to the school supply line at the old pump house, would supply water until the permanent installation could be made. This would leave sufficient space around the well to excavate for and build the pump chamber. It would also provide a service test on the well to determine its capacity.

Approximately 150 feet of 2 inch pipe are already at the school, being used in the surface line from the lake to the old pump house. An additional 100 feet of two inch pipe would be all that is necessary for this temporary installation; the cost of which is estimated as follows:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Department letter of the 30th ultimo, File No. 121-1-N T, in connection with the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

The Department will have received a telegram from Indian Agent R.S. Davis to the effect that the small Lister engine, which had been repaired by the Mumford Medland Company of Winnipeg, and returned promptly to the school to be available for the opening of school, was, in some manner, put out of working order almost immediately after being put in operation.

It may be found that only slight damage has been done to the engine and if the Department gave Mr. Davis authority, promptly, to engage an electrician, and he was able to find one, the small engine, and thereby the lighting system, may be put in working order again in a very short time.

There are several other matters at the school to which Mr. Davis is giving all of his attention. At the end of August the school engineer ceased work and the present principal, who has been informed that he is going to be replaced, does not appear to have much interest in the future of the school. This has added considerable difficulty to Mr. Davis' position in the matter.

The order has been placed for the necessary pipes for the pipe line and as soon as the pipes are received the necessary excavating will be done, if men are available, to install the pipe line. Harvest operations are under way and casual labour is very much in demand at higher rates, therefore it will not be easy to get the excavating done. We are not wishing to commence the excavating until the pipes are on hand so far that they can be laid as the excavating is done. The ground is generally loose and the walls of excavation will not hold up for any length of time without cribbing. They will fall immediately after being dug which is Mr. Davis' reason for wanting to lay the pipes as soon as the digging is completed. It is true there is a temporary arrangement for supplying water to the school but this can be operated only as long as it is not freezing. They are laid on the ground, consequently they will be put out of working order by freezing as soon as the weather turns cold. If the permanent water supply is not completed by that time there will be no way of getting water to the school.

It will be seen that it is practically impossible to operate the school until we can be certain that both the lighting plant and the water supply are permanently repaired and safe against the elements.

Mr. Davis has engaged 15 Indian women to clean the school and has arranged for the decorators to come in next week for repairing the plaster and doing the redecorating. The chimneys have been neglected and arrangements are being made to have them cleaned. The kitchen stoves were in very bad condition. They have been cleaned and are now in working order. Whether the school opens at once, or not, a school engineer should be appointed and put to work at once as there are many matters around the school needing his attention even before the school is open.

Further to our File No. 1216-312-11 AGE, dated July 25th, to date we have had no reply to the above letter and requisition for light batteries for the Gordon's School.

One Lister engine for this plant has been returned to the school and had only been running a very short time when smoke began issuing from the generator. Yesterday an electrician from Saskatoon was given authority to repair the generator at an approximate cost of $80.00 to $100.00.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have just received a report from the Provincial Department of Public Health, Regina, on the water from the new well recently dug at Gordon's Indian Residential School.

The report states that the mineral salt content of this water is excessively high and it cannot be recommended for drinking or domestic purposes.

This report comes as a surprise to me as the stream runs through gravel and has been feeding the lake where the school has been getting their water for years.

While there was always a lot of kicking about the water, when a sample was sent in for testing, the report always came back that it was O.K.

The only thing I can see is to get a punching machine and dig a deep well, as we have to do something. We have a valuable school there which should not be wasted.

Right now the school is using soft water for drinking and cooking purposes, but this supply will not last long.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM

November 7th, 1946

Re: WATER SUPPLY - GORDON'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL - SASKATCHEWAN

Referring to your memorandum of September 13th, we have now received a report from Mr. Martin dated October 18th, duplicate copies of which are attached herewith, as well as of the plans accompanying same.

It appears that Mr. Martin found a spare motor at the school and used it in place of the gas engine to run the pump at the well. This motor is operated manually from the boiler room. The gas engine was not in good repair, and by using electric power for the pump, ventilation difficulties were surmounted.

Mr. Martin suggests that a permanent concrete well be installed after the water delivery from the present well has been proved during twelve months' use. We presume he means that the well should be enlarged and lined with concrete so that one full day's supply could be stored in it.

Memorandum:

To - C. M. Walker, Esq.,
Supervising Engineer.

Gordon Indian School Water Supply.

I arrived at the Gordon School on September 24th and met Mr. Davis, Indian Agent. Mr. Davis had been getting a temporary water supply for the school by placing a centrifugal pump eleven feet down in the new well. The well was driven by belt drive from a gas engine on the surface. The water was being pumped overland to the 3" pipeline near the old pump-house. The excavation for this pipeline had just been completed and a supply of 2" pipe was on hand. I completed the laying of this 230 feet of 2" galvanized iron pipe into the well.

On investigation I found that:

(1) The water in the lake is unfit for use on account of stagnation.

(2) The water supplying the new well comes from the opposite direction to the lake and is the water supplying the lake. The water runs into the well 13 feet from the surface near the bottom of the gravel seam. The flow into the well is 300 gallons per hour. The well should be pumped for a year before supply is proved.

(3) The 3" suction line from the reservoir to the boiler-room in the school was so badly corroded it had to be abandoned. Mr. Davis had set up the pump with a gas engine on account of the power being off and laid a suction line overland to the reservoir. The pump itself was in bad repair.

(4) The reservoir at the school is 15' x 15' by 10 feet high. The intake and outlet are 6 feet from the floor. Dead mice and bugs were found in the reservoir.

(5) The old concrete well near the lake which had been in use, was full of lizards.

(6) The gas engine running the centrifugal pump at the well was worn out and it was not practical to run the pump so far from the engine.

(7) It was not possible to buy pumps in Regina or Saskatoon.

(8) The 3" pipeline from the old pump house to the reservoir is badly corroded but can serve for the time being.

(9) The system of pumping from the well to the reservoir and from the reservoir to the pressure tanks is a good one.

On account .............
On account of the scarcity of pumps I had the existing ones rebuilt. The 2" suction 1/2" discharge centrifugal pump at the well was mounted on a base with a 3 H.P. Motor which was at the school and placed 1/2 feet above water level in the well. New lining was put in the cylinders of the pump at the school and it was mounted on a base with the motor which had previously driven it. A power line was constructed to the well. The pump at the well is operated by closing the switch manually in the Power room at the school. The pump in the school works with a pressure control switch with relay. The pumps were rebuilt by H. Lambert Electric Company, Saskatoon.

The wiring work on the pole line and the inside wiring in conduit in the boiler-room was done by S.H. Brown electrician of Punnichy. The power line from the well to the school is approximately 800 feet long. It was necessary to use poplar poles. The poles were peeled and creosoted on the butts. No.2 wire was used as No.4 was not obtainable.

The well was roofed over 6 feet above the pump and again at the surface. Trap doors were installed and a 3 inch vent pipe installed from the pump chamber to the surface. The two coverings over the pump chambers are insulated against freezing. A building 8' x 9' was moved from the Agency to the well. It will serve to keep snow off the entrance and prevent the installation being tampered with. It is not necessary to heat the building, an electric light was placed in the pump chamber.

A new 2" suction line was laid from the reservoir to the pump in the school.

A relief valve was placed on the present tanks in the boiler room.

There is a gas compressor to build up the air pressure for the storage tanks.

When the pump in the well was started after being idle two days it pumped 2000 gallons in two hours. I suspect water had backed up around the well. Later the water was lowered six feet in pumping forty-five minutes. This equals the first performance of seventeen gallons per minute. The well should not be pumped for more than forty-five minutes at a time, and the water allowed to come back for two hours. Mr. Davis is posting a time table for pumping which allows for thirty minutes pumping in any two hours. In this way the requirements of the school will be met.

When the supply of water in the well has been proved after a year's pumping, which I think it will, I suggest a permanent concrete well be installed holding at least a day's supply of water. Water would then be pumped once a day and could also be available for the stables and as a reserve in case of fire.

The pipe line from the well to the reservoir will have to be renewed before long and this work should be done at the same time the permanent well is constructed.

Domestic Hot Water

There is a 350 gallon hot water tank in the boiler room connected to the steam heating boiler. It is also connected to a hot water heater. A small vertical type boiler supplies steam to the laundry.

Heating ..................
Heating

The school is heated by a horizontal Tube E Leonard and Sons steam boiler. The boiler leaks around the base. Mr. Davis is endeavouring to get a portable electric welding outfit to fix it. He is also having the hard water in the boiler replaced by soft water. The pipes throughout the school are badly corroded. The boiler has been kept too full and water driven into the pipes and radiators; the water hammer causing leaks in the corroded pipes. This plant has been run by inexperienced help. No maintenance work has been kept up on it.

It is important that an experienced man be put in the boiler room immediately to run the boiler pumps and lighting plant. He would have months of work ahead of him cleaning valves, stopping leaks, etc.

Lighting Plant.

When I arrived at the school there was no electric power. Both gas plants had been sent to Winnipeg for repairs. The batteries were run down. Before I left the small plant a Lister V.110, A.35 R.P.M. 600 generator had been repaired and installed by H. Lambert Electric Company. New batteries were purchased. Mr. Lambert installed a relay to prevent the batteries burning out the generator.

To me the plant is antiquated. I suggest that two Diesel plants be installed and the batteries done away with as soon as these plants can be purchased, alternating current generators, of course, being used.

The direct current motors run from the plant are the two 2 H.P. Motors on the water pumps and a 1 H.P. on the bread mixer.

Mr. Davis had considerable cleaning up and painting done at the school this fall.

Now that the power and light are on at the school most of their difficulties can be solved by a good man in the boiler room.

I am enclosing a plan of the building area and a detail plan showing boiler and engine room layout. I am also attaching a breakdown of the cost of the work done by this Service.

R. M. Martin,
Senior Assistant Engineer.

Mr. and Mrs. Fawke were sent to the school from Edmonton by the Indian and Eskimo Commission. Mr. Fawke was to be a manual training instructor and Mrs. Fawke a class-room teacher. Mr. Fawke is entirely unfit for this work according to his own statement; he has had very little experience in manual training instruction and seems to know little other than leather work. Leather work might be considered as one phase of manual training instruction but there are many things which should be taught other than leather work, and a suitable manual training instructor could, in the course of his instruction, assist the engineer to some extent to look after minor repairs. Mr. Fawke is almost a total cripple, and has to get around with crutches. He told me he has done no work since 1926 when he was stricken with Encephalomyelitis. I cannot see how he will ever be active enough to be a useful member of a residential school staff, and I so informed him. He now states that he intends to leave and his wife has already submitted her resignation as class-room teacher.

Mrs. Mayo has been teaching one of the classrooms but she intends to leave at the end of this month when her husband leaves. The result of this will be that there will be only one class-room teacher, Miss MacDonald, and there are about 100 children in the school. I believe that Miss MacDonald will prove a satisfactory teacher but she certainly cannot teach three class-rooms.

The only sewing instruction which the girls are receiving is the usual mending of old worn-out clothing. I informed the Principal that he should secure some material with which the girls should be taught to make garments and other useful things which would give them some interest in sewing. An Indian girl will never become very interested in sewing if the only sewing she ever does is the sewing of one patch on top of another. This is the only kind of sewing I have ever seen at the Gordon's School.

The Farming Instructor has very little initiative and it is necessary for Mr. Ferguson to instruct him in his work from day to day. He should be replaced by a man with a thorough knowledge of grain growing, gardening, and the care of livestock and machinery. Without a man of this kind there is little hope that the Indian boys will leave the school with a knowledge which will fit them for farming and livestock raising on their reserve.

I found the building much cleaner and more tidy than I have ever found it before. Most of the interior decoration has been completed and the interior of the building is no longer a disgrace to the Department.

Notwithstanding the fact that I have twice ordered the removal of locks from the fire escape doors I again found two of them locked, and a third door with a lock on it, but this one was not locked. Apparently it is locked at times, otherwise the padlock would not be there. I informed Mr. Ferguson that this cannot be permitted.

Two of the dormitories have not direct access to a fire escape and it would be necessary for the children from those two dormitories to cross a hall and enter another dormitory in order to get to a fire escape. This is not desirable for two reasons. First that the halls of the building, in case of a fire, will be the most dangerous part of the building, and will probably be full of smoke and fumes. Second that having to cross the hall and enter another dormitory to a fire escape is almost sure to result in confusion in case of a fire. I have not previously criticised this when reporting on the Gordon's School as there have been so many other things to criticise and the building is reasonably safe from fire. However, I believe that a separate fire escape should be installed in order that the children from the two dormitories in question could get directly to the fresh air at the outside of the building without having to pass through a hall. Indian Agent Davis is going to submit a requisition for a fire escape which will service both of these dormitories and I would recommend that it be authorized when the requisition is received.

There is considerable improve...
There is considerable improvement in the variety and quantity of food being supplied to the children. There is no improvement in the fresh milk situation as they have been unable to buy good rich cream. However, the children do have some milk which is saved by the use of powdered milk. There are no vegetables other than potatoes as the garden was almost a complete failure due to miscellaneous. It is hoped that a supply of vegetables will be obtained from the Saskatchewan Penitentiary at Prince Albert. If this is not possible the school will certainly have to buy a quantity of vegetables.

Ottawa, November 23, 1946.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Electrical Plant at Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Sask.

There are two D.C. gasoline engines normally supplying electricity for the above school. Both these engines are Listers, manufactured in the United Kingdom. Naturally the supply of replacement parts during the last seven years has been almost nil. As a result, both these machines failed this summer and they were shipped to Humford-Medland's in Winnipeg for repair.

The smaller machine has been repaired and returned to the school and is now carrying the load. It is a 3½ K.W. engine trying to replace the larger 7½ K.W. engine and of course operating at high speeds, for 16 hours a day, is in need of constant attention. Inspector Ostrander reports: "It may break down at any moment. If this happens before another engine is secured the school may have to be closed".

Upon receipt of the above information by long distance phone from Indian Agent Davis and by the above mentioned letter from Inspector Ostrander, we tried the following sources of supply:

(a) Har Assets Corporation - To our wire the answer received was: "Regret no Diesel or gasoline engines anywhere near the required horse power available".

(b) Humford-Medland - To our wire they replied that it would be four or five months before they could replace the unit. In six weeks they could provide a re-assembled unit.

...... They suggested
They suggested shipping the present plant and then when new parts were received from England they could ship to the school for installation. If there were a capable engineer at the school, we would not hesitate to do this. As it is, however, we feel that this temporary installation would be but a constant source of grief - just as the engine was before being shipped to Winnipeg.

Therefore we recommend the purchase of a new engine. With this in mind we contacted Fairbanks-Morse, who informed us they were unable to provide immediate delivery on anything but a 4½ K.W. engine. We finally located an engine through Mainguy's, Limited, in Montreal. They can give immediate delivery on a Witte Diesel from Kansas City. The Surveys and Engineering officials approve this type of machine. A similar plant is already in use at the Moose Factory Residential School and is giving entire satisfaction.

It is therefore recommended, in view of this emergency, that an order for the engine as detailed herewith be placed with Mainguy's, Limited, of Montreal.

to the school with tanks and trucks, and put in the cistern.

I explained to Mr. Ducet that we would have to get an electric
pump to take this water out of the cistern and pipe it into the
kitchen, as at present there is only an old hand pump that some-
times works and sometimes doesn't, so they have to take the lid
from the top of the cistern and bail it out, which is most un-
sanitary.

Mr. Ducet knows just what we want and is taking the matter up in
Winnipeg regarding price etc., and promised to do what he could to
see that you placed the order. I also talked over with him the
matter of getting a chlorinator at once, one which was large
enough to chlorinate about 5000 gallons per day. These two things
are urgently needed, and the sooner you can get them here, the
better.

The D.C. plant is still going but has to be run so long the engine
is worked to death trying to keep the thing going and no doubt you
you will have this matter straightened up shortly. It will cost
in the neighbourhood of $300.00 to switch over from D.C. to A.C.
We only have four motors to change and there would be the two
motors we would get, one with the chlorinator and one with the
cistern pump.

The D.C. motors are worth more than the A.C. motors and I believe
that I can take the D.C. motors to Saskatoon and trade them for
A.C. with very little extra cost. Of course the price of $300.00
will not include the cost of installing the new lighting plant,
as I am unable to give you a price on this.

There will be considerable equipment needed at this school, such
as digging a well, boiler etc., which will have to be installed
next summer. The whole plumbing system in the school will have
to be overhauled, and most of it replaced. My difficulty is that when forwarding my request to you, to get the cost of these replacements, etc. Would it be satisfactory to you if I send you a list of what is needed and you get the prices and the costs, from some of the technical men in the engineering branch, so as to take the whole matter up before the Minister.

Please wire me if this will be satisfactory and I will go over the whole thing with Mr. Martin before he leaves here, and send you a report by airmail.

REPORT ON
A SANITARY SURVEY OF THE WATER SUPPLY
AT GORDON'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
PUNNICHY, SASKATCHEWAN.

Examined - December 1 - 2, 1946.

Examined and Reported by:
N.J. Goode,
Senior Sanitary Engineer,
Public Health Engineering Division.
REPORT ON A SANITARY SURVEY OF THE WATER SUPPLY AT
GORDON'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL AT PUNNICHY, SASKATCHEWAN

Examined - December 1-2, 1946.

Gordon's Indian Residential School is situated seven miles south of the railway station at Punnichy, Saskatchewan. At the time of the examination there were approximately 120 persons, including 100 pupils and 20 staff members, residing at the school.

Principal - Mr. Mayo.
Acting Principal - Rev. Ferguson.
Indian Agent - Mr. R.S. Davis.

The present water supply includes two systems. The main source of supply is obtained from a well, and a lake. The secondary source of supply is obtained from snow, and rain water falling on the roof of the building.

The Main Water Supply

The well, which was constructed in 1946, was originally intended to supply the normal demands of the school. It is 700 feet from the school and 100 feet inshore from the lake. The well shaft is 4 feet square and approximately 30 feet deep. Water is drawn from the well by a 2" dia. intake pipe, fitted with a coarse screen and foot valve, attached to an electrically-driven pump (Fairbanks-Morse Motor, Type D, Serial No. X55298; 2 HP, D.C. 115v, 16.8a, 1,750 RPM, attached to a centrifugal pump with an 8" dia. impeller). On leaving the pump, the water is forced through a 2" dia. discharge pipe to a 10,000 gallon cistern adjacent to the school building.
Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

The lake could be termed a pond as the water surface is only 100,000 square yards in extent, and the drainage area is less than \( \frac{1}{2} \) square mile. An intake, through the ice on the lake surface, was recently constructed to supplement the limited volume of water obtainable from the well. This intake was placed in a temporary housing 100 feet from the lake shore. Water, from this emergency source of supply, is drawn through a 1\(\frac{3}{4}\)" dia. intake pipe to a gasoline-driven pump (London, self-priming centrifugal pump; Serial No. 465636, Model LW; Manufactured by Lawson Co., New Holstein, Wisconsin). This pump forces the water through a 1\(\frac{3}{4}\)" dia. discharge pipe, supported on blocks above ground, to the 2" dia. pipe leading from the well to the cistern. By a suitable valving arrangement, water can be pumped to the school from either the lake or the well.

The equipment, installed in the school building for the distribution of the water, includes a pump and motor, two pressure tanks, a pressure filter, and appurtenances. The motor, attached to the pump, is equipped with an automatic start-stop arrangement adjusted to maintain the water pressure between 25 and 45 pounds per square inch. Water is drawn from the cistern by an electrically-driven pump (Fairbanks-Morse Pump rated at 1,000 gallons per hour, 270 RPM is driven by Fairbanks-Morse Motor, Serial No. X52154, Type DH, 8 HP, 1,750 RPM; D.C. 115v, 16.3a) which forces it through the pressure tanks to the outlets in the building.

The Secondary Water Supply

The secondary source of supply is
Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

obtained by collecting melted snow, and rain water, from the roof of the school. This water is stored in a second 10,000 gallon concrete cistern beside the building. The sole outlet to this cistern is a handpump located in the basement of the school. This supply is necessarily limited and, consequently, is used only for laundry and cooking purposes.

Water Treatment

There has been no systematic treatment of the water during the present school term. The pressure filter, installed in the basement, (Water Softener and Filtration Plant, supplied by the International Filter Co.) has been disconnected and out of use for a number of years. However, following the receipt of unfavourable bacteriological analyses from the Saskatchewan Department of Public Health, there have been attempts to chlorinate water from the main supply. As far as can be ascertained, these attempts were haphazard as the required procedure was not known.

The Sewerage System

Sewage is discharged into a septic tank 100 feet from the school building. The effluent from this tank runs into a slough 400 feet from the school. This slough is in the opposite direction from the lake, and separated from it by the high ground on which the school stands.

CONCLUSION

There are numerous potential, and actual sources of pollution in this system.

The drainage area of the lake is unrestricted. This area includes part of the school grounds, farm land, and wooded country. Consequently, there are a number of persons in close proximity to the lake who could contaminate it.

The lake is used for watering cattle. Two watering holes in the ice were noted during the examination. It was evident that these had been cut for cattle as their droppings were noticed nearby. One of these holes was within 150 feet of the emergency intake. Such an arrangement is an obvious source of pollution.

The emergency intake pipe, from the lake, is supported on blocks above ground. After pumping, it is necessary to disconnect and drain this pipe to prevent it from freezing. While this pipe is being connected and disconnected, and during the time it is left open to drain, there is ample opportunity for the pipe to become contaminated.

The well shaft is not water-tight as it is made of wood. Thus it is possible for contaminated surface water to enter the well shaft.
Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

Originally the pump, installed in the well shaft, was supported by a wooden floor. However, during repairs, this floor was removed and the pump was supported by two planks. Since that time this flooring has not been replaced. Thus there is a danger of polluting substances falling from the pump level to the water surface. This is an ever present danger as the operator descends the shaft several times a day to start and stop the pump.

The entrance to the main water supply cistern is above ground. This entrance was originally well protected by a fitted, dome-shaped, cast iron lid. However, a hole has been cut in this lid. This hole was made to allow a wooden pole, adapted as a float gauge, to fluctuate freely. It serves this purpose, but it also allows contaminating substances to enter the cistern.

An open pipe line connects an upper level of the cistern to a sump in the basement of the school. This pipe line allows water to enter the sump when the water level of the cistern is above the level of the sump. If, subsequently, water is drawn from the cistern before water in the sump is pumped to waste, there is a danger of contamination entering the cistern in the backflow from the sump.

The results of the bacteriological analyses, of samples taken from this water supply system, show a marked degree of contamination. It is evident from these results that the water, in its raw state, is not safe for human consumption. It should also be noted that the mineral salt content, although not dangerous, is objectionably high.
Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

The slough, created by the septic tank effluent, is separated from the lake by the high ground on which the school stands. Consequently, it is extremely improbable that the septic tank effluent could contaminate the main water supply. This effluent, however, creates a nuisance and a health hazard, as it gives off an unpleasant odour and forms a breeding place for flies.

RECOMMENDATIONS

It will be recognised by the foregoing paragraphs, that the sanitary conditions throughout the water supply system at Gordon's Indian Residential School are extremely unsatisfactory. In order to eliminate some of the worst aspects of the present installation it is recommended that the following steps be taken.

1. It is impractical to enforce restrictions to the drainage area of the lake, as it includes part of the school grounds and a farm. However, persons frequenting the immediate vicinity of the lake should be warned against fouling the water.

2. Cattle should not be watered directly from the lake, especially, not from the immediate vicinity of the intake.

3. Great care should be exercised in handling the emergency pipe line when it is being connected and disconnected. To eliminate the possibility of contamination, and to provide a more practical means of draining the pipe, a drainage valve should be installed adjacent to the pump.

4. The flooring beneath the pump, in the well shaft, should be replaced.

5. The hole in the cover of the main water supply cistern should be sealed. This would
Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

necessitate the installation of a different type of depth gauge.

6. The pipe line connecting the cistern to the sump, should be permanently sealed.

7. Both water supplies should be chlorinated. This is the most urgent, immediate recommendation.

8. A supply of orthotolidin, and a comparator should be supplied to ensure that an adequate chlorine residual is present.

9. An automatic hypochlorinator should be installed in the main water supply system. The ideal location for this equipment would be on the pipe line leading to the cistern from the well. A sufficient contact period would be assured with such an arrangement.

At the time of the examination it was recognised that chlorination of these supplies was necessary. Therefore typewritten instructions, detailing manual emergency chlorination procedure, were prepared and left with officials of the school. If carried out, these instructions will provide a dosage of 3 ppm available chlorine for the main water supply, and 2 ppm for the secondary supply.

10. Water from the main supply source should not be used for drinking, as it is not very palatable, and as it has a large mineral salt content which is the probable source of a laxative effect. To utilize the secondary supply for drinking, it will be necessary to provide a suitable means of distribution as, at present, there is only one inefficient outlet.

A suggested means of effecting this distribution, is to provide six 5-gallon water bottles, similar to those used in office buildings, to dispense the drinking water.
Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

These water bottles would be placed in readily accessible positions about the school building after being filled with chlorinated water from the secondary supply.

It is to be emphasised that the foregoing recommendations are suggested as a means of improving the worst features of a very unsatisfactory supply. These recommendations are not intended to produce a wholesome safe supply, but are emergency measures to improve the quality of the water until a more satisfactory source is obtained.

The following two recommendations are believed to be both necessary and practical. They will effect a more permanent solution to the water supply problems encountered at the Indian School.

11. A deep well should be drilled, as it has been proven that shallow wells in this vicinity do not maintain a sufficient yield to satisfy the water demand of the school. In support of this statement, there is considerable correspondence, on file in the Indian Agent's Office, dealing with trouble encountered with shallow well supplies in recent years. It is admitted that there is no guarantee of a deep well furnishing an adequate water supply. However, in view of the foregoing facts and the present situation, it should prove to be more practical and economical than continued reliance on inadequate surface, or shallow well supplies.

If a deep well is to be drilled, the present manual chlorination could be continued until it is in service. Subsequent tests on the deep well water may show that it doesn't require chlorination. Thus, it may be possible to save the expense of a hypochlorinator.
Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

12. An experienced, practical man should be placed in charge of the electrical and mechanical equipment of the school. Besides the heating units, this equipment includes two electrically-driven pumps, one gasoline-driven pump, and a gasoline-driven electric generator, which operate the water supply system. Lately, the men placed in charge of this machinery have had only a rudimentary knowledge of its operation and maintenance. Such men, although not necessarily negligent, cannot be expected to maintain machinery at operating efficiency. Because of their lack of training, minor defects go unattended until they result in a major breakdown, with a consequent partial or total failure of the water supply. Therefore, it is felt that a competent maintenance man is the best insurance against recurrent failures of machinery, and disruption of the water supply system.

N.J. Goode,
Sr. Sanitary Engineer.

SUPPLEMENT TO REPORT ON A SANITARY SURVEY OF THE
WATER SUPPLY AT GORDON'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
AT PUNNICHY, SASKATCHEWAN.

Examined December 1 - 2, 1946.

The report on the water supply of Gordon's Indian Residential School was originally submitted before the results of the chemical analysis of the water were known. This was possible as it was realized that data obtained from such an analysis could not appreciably change the opinion on such an obviously unsatisfactory supply. If such a course had not been taken the report would have been delayed for a month as chemical analyses are often time-consuming, especially when the laboratory has limited space available, as is the case of the laboratory in Regina. Thus, by forwarding the report before the analysis was completed, it was possible for remedial action to be instituted at an earlier date.

As was anticipated, the results of the chemical analysis bear out the original observation that water from the present supply sources is not fit for human consumption. There are excess amounts of the following items in the water:

Magnesium .................................. 311.3 p.p.m.
- should not exceed 125 p.p.m.#

Sulphate .................................... 1166.8 p.p.m.
- should not exceed 250 p.p.m.#

Total dissolved solids ..................... 3002 p.p.m.
- should not exceed 1000 p.p.m.#

This partial chemical analysis emphasizes the inferior quality of the water.
Indian School, Punnichy, Sask.

It is possible to improve the bacteriological quality by chlorination, but to improve the chemical quality satisfactorily it would be necessary to install a complete water treatment plant. This expedient is out of the question as it has already been foreseen that the present sources of supply are not adequate for the needs of the school. Therefore the only reasonable conclusion obtained from the foregoing data supports the recommendation in the report that another source of supply should be obtained by drilling a deep well.

M. J. Goode,
Sr. Sanitary Engineer,
Public Health Engineering Div.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, SURVEYS AND ENGINEERING BRANCH

Water Supply, Gordon's Indian Residential School,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

In view of the increased pupilage at the above school, and the present inadequacy of a drinking water supply it has been decided to proceed with the digging of a drilled well.

Therefore, would you now arrange to call for tenders for the digging of this well and arrange to let a contract for this operation. It is understood that Colonel Henry, the Superintendent of Welfare and Training, has discussed this matter at some length with Mr. Shaw and that the digging of this well may eventually cost as much as $4,000.00.

Director.
February 7th, 1947.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

Water Supply - Gordon's Indian Residential School.

I have had a long discussion with Mr. Shaw of the Surveys and Engineering Branch and with Mr. Ostrander concerning the water supply at this school.

The present temporary draw of water from the slough provides sufficient for flushing the toilets and for washing purposes. It is not sufficient, however, for drinking purposes and we have been forced to purchase a car-load of ice.

Therefore, it would seem that we have no alternative other than to proceed at once with the drilling of a deep well.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum

Re: Water Supply - Gordon's Indian Residential School - Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

Referring to your memorandum of December 10th on the subject of water supply at the above school, we have received a further report from Mr. Martin dated January 31st, copies of which are attached herewith in duplicate.

Replying in detail to questions (a) and (b) of your memorandum of December 10th, we would advise as follows:

(a) There appears to be nothing more to be done to ensure a safe temporary source of water supply. The Sanitary Engineer, Mr. Goode, left instructions at the school re temporary water treatment and the Director of Indian Affairs advises under date of January 10th that a chlorinator is being provided so that the water will be purified from bacteriological pollution. However, the mineral content of the well and lake water is too high and Mr. Goode recommends that it be not used for drinking and seems to suggest that the soft water supply from the roof could be used for drinking. We understand that ice has been hauled in during the winter for a drinking supply.

(b) In the present school location the only proposal remaining to be tried is that of drilling a deep well, although there can be no guarantee of a satisfactory supply from this source. Water might not easily be found and if found, might be of poor quality.

Mr. Martin, on November 25th, reported the rates for drilling. From these figures two wells could each be drilled to 200 feet depth and cased with 5-5/8" pipe for a cost of about $8,000.00 or one well could be drilled and cased to a depth of about 400 feet for the same amount. The cost of pumping equipment and housing might approximate $1,000.00 for one well so that $4,000.00 should be made available.

The following is an extract from a report of the Geological Survey on "Ground-Water Resources of the Rural Municipality of Touchwood" contained in Water Supply Paper No. 99:

"Water would doubtless be encountered in places in the bedrock if wells were drilled into it, but, because of the expense involved and the uncertainty of obtaining water that is not highly mineralized, deep drilling in this municipality is not warranted."

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

Enc.
However in spite of this report, the Indian Agent at Punnichy has apparently secured good water at a depth of 180 feet.

We shall be pleased to be advised if any further action is necessary by this Service in regard to the drilling of a deep well.

Chief Engineer.
Bunff, Alberta,
January 31st, 1947.

MEMORANDUM:

To - C. M. Walker, Esq.,
District Engineer.

Re: Water Supply, Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Sask.

In regard to this water supply I beg to draw your attention to different recommendations that I have made in memoranda to you and in letters to Mr. T.S. Mills, while I was at Punnichy.

In my memorandum of October 15th I pointed out that the supply of water in the new well should be tested out over a period of time before going to the expense of installing permanent well cribbing, pump-house and pipeline repairs. In November the supply decreased to 110 gals. per hour, due to a drop of one foot in the water level. I augmented this water supply by fitting a temporary line to the lake, and recommended:

(1) That a hypo-chlorinator be placed immediately in the boiler room on the discharge side of the pump. There are two 1000 gal pressure tanks on the discharge line. In my opinion the hypo-chlorinator would be required, regardless of source of water supply.

(2) That the building area be drilled for a water supply.

In my letter of November 29th to Mr. Mills I estimated the cost of the above undertakings to be $3,000. to $6,000, according to results from drilling. If the results from drilling are not satisfactory I believe it possible to excavate a reservoir at the present new well which would supply sufficient water. If a hypochlorinator were installed at the present time it would be determined whether the water would be fit for use or not.

I see no great difference between Mr. Goode's recommendation and my own as far as a permanent solution goes, which is that the area be drilled for water.

Mr. Davis, Indian Agent, told me he could have ice hauled for drinking purposes during the winter. The cistern referred to in Mr. Goode's report holds the drainage water from the roof of the school.

In my memorandum of October 15th I advised having a skilled man in the boiler-room to take care of boilers, generators, and pumps. I believe that this has not been done.

With regard to water analysis, Mr. Davis sent two samples to the University of Saskatchewan. He was to send a copy to this office with the original to Ottawa. The tests made by the Department of Health showed more contamination in the well than in the lake. This was no doubt due to the well being open below the ladder.

In my opinion the first move to make in this matter is to drill for water. Clark Drilling Co., at Estrous and the International Water Supply Company, Regina, are drillers in this area.

[Signature]

Senior Assistant Engineer.

Re: Water Supply - Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Sask.

Since receipt of your memorandum of February 7th last this matter has been receiving active consideration.

We have been in communication with the International Water Supply Limited, London, Ontario, who are affiliated with Layne and Bowler Incorporated, Memphis, Tennessee, and who have had very extensive experience in the installation of what is known as the Layne Gravel Wall type of well. We are of opinion that this type of well is more likely to provide an adequate water supply than can be secured by simple well drilling and casing.

With the installation of a Layne Gravel Wall type of well the International Water Supply Company would guarantee the development of a definite quantity of water for a set sum of money but this guarantee would be based on the results of preliminary test borings.

The International Water Supply Company recommends that a small test boring be sunk first to determine if any water-bearing formations exist at the school. Proper pumping tests at small capacity would determine the amount of water the formation would safely yield to a permanent well and samples of the water would determine if it were of potable quality. In drilling this preliminary test exploration boring they would use a small powered hydraulic rotary machine which drills a hole approximately 4" in diameter. No casing is required unless a potential water-bearing formation is encountered. In this case, the hole is cased with 2" diameter pipe and screen and a pumping test conducted to determine the specific capacity of the...
of the formation. It may be necessary to drill a companion gauge hole, similarly cased and screened in which to measure the drawdown and recovery, or if hole is not too deep, a pipe of small diameter can be set alongside the 2" pipe and measurements taken in it.

The International Water Supply Limited state that they can go to a depth of 400 feet with this equipment. They further state that the bed-rock marine shale series would be encountered above 600 feet in this area. Once the top of this shale series is reached it is useless to drill deeper in search of water since if any is encountered it would be too highly mineralized for use.

The International Water Supply Limited estimates the total cost of a 400 ft. test hole would be as follows:

Drilling 400' @ $2.00 per ft. ......................... $800.00
Setting casing, screen and test pump ............... 75.00
Develop and pump test well .......................... 150.00
Removal of casing & screen ........................... 50.00
Transportation ........................................ 150.00

$1,225.00

Additional test pumping if more than one water-bearing formation checked .................... 375.00

After the results of the preliminary test boring are known the International Water Supply Limited would submit an estimate of the cost of a permanent gravel wall well.

It is recommended that we be authorized to engage the International Water Supply Limited to undertake one or more test borings as required on the terms outlined above and if sufficient water is available and quality suitable to have them quote on a Layne Gravel Wall well equipped with a Layne Deep Well Turbine pump.

Will you kindly advise of your wishes in this matter.

Director.

In order to correct the services inspected, major operations will be necessary along the following lines:

1. Provide 2 new low pressure steam steel heating boilers, portable type with necessary protective devices to regulate water levels.
2. Remove all steam and returns in basement and replace same with new material.
3. Disconnect every radiator and if after a careful inspection any undue signs of sludge or scale are present replace.
4. Remove all traps from mains and replace with proper type.
5. Remove all traps from radiators and replace with new ones.
6. Remove all boiler room piping.
7. Remove and replace all Domestic hot water equipment including all piping.

Funds for the above purpose were not specifically provided in the main appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48, but I hope that the Minister will approve the expenditure and I intend to include the amount of $35,000. for the purpose in the supplementary estimates for the current fiscal year. In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of April 28th, 1947, bearing your notation of May 3rd with reference to the above, we comment as follows:

There is no doubt in our minds that the work outlined in our memorandum of April 10th, 1947 should be carried out this summer, but only on the condition that a reliable source of water is provided. The boiler could fail at any time, and if it were decided to risk operating this unit another winter, there is no standby boiler to take over, and there is no room to install one.

The International Water Supply Ltd., has been engaged to drill test holes and the work is to be undertaken as soon as possible. Failure to discover a satisfactory source of water coupled with a decision to attempt to carry on with the present heating equipment, could only result in the automatic closing of the School. This was the thought brought to the attention of the School Authorities by our Mr. Hargreaves on his recent visit.

Not only is the boiler in a precarious state, but most of the piping and radiation is badly plugged with scale, sludge and other foreign matter, and we feel that nothing but trouble would result from an attempt to continue operations under these adverse circumstances.

It is again pointed out that the work involved in connection with the heating system would take 3 to 4 months to carry out, under favourable circumstances, and if the School is to be opened usual in September, this fact should not be lost sight of.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Gordon's (Anglican) Indian Residential School.
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

In accordance with a request received from Indian Affairs Branch, an officer from this Service visited the above and carried out an extensive inspection of the heating, plumbing and domestic water services.

The results of these investigations are summarized below with recommendations and approximate costs to carry out the necessary revisions.

The heating system is served by one low pressure steam steel portable type heating boiler. This boiler leaks in numerous places and though attempts have been made to weld the cracks, it has not been possible to make a satisfactory job, and the leaks are becoming progressively worse. Regular blow-downs to remove scale and dirt cannot be carried out as the boiler is burnt thin in many places and is in danger of a complete collapse.

The piping system in the Basement is badly corroded and is full of scale, dirt and sludge. As a consequence, its area has been reduced so much that even when a pressure of 10 pounds per square inch is raised, the steam does not reach the ends of the mains and branches.

Many radiators have been cracked and repairs have been attempted. Such repairs have not proved to be satisfactory. Radiators which have been removed were examined and found to be full of scale, dirt and sludge, and they cannot be cleaned. It naturally follows that most of the traps will be in such condition as to make them useless.

The domestic hot and cold water system was not too well designed originally. The storage tank and heating coil are too small and the heater is nearly burnt out. The piping in this system is also scaled and corroded, and the flow of water is retarded to such an extent as to make the system almost totally inadequate to serve the fixtures.

Excessively hard water has been a major cause in these failures. Equally, the utter lack of even semi-skilled operating staff has contributed much to the failures. There is no evidence to show that even the most elementary maintenance had been carried out. The staff turnover has been frequent and it has been hard for the School Authorities to attract men with the minimum qualifications to take on this important post.

Many other points were noted, and sufficient technical data was gathered to enable this Service to prepare plans and specifications to cover the necessary revisions.
The Indian Agent reported that the Dominion and Provincial Analysts had condemned the water as being unfit for human consumption.

In order to correct the services inspected, major operations will be necessary along the following lines:

1. Provide 2 new low pressure steam steel heating boilers, portable type with necessary protective devices to regulate water levels.
2. Remove all steam and returns in Basement and replace same with new material.
3. Disconnect every radiator and if after a careful inspection any undue signs of sludge or scale are present replace same.
4. Remove all traps from mains and replace with proper type.
5. Remove all traps from radiators and replace with new ones.
6. Remove all boiler room piping.
7. Remove and replace all Domestic hot water equipment including all piping.

All the above work should be executed in accordance with plans and specifications prepared by this Service, and before same is undertaken, a sample of water should be submitted for analysis to enable us to determine the type and capacity of water softening equipment.

The above work has been roughly estimated to cost in the neighborhood of $21,500.00.

If any attempt were made to use questionable items of existing equipment in an effort to reduce the cost, the new work would be affected immediately and the initial saving from such action would soon be lost.

We concur with our Heating Engineer that all the above operations should be carried out at one time.

(Signed) T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School, Touchwood Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan.

Attached is a copy of a report from the Surveys and Engineering Branch with reference to extensive repairs required at the above mentioned school.

This morning the Superintendent of Welfare and Training had an interview with Dr. Alderwood, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., Mr. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan, and Mr. Hargreaves of the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

During the course of the discussion, Mr. Hargreaves pointed out the absolute necessity for making the changes suggested in the attached report at an approximate cost of $21,500.

In addition to the expenditure mentioned, Mr. Hargreaves and Inspector Ostrander agreed that it would be advisable to put eaves trough on the school and build a special tank to hold soft water which would only be used in operating the heating system.

In addition, it was also agreed that it would be advisable to install two boilers instead of one. With these additional improvements, the total expenditure will probably reach $35,000.
The situation is a very serious one, and in order to have this school in proper condition to reopen in the Fall, it is absolutely essential that the improvements mentioned above be carried out during the next four months.

Funds for the above purpose were not specifically provided in the main appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48, but I hope that the Minister will approve the expenditure and I intend to include the amount of $35,000. for the purpose in the supplementary estimates for the current fiscal year. Gordon's is a Government-owned school.

PP/MGD

Director.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 16th instant, file 913-312-11 ACE, and enquiring concerning the possibilities of obtaining heating boilers on transfer, will you please advise the size of boilers you had in mind.

For your information, we have periodically declared surplus heating units, including boilers, in both hangars and link trainer buildings. The boilers are usually of the same sizes in all hangars and the same applies with respect to link trainer buildings. Therefore, you might be able to ascertain whether or not these two sizes would be suitable for your purposes, and we, in turn, could advise you prior to our recommendation they be declared surplus to our requirements.

Yours truly,

Sgd. E. Hickson)
District Inspector, Central Airways.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

If the boiler has not yet been purchased for the Gordon's Indian Residential School I would suggest writing to Mr. E. Hickson, District Inspector, Central Airways, 808 Confederation Life Building, Winnipeg.

Enclosed herewith is copy of a letter which I have received from him in reply to an enquiry of mine. Something should be done very soon about the installation of the boiler and renewal of the radiators and connections at the Gordon's Indian Residential School. Also, a definite decision should be made as to the development of the spring, regarding which Mr. Mitchell has reported to his Branch, that is the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

It was my recommendation that a deep well be sunk near the school to whatever depth is necessary to secure an adequate supply of water. The Surveys and Engineering Branch received information that a well had been sunk in that vicinity to a depth of 385 ft., I believe, and they were informed that no water had been struck, and there was very little indication that water would be found before reaching bedrock, which might be 700 or 800 ft. In view of this information they decided it was inadvisable to proceed with the sinking of the well. Mr. Mitchell therefore explored the possibility of developing a spring which is about 1½ miles from the school. This may be found to be a satisfactory solution and a suggestion to this effect was made by me about two years ago but it was not taken very seriously by anyone.

If the Surveys and Engineering Branch spend the rest of the summer trying to decide which should be done nothing will be done and the school cannot be opened for the next term.

My dear Sir,

Mr. Attwood, the Principal of Ponoka Indian Board School, in the Leduc County, informed me the other day that it was possible that new plans might be considered, making an entirely new building, instead of adding to the old one. I told him that the present site was selected against my wish, as I did not approve of the school being in an Indian Reserve, and that I wanted it built in the reserve land that the Agency Buildings are on at Kainai, which is besides being at a distance from any Reserve, the most central site in the Leduc County. He asked me to do everything possible in order that my suggestion might be carried out, as it would cost both him and his staff, work in two if it could be done. I have written to Mr. Bishop of the Appellate, and now to you. In favor of my suggestion I may perhaps be excused if I point out some of the advantages of the change, especially, as you, I believe, have no personal knowledge of this Agency. In the first place, as you are perhaps aware, one of the principal burdens of the staff is; that they have to be in guard, night and day, trying to prevent immorality, and generally even then generally more or less unsuccessfully. If the school was where I suggest it could be fenced with a good fence, and certain rules without the consent of elders.

I have the honour to report that in accordance with your instructions, I began the survey of the property of the Church of England and the School on the Gordon, Indians Reserve on Friday the 5th of July and completed the same on the 15th in accordance with your subsequent telegram to Agent Marison.

We established the necessary portion of the south boundary of Tp. 27, R.17 W. of the second meridian by cutting and retracing the old line of mounds existing near the west boundary of the reserve. By astronomical observations this was found to be two minutes out in azimuth. We found on retracing the east boundary of Sec.4 of this Tp. that it was mounded and we accepted them as correct.

The School land begins at a point 10 chains north and 5 chains west of the quarter section corner on the east boundary of section 3, thence west (3 & 1/3) eight and one third chains, thence north ("12") twelve chains, thence east (8 1/3) eight and one third chains, thence south ("12") twelve chains to the place of beginning containing by measurement "10" ten acres more or less.

Our meridian lines are all run due north but the azimuths are referred to the central meridian as 0 or 360 degrees in accordance with the Dominion Lands System of survey.

I enclose herewith a sketch of the said properties showing Road allowance running between the two quarters, but the Reverend Sup't Atwater expressed no disapproval of the same as the regularly travelled and graded road runs a short distance west of the School property.

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of yours of the 7th of August last. I imagined I had replied to that long ago but I have just discovered my reply here among other papers on the Gordon Res. file, dated 20th Augt. 1918, as follows:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of yours of the 7th inst. in re Road frontage of School property on Gordon's Ind. Res.

In the survey of this School property I was guided by:
1. An area of ten (10) acres,
2. No boundary to be nearer than 66 feet to any building,
3. The Rev. Sup't Atwalai's wish to include a high and dry building site, as he expects to erect or have erected a new School building in the near future.

At present by courtesy, the travelled road passes through this School land and immediately in front of the School building, but the graded road as (I am informed by Agent Munson) guaranteed by the Indians passes some 20 chains to the west of the School.
I did not locate and survey a road to and from the school as I was under the impression that the Church and School property were practically one and the same—merely under different Committees; and the East boundary of the School land is only five (5) chains from the road allowance between sections two (2) and three (3) and the production thereof northward in accordance with the surrender.

On consultation with Agent Morrison, it was decided a mere waste of time to "lay out" and post the road allowances mentioned in the surrender because it is an impractical road location; and moreover, as previously mentioned, the guaranteed road through the Church property.

It is impossible to give the section land a road frontage and conform with the three foregoing conditions.

If such a road, as you suggest, is necessary for the school, I beg to recommend that the Church and School Committees of the Church of England be requested to decide on a road or lane location for the School. I have the honour to be, sir,

Herewith is a surrender, for acceptance by Council, of the n.w.¼ of section 2, township 27, range 17, w.2 M., containing 160.5 acres, in the George Gordon Indian reserve, Sask., with a view to an exchange of land.

Memorandum,

Mr. Buskard,

With reference to your verbal inquiry, I beg to say that Mr. William Swan, Architect, of Punnichy, Sask., a returned soldier, was appointed as Inspector of Construction for the Gordon's Indian school, in the Touchwood Agency, Sask., when it was built in 1921, his appointment being made by the Civil Service Commission. The school was burned and rebuilt in 1929. When the contract was let and the work to be gone on with we wrote to the Civil Service Commission, advising them that we would require an Inspector of Construction and that, if possible, we would like to have Mr. William Swan appointed, as he was employed during the building of the original school and his services were very satisfactory; they issued a temporary certificate in his favour for six months, from October 27, 1929, at a salary of $6.00 a day. This was renewed for a further period of six months, as the work on the Gordon's school had not yet been completed.

In June, 1930, a contract was let for the Muscowequan Indian residential school and, as Mr. Swan's certificate was still current and the Gordon's school almost completed, we decided to utilise his services in connection with the Muscowequan's school and he was so advised on June 23, 1930. When his certificate expired on October 27 we requested the Civil Service Commission to renew it for a further period of six months, which they have done, but they requested that we obtain the authority of His Excellency the Governor General in Council for the continuance of the position as a temporary one. Under Section 40 of the Civil Service Regulations this is necessary if the employment covers a longer period than twelve months.

The Muscowequan's school and the Gordon's school are both in the Touchwood Indian agency and in the electoral district of Last Mountain.

I beg to refer you to official letter of the 6th instant, with which was enclosed a copy of the Department's letter to Mr. Agent Waddy. With reference to the last paragraph of that letter, Mr. Waddy writes, as follows:

"Farm land in the vicinity is assessed at from $9.00 to $12.00 per acre. Referring to your letter 121-1-9, dated the 6th ultimo, with reference to the new site selected for the Gordon's Indian Residential School, I beg to report that I proceeded to the Gordon's Reserve on the 17th instant, after sending ample notice to the Band to meet me on their reserve on that date, for the purpose of discussing the matter of the school site.

I called at the Touchwood Agency for Mr. Waddy, who accompanied me to the reserve, and who was present at the meeting. The matter was taken up very fully. There were forty-two voting members of the Band present at the meeting, and fifteen absentees.

After discussing the matter fully and carefully, the Indians unanimously agreed to set aside the North East Quarter of Section Two, the South East Quarter of Section Ten, the South Half of Section Eleven, and Eighty acres, being the South Half of the North East Quarter of Section Eleven, all in Township 27, Range 17, West of the 2nd Principal Meridian.

The only conditions asked by the Band were that any Indian whose residence may be upon the said released lands should receive compensation to enable him to remove his buildings, and that they should be compensated for any improvements which they had made thereon, at a fair valuation, to be arrived at by mutual agreement, and further, that a road from Francis Cyr's house, which runs through the South East quarter of Section Ten to the main highway running through the said quarter section, shall be preserved for the use of the Indians of the Band. This is their main outlet from the West side of the reserve.

I looked over the ground, and as near as I could judge where the lines ran, find that the only resident on that quarter section was George Pratt, whose buildings could be removed, I estimate, at a cost of about $100.00.

There are eighteen acres under cultivation on this quarter, which is being used, and has been for some time, by the school. There appeared to be some doubt as to who should receive compensation for this, but this is a matter which can be inquired into more fully by the Agent.

The Secretary

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Ottawa.
The School had asked in the first instance that all of Section Eleven be set aside for school purposes. Upon inquiring into the matter, one of the Indians stated that his hay grounds were situated on the North East Quarter of Section Eleven. I therefore did not take that quarter into consideration, but they were quite willing to set aside the North East Quarter of Section Two, which I know has more open land suitable for cultivation than the North East Quarter of Eleven.

I also found objections to releasing the North Half of the North West Quarter of Section Eleven. The Indians stated, and correctly so, that their main road from the West and South sides of the Reserve, to the East and North sides, had for years passed through this quarter section, and if it were closed to them it would cause them great inconvenience.

They also complained that the School had been cultivating an old field which belonged to the deceased Josiah Pratt, whose son is residing on this piece of land, and who should rightfully have the benefit of this field.

After discussing the matter fully with the Indians, I had a conversation with the Venerable Archdeacon Knowles, and informed him regarding the lands the Indians were in favour of releasing for school purposes. Archdeacon Knowles expressed his satisfaction, and stated that in his opinion the Indians had been very generous to the School. I therefore had the Indians vote on the question, and I am submitting herewith surrender forms, in duplicate, duly completed, together with a declaration of myself, the Chief and the councillors, and a list showing the voting members of the Band, and the result of the vote. The Indians did not ask for any compensation for these lands. The only matter they wished to be assured about was that the land would be used for the benefit of the School only, and should the department at any time discontinue the Residential School on their reserve, that the land would not be used for other purposes, but would revert to them.

I am enclosing the Township Plan, with the released lands marked thereon.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,

Sir:

Referring to your letter No. 121-1-9, dated the 24th ultimo, in connection with the old Gordon's School plot, comprising ten acres in the N.E.¼ of Section 2, Tp. 27-Rge. 17, W. 2nd Meridian in the Gordon's Reserve, I have to report that this quarter section, together with the N.W.¼ of Section 2-27-17, were surrendered on July 4th, 1914, in exchange for the East Half of Section 4-27-17, which had been patented to the Church of England.

I took the matter up with the Indians of the Gordon's Band on the 17th instant, and they unanimously voted in favour of transferring the ten acres, comprising the old school plot, to the Church. They stated that they had received a full half-section from the Church, and it was only but fair that the Church should receive an equal amount of land.

Although the Department did not say it was necessary, I obtained a surrender of this ten acres, which I am forwarding herewith in duplicate, duly completed, with the usual declaration, and list of voters attached, and trust you will find all in order.

With reference to the buildings on this plot, the old stone school is still standing. The roof is in a badly dilapidated and dangerous condition, and I arranged with the Indians to have this taken down without expense, and informed them that they could have whatever lumber they were able to salvage from the roof. The windows, interior floors, joists, in fact everything in the shape of lumber within the school has been removed, and as the roof stands at present it is a menace, and I, therefore, ordered it removed.

The frame addition referred to is only in fair condition. The windows have all been removed, and Agent Waddy informed me that he has them on hand. This might be handed over for Church purposes without charge.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I am taking the liberty of writing to you about a matter which is worrying me considerably. I have several times asked Commissioner Brown to try to obtain permission from the Department for me to buy three teams of horses and three wagons and bob sleighs. We have been very much handicapped all this summer for want of equipment and have practically no land ready for next spring. On August 7th I received a letter from the Commissioner telling me that he had taken this matter up with the Department and that they had advised him that there were no funds available at that time. He also told me in conversation that the Department did not make a practice of helping in this way.

We are facing very cold weather and as you know we are over seven miles from town and have not got a team that is able to draw a load of coal and the only wagon I have has broken down several times.

There are several auction sales listed near here during the present month and I feel sure I could purchase horses at a very
reasonable price — about $175.00 a team, the horses weighing about 1400 lbs. The first sale is to be on November 14th, and there are three teams listed which would suit me very well.

This school has gone down a lot and Mr. Dance has had a lot of trouble with staff as he took over when all the trouble was on switching Principals etc., during the school year, something which should never have been done until the start of a new school year. Since he has taken over he has improved conditions as far as farming goes as he has put in more crop and done some summerfallow, and if given half a chance will no doubt make a success of it as he is very interested in his work and is very energetic. However it is very hard for a man of 57 to make over a position like this without previous experience, and in my opinion is a job for a younger man.

The education of the children is the same as it was before, absolutely no improvement has been made. This was one of the things I understood the Department was anxious to get rid of Mr. Frayling for. However, in my opinion, the children of this school have been, and are now receiving, as good an education as children in any other boarding school.

Considerable repairs are needed and will have to be done in the near future. However this school is in wonderful condition for the amount of money spent on it by the Department in the last 12 years. Anything that was done up to the present has been paid for mostly out of school grant. The new water tanks are on hand and will be installed as soon as I can get men to do the work.

The Indian Committee of the Diocese of Qu'Appelle met November 28th, 1945, to receive the report of the new principal, and to further discuss ways and means of trying to improve conditions at the school, following a period beset with many difficulties due to lack of competent staff, and the greatly increased cost of operation, in part due to conditions created by the war, higher salaries and cost of food and clothing.

It was generally agreed that our greatest difficulty at the present time is in connection with the operation of the farm at the school. For several years past, stating our case quite frankly little or no replacements have been made in the matter of farm machinery and equipment, the greater part of which is now obsolete and worn out. Our position is aggravated due to the fact that we have insufficient acreage to enable us to properly provide for the needs of the school and make the necessary replacements when needed. My dear Bishop Knowles:

Re: Gordon's Indian Residential School -

You will pardon me for not replying to your letter of December 10th until now.

I was anxious to discuss with Inspector Ostrander, who is at present visiting Ottawa, and with the senior officials at the Minister's office, the request submitted by you in your communication. This, I had an opportunity to do yesterday.
