The officials here hesitate to establish a precedent in this case. At the same time, we appreciate very fully the difficulties you are experiencing in the operation of the Gordon's Residential School. In view of this fact, I have asked the Chief of the Training Division to review the standing of the Institution in the hope that adjustments might be made in the payment of per capita grants or in the authorized pupilage. In addition to this, if tractors are available, we might by paying the regular per capita grant in advance, enable the Principal to proceed with the purchase of a tractor and the six-foot tiller combine. I am also asking Inspector Ostrander to investigate the land holdings at the school and to discuss with the Principal the best ways and means of bringing the land available under cultivation.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Gladys Sanderson, Pupil No. 0318, of the Gordon Indian Residential School at Funnichy, Sask., who died at Lesteck Hospital (place) on 19th 1940, Lesteck, Sask.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

June 15th, 1947.

William Favel, aged 13 years, student of Gordon's Indian School, Punnichy District, Saskatchewan, state as follows:

On Saturday, June 14th, 1947, after we had our dinner at 12.00 noon, we were dismissed by the boys' supervisor and told that we could go for a walk or if our homes were near we could go to them. I went for a walk around the barns and onto the highway and then came back to the school. I met Ernest Whitequill, Hubert Assoon, Warran Kay, and we went down towards the lake. We are not allowed to go near the lake, but I have been there several times before with other boys. When we arrived at the lake we saw three girls out on the water on a raft. They were Myrtle Moostoes, Mary Whitequill, and Margaret Bruce. Two of the girls were sitting on the raft and Myrtle Moostoes was using a pole to push the raft, and as we watched them one of the girls stood up and then fell into the water. We were about 100 yards from them when this happened. Right after this one of the other girls fell into the water and we then ran around to the edge of the lake and Ernest Whitequill called to the other girl on the raft to stay on the raft. This girl was Mary Quitequill, Ernest's sister. The wind blew the raft in towards the shore and Ernest Whitequill pulled the raft into the shore and his sister, Mary, got off, and went back to the school. The other two girls were still in the water and I ran up to the school and told Mrs. Daysh, the school matron, that the two girls were in the water. Mr. Wickenden came with me and I showed him the spot where I had last seen the girls in the water and we saw one of the girls still in the water. Mr. Wickenden then went into the water and pulled this girl out. This was Myrtle Moostoes, but there was no sign of the other girl. I was then sent back to the school for a swim suit for Mr. McLeod.

Signed

William Favel.
Gordon's (Anglican) Indian Residential School,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

June 15th, 1947.

Ernest Whitequill, aged 14 years, student of Gordon's Indian School, Punnichy District, Sask.,

On Saturday, June 14th, 1947, at about 1.30 P.M. I met William Favel in the school yard, also Herbert Assoon and Warren Kay. We all went down towards the lake which is located at a quarter of a mile east of the school. When we arrived at the lake we saw three girls out on the water on a raft. Two girls were sitting down and one girl was pushing the raft with a pole. Myrtle Jane was pushing the raft, Margaret Bruce and my sister, Mary Whitequill, were sitting down on the raft. As we watched this raft one of the girls fell into the water, and then Myrtle Jane went into the water, and the other girl stayed on the raft. William Favel and I raced around the edge of the lake and told the other girl to stay on the raft. This girl stayed until it was blown to the edge of the lake and then I pulled it in to the shore and helped my sister off the raft. William Favel ran towards the school to tell Mr. Daysh that the other two girls were in the water and I brought my sister back to the school.

Signed

Ernest Whitequill.
Gordon's (Anglican) Indian Residential School,
PUNNICHY, Saskatchewan.

June 15th, 1947.

I, Mabel Matchechuk, Treaty Indian, aged 14 years, student of Gordon's Indian School, Punnichy district, Saskatchewan, state as follows:

On Saturday, June 14th, 1947, I was working in the kitchen shortly after noon, and when I had finished my work I went out into the girls' playground. I met Joan Blind, aged 13 years, near the gate and asked her if she knew where Myrtle Moostocs was. Joan said, "Maybe she is down by the lake", and we both walked towards the lake, which is located about a quarter of a mile east of the school. When we arrived at the lake I saw three girls on a raft. They were: Myrtle Moostocs, Margaret Bruce, and Mary Whitequill. They were quite a way from the shore. Shortly after we arrived at the lake shore some boys came down and then William Favel came over and told us to come and tell the matron that the girls were in the water. Joan and I ran up to the school, but by the time we arrived William Favel had run to the school himself and both Joan and I went into the washroom. I have been down to the lake several times before with Myrtle Moostocs. I know that it is against the regulations for any of us girls to go near the lake, or to leave the playground without permission.

Signed

Mabel Matchechuk.
June 15th, 1947.

I, Joan BLIND, aged 13 years, student of Gordon's Indian School, Punnichy district, state as follows:

On Saturday, June 14th, 1947, I was working in the kitchen and when I had finished my work I went to the girls' playground. After I had been in the playground for about an hour, I was walking towards the gate to the girls' playground when I met Mabel Matchechuk, aged 14 years, who asked me if I knew where Myrtle Moostos was. I said "Maybe Myrtle is down by the lake", as Myrtle had been down by the lake before. Mable and I walked down to the lake and when we arrived Mabel saw three girls on a raft and said, "There they are", and when I looked the raft was quite a way out from the shore going in a north easterly direction. Several boys came down to the lake at this time and as we watched the raft we saw Myrtle jump off the raft and William Favel told us to come and tell Mrs. Daysh, the school matron. William Favel, however, came to the school himself, ahead of us, and told Mrs. Daysh, and we stayed at the school. I did not see Margaret Bruce leave the raft. I have been down to the lake about three times. I have been told by the school Matron, Mrs. Daysh, that I was not allowed to go near the lake, and also that I am not allowed to leave the girls' playground without permission.

Mary Whitequill, aged 12 years, student, states as follows:

On Saturday, June 14th, 1947, at about 1.00 P.M., I was in the girls' wash-room and Myrtle Moostoes came in and asked me to walk down to the lake with her. I started off with Myrtle Moostoes and Margaret Bruce, aged 10 years. The lake is on the east side of the school, and we arrived at this point and there was a raft made of gasoline drums near the pump house. Myrtle got on this raft, and Margaret and I took our stockings off and played around in the water for a short time. Myrtle then called to us to come and get on the raft, which we did. Myrtle then pushed the raft out into the water with a pole that was on the raft and we started off across the lake. We were going in a north-easterly direction. Myrtle then saw two girls coming from the school, and said: "Let's hurry" as she did not want any more girls on the raft. We then saw some boys coming towards the lake and Margaret said "Let's jump off as they might throw stones at us", and Margaret then jumped off the raft into the water. The water was too deep for Margaret at this point and Myrtle passed the pole towards her and told her to grab it. Margaret tried to reach the pole but could not do so. Myrtle then said, "I will jump off and try and catch Margaret", and Myrtle then jumped off the raft and let the stick go and I was on the raft by myself. Myrtle tried to swim but could not do so and she went down into the water, and was not able to get anywhere near Margaret. Margaret disappeared in the water. I sat still on the raft and the wind blew it towards the shore and when it arrived my brother, Ernest Whitequill, aged 13 years, pulled the raft in and I got off and walked back to the school.

Signed

Mary Whitequill.
Dear Mr. Hoey:

With reference to my telegram of the 14th instant advising of the death of two Indian girl pupils of the Gordon's Indian Residential School by drowning, I wish to report as follows:

At approximately 4.00 P.M. Saturday, the 14th instant, while at the Fort Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital on other business, I received a telephone call from Dr. Golman at Punnichy, advising me of the death by drowning of two Indian girl pupils of the Gordon's Indian Residential School and asking me whether an inquest should be held. I informed him that in my opinion an inquest was very necessary and that he should make arrangements for same.

I proceeded to the Gordon's School as soon as I had finished my business at the Fort Qu'Appelle Hospital. At the Gordon's School I talked to Reverend D.C. Wickenden and Mr. Mayo, joint acting Principals of the Gordon's School, also the engineer and Cpl. Playford, of the R.C.M. Police. Dr. Golman had been at the school and taken what action he considered necessary and returned to Punnichy, and I did not see him. Indian Agent Mr. R.S. Davis, and Mr. Evers, Clerk, were away at the Nut Lake Reserve paying Treaty and Mr. Davis did not get to the school until late in the evening. Enclosed are copies of statements of Mary Whitequill, Joan Blind, Mabel Matchecheuk, Ernest Whitequill, and William Pavel, all pupils of the school. The statements in question were given to Cpl. T.E. Playford, R.C.M. Police.

The two girls who had drowned are Myrtle Moostos, 16 years old, from the James Smith's Reserve, Duck Lake Agency, and Margaret Bruce, 11 years old, from the Bay Star Reserve, Touchwood Agency. Also with them on the raft was a third girl, Mary Whitequill, 11 years old, who was saved. Evidence at the inquest will probably reveal that these three girls were supposed to be playing in the girls' playground at the time. Apparently they, and possibly others, had left the playground unnoticed, crossed the road, proceeded through the garden and two fences down to the shore of the small lake which has been used to supply water for the school. There is evidence that they played on the shore of the lake a short time, then proceeded around the lake to where a raft was lying on the shore. Apparently they played on the shore of the lake a short time, then they pushed the raft out on the water and boarded it. There was a fairly high wind blowing and the raft drifted lengthwise of the lake, which is about 400 yards long. The girls had clung to the raft until nearing the far shore when apparently they became frightened. The girl, Margaret Bruce, fell off the raft and the older girl, Myrtle Moostos, jumped into the water in an effort to rescue her. The third girl, Mary Whitequill, clung to the raft and was saved.

The raft referred to is constructed of oil drums held together by a hastily constructed framework and had been used at the time of the spring break-up when some of the school staff were giving attention to the pump which had been on the ice of the lake. It had apparently been left on the shore of the lake after they finished with it.

Mr. Wickenden and Mr. Mayo both informed me that the area of the lake was out of bounds to all of the children and that it was strictly against orders for the children to go down to the lake. However, at this particular time, about 2.00 P.M. on Saturday afternoon, it would appear that several children were at or near the lake, both girls and boys, as it was a boy who ran to the school and reported the accident as he had seen it from the shore of the lake.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Mrs. Daysh: (Matron)

At one o'clock on June 14, I told Miss Coe (Girls' Supervisor) to go off duty for awhile. I would be in the hall and go in and out to see that the children were all right. At the same time I was trying on dresses for the junior girls in the hall. It must have been just after 2 o'clock when one of the boys came in and said that 2 of the girls were drowning. I came in and told Mr. Mayo and Mr. Wickenden.

The girls are not allowed to go off by themselves. They had been told about that the week before. I had told them and asked Mr. Mayo to make a public announcement in the dining room, which he did very forcefully after supper one evening. They were worrying their supervisor very much because they had taken into going into the space across the road which used to be Mr. Frayling's garden and they were not supposed to be there. They have a large space of their own with playground equipment. The Saturday previous I had been shaking mats on the front steps and heard voices and saw a red sweater in that garden. I went over and saw Myrtle Jane Moostos, Mabel Matchechuck, Betty Moosemay and Myrtle McNab, with some younger girls, coming up the path. I told them they were doing wrong by taking the little girls and encouraging them to go out of bounds. I did not realize this garden gave them such easy access to the lake. On the Monday it worried me so much I asked Mr. Mayo to speak to the girls about going out of their playground. On the same Monday I found Betty Moosemay, Leona Bird, Etheline Bird and Minnie Miristy in the garden again and I sent them to bed right away and also sent them to bed early the next night.

On Saturday, the 14th, I asked Miss Coe, the Girls' Supervisor, if she had seen the girls going into the garden during the past week and she said she had not. She supervises them during the hours when they are not in the classroom or working under some instructor. I had no idea of their being on the raft. Myrtle Jane was a kitchen girl and should have been at work in the mornings—possibly went down to the lake during recess.

The girls were playing baseball by themselves when I went out that Saturday afternoon to the playground. The supervising under Mr. Mayo and Mr. Wickenden has been the same. The supervisor gets the children up in the morning, supervises the breakfast and cleaning of the dormitories and has them whenever they are not in school or working about the building. Twice a week after nine Miss Coe has been going to help with the laundering of the quilts as an emergency measure, otherwise she is free during classroom hours.

(The end)
Mr. Harry Morrow: (Manual Training Instructor, acting-supervisor).

The Boys' Supervisor gets the boys up, gets them ready for school, supervises meals, sports or handicrafts during the evenings, and puts them to bed.

I try to keep them on the playground, but it is hard to keep check of them unless you are able to be there all the time. Other duties sometimes keep you inside. There are times when they have to be left on the playground alone. If some of them are not around they have to be locked up. When I am having my meals the supervisor for the junior boys is around. I always have an idea where they are because the Farm Instructor tells me the ones he wants.

Saturday afternoons I am working at repair work and the boys go home. By repair work I mean general maintenance around the building. It does not fit in well with the Boys' Supervisors' work. It keeps me busy even when the boys are in school. When I have my half day they are more or less on their own at times. When I work on repairs some boys are with me learning. I have no boys with me on Saturdays because most of them go home or visiting with others.

I did not know the boys had been going down to the lake. I have told them on more than one occasion not to go down there. I was on the raft twice, once when repairing the pump line, and again during the dragging.

Mr. D. C. Wickenden:

The lake is generally known to be out of bounds and all the staff are aware of this and that no child should go down without some definite reason. I am joint Acting-Principal and my particular sphere of influence is the supervision of the children in the various phases of their work and recreation. Boys and girls know quite definitely that the lake is out of bounds and girls particularly, know that their proper place is their own playground, and that they should not be out of it without permission, unless they are occupied in the school. I have two small children and have allowed smaller girls at times to play with my children on my grounds. I have not encouraged the older girls to come in and I have often sent girls away. I have told them that they must ask permission of Mrs. Wickenden or of me before they play with the children.

On Saturday, June 14th, after lunch, I came back to the office to work. At about 2 o'clock the matron came in and announced that two girls were reported to have drowned in the lake. William Pavel, the school boy who brought the information, appeared and confirmed this. I called for blankets and immediately ran off with William Pavel, followed by William Anderson (a general helper on the farm). The boy guided us to the north shore of the lake where he had seen the girls fall in, and with very little loss of time we saw one body floating, barely submerged. I took off a little clothing, waded in, and swam and waded back to shore with the body. I recognized it as Myrtle Moostos. About this time Mr. Mayo appeared and blankets came. Without delay I began artificial respiration. I continued alone until the doctor arrived, which would be shortly before three. Under his direction artificial respiration was carried on, and when he left about 3.30 his directions were to carry on for one-half hour longer and then to desist if there was no evidence of a pulse. Actually, spelled off by others, we carried on until a quarter to five and then we decided that it was hopeless.

In the meantime the search for the other body continued under Corporal Playford, and two of our staff members, Mr. MacLeod and Mr. Morrow, aided by others. This body, that of Margaret Bruce, was not recovered until Monday forenoon.

(The school had been asked to try to overcome the ill-will among the Indians, so a concession was made and the children allowed to go home one Sunday a month, also Saturday afternoons also. There is a strong demand on the part of the parents that the children visit their homes whenever possible, leading to a con-

tinual shifting of responsibility. For instance, at Lac la Ronge the older boys were originally allowed to go home once a month, then it gradually got down to once a week. There was increasing pressure from the parents and there has been the same thing here. I have allowed the girls to go in and play with my children in the interests of friendship, but have tried to control it. The children should not have gone down to the lake and it is strange that Myrtle Jane should have got this notion. She has always been a well-behaved girl. Perhaps those from far away Reserves feel the restrictions and the fact that they never get home during the year. The girls concerned are those that live at a distance. We just ran down there as soon as we saw the girls and then came right back to the school. Mr. Wickenham and William Anderson ran right down.

2nd. Appearance: One time before the Saturday we threw stones at the girls on the raft. We were not really trying to hit them or scare them. We did not want the raft. On Saturday afternoons we are allowed to walk around. We know we are not allowed to go down to the lake. We were trying to splash water on the girls with the stones, not to hit them. That day we saw Margaret Bruce and Mary White Quill on the south shore.

William Favel
Accident, June 14, 1947; at Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Sask.

Ernest White Quill, aged 14, Ochapowace Reserve:

I went down to the lake and saw some girls fasting. One fell in, then another one fell in, and one stayed on. I started running there, the girls told us they were drowning. I told Mary to stay on the raft. I ran up to the school.

William Favel and Warren Kay were with me. I brought my sister (Mary) back to the school. William came to the school first. The raft was blown into the shore.

The children down at the lake then were William Favel, Hubert Assoon, Warren Kay and myself, Mary White Quill, Joan Blind, Mabel Matchecheuck, Margaret Bruce, and Myrtle Jane Moostoes.

I had not been on the raft before; I only went down there when sent. I do not know if others had been there before that day; it was the first time I had been down there on my own.

On the raft were Myrtle Jane Moostoes, Mary White Quill and Margaret Bruce.

Ernest White Quill
Dr. S. Golzman:

On the 14th of June between 2.30 and 5.00 p.m. I had a phone call from Mr. Mayo, who said that two girls were drowned, or apparently drowned, at the lake east of the school and could I come right out. I immediately called Mr. Davis to inform him of the accident, but he was away on another Reserve. I also called the Mounted Police but learned later that they were already at the scene of the accident. I arrived at the school about 15 minutes after the phone call. Mr. Mayo met me at the School and we proceeded down to the lake. When I arrived there I saw a body, which was later identified as that of Myrtle Jane Moosos, and Mr. Wickenden was giving her artificial respiration at the time. Artificial respiration was carried on according to my instructions and stimulants were injected intra-muscularly. I could not detect any visible pulse nor were there any respirations. I assisted in the artificial respiration for almost an hour, changing off with Mr. Wickenden, but the body failed to respond to any treatment. Death was due to drowning. We could not find the other body at that time.

On June 16th, at about noon, I was informed by the Mounted Police of Punnichy that the other body had been recovered from the lake, and as coroner I came out and viewed the body. I was unable to go out until about 5 o'clock. When I arrived there the body was at the edge of the lake, face down, and it was the body of Margaret Bruce. She was identified by Mr. Wickenden. She was quite dead and death was apparently due to drowning.

There were no marks of violence of misdemeanour on either of the two bodies.

I came in here under peculiar conditions. I came in here first of all for two weeks, then a month, and when I went into the office in Winnipeg I was asked to come right on here. "MYRTLE WHITESHILL, aged 12 years states as follows:

On Saturday June 14th, 1947 at about 1:00 P.M., I was in the girls wash-room at the Gordon Indian School. Myrtle MCFARLANE came and asked me to walk home to the lake with her. I started walking with Myrtle MCFARLANE and Margaret BRUCE, aged 10 years. The lake is on the east side of the school, and we arrived at this point, there was a raft made of gasoline drums near the pump house. Myrtle got on this raft, Margaret and I took off our stockings and played around in the water for a short time. Myrtle then yelled to us to come and get on the raft which we did. Myrtle pushed the raft out into the water with a pole that was on the raft, and we started off across the lake, so were going in an northerly direction. He then saw some boys coming towards the lake and Margaret BRUCE said "Lets jump off as they might throw stones at us" and Margaret then jumped off the raft into the water. William Pavel, aged 13 years, student of Gordon Indian School was interviewed and the following statement obtained:

"I, William Pavel, Treaty Indian of Gordon Indian School state as follows, On Saturday June 14th, 1947, after we had our dinner at 12:00 noon, we were dismissed by the boys supervisor and told we could go for a walk or in our house some near we came into town. I went for a walk around the house and went to the riverbank and then came back to the school. I met Ernest Whitesill Hubert Jackson and Warren Kay and we went down towards the lake. We are not allowed to go near the lake but I have been there several times before with other boys. When we arrived at the lake we saw three girls out on the water on a raft, they were Myrtle McTeece, Mary Whitesill and Margaret Bruce, two of the girls were sitting on the raft and Myrtle McTeece was using a pole to push the raft, and as we watched them one of the girls stood up and then fell into the water, we were about 100 feet from them when this happened, right after this one of the other girls fell into the water and we then ran around the edge of the lake and Ernest Whitesill called to the other girl to stay on the raft, this girl was Mary Whitesill, Ernest's sister, the wind blew the raft towards the shore and Ernest Whitesill pulled the raft to the shore and his sister Mary got off, she went back to the school. The Rev. H. G. WICKENDEN, acting Principal of the Gordon Indian School was interviewed and the following statement obtained:

BRUNGE: About 2:00 P.M. Saturday June 14th, 1947, I was in my office at the Gordon Indian School, attending to a telephone message. Mr. William MAY and William JENSEN were present. Suddenly our Matron, Mrs. BATH, entered and announced that two girls had drowned in the lake, her informant, who may have been William FOWL, expressed forthwith and confirmed the report that he and others had seen two girls, Margaret BRUCE and Myrtle Jones MCCOOG, fall from a raft into the lake where they had drowned. I called for blankets and immediately ran off towards the lake guided by William FOWL to the scene of the incident, and followed by William JENSEN.

We ran along the north shore and very soon sighted one body floating barely submerged in the water not many yards from the shore. After removing my outer clothing and shoes I entered the water and brought the body to land. It was Myrtle MCCOOG drowned. I dragged her feet out of the water and applied artificial respiration without delay. The other came to me and assisted me in the second body. Mr. MAY had arrived by this time and was closely followed by Mrs. MAY who brought blankets. Mr. MAY did not delay but went off to phone for Dr. GOLDFIHN, who arrived at the school 20 minutes later. In the interval I persevered with the artificial respiration assisted by Mrs John PISHER, wife of the Chief; Miss L. McCONNELL and Miss Orches of the school staff and others who attempted to restore circulation of the blood. Very shortly after Dr. GOLDFIHN appeared on the scene unexpectedly accompanied by Mr. George TRIPP, the former launched a raft and assisted by Mr. D. McLEOD, and Mr. R. MORROW of the school staff kept up the search for the body of Margaret BRUCE around the shore. Dr. C. GOLDFIHN arrived about 2:45 P.M. and artificial respiration was continued under his direction. When he left, about 3:30 P.M. there was still no sign of life in the body and we were told that we might consider our efforts useless if there was no sign or indication of a pulse after another half hour. Actually we continued artificial respiration until 4:45 P.M. but in vain.

I should estimate that artificial respiration was applied within five minutes of the announcement of the drowning to us in the office, and it appears that the pupils who viewed the tragedy lost little time in reporting it.

Myrtle Jane MCCOOG was 16 years of age and due for discharge, she belonged to the James SMITH Band, Fort Le Gorne and was born February 19th, 1931. Margaret BRUCE belonged to the Day Step Indian Reserve and was 11 years of age. I wish to state that the schools of the incident are out of bounds to the girls and boys and that the girls had left their playground without permission.

H.G. Wickenden,
Acting Principal,
Gordon School,
Punnichy, Sask.

13. In the late P.M. this same date the Jury was summoned and the body viewed and same being identified by the Rev. D.G. WICKENDEN, Acting Principal of the Gordon Indian School, the Inquest was adjourned sine die.

14. The lake in which this drowning took place is oblong of water located approximately a quarter of a mile east of the Gordon Indian School, from which water is pumped for washing purposes etc., same is approximately 400 yards long running east and west and approximately 250 to 275 yards in width north and south, there is a pump located on the west side and it was from this point the girls embarked upon the raft which was a homemade affair consisting of four gasoline barrels and a wooden frame, on Saturday June 14th, there was a strong south west wind prevailing and when the raft left the shore it proceeded in northerly direction, about half way on the north side of this lake there is a point which juts out into the lake possibly 15 to 20 feet and it was near this spot that the body of both girls were located, the water at its deepest point is about 10 to 12 feet, the bottom of the lake is composed of a black alluvial of earth about 10 to 12 inches in depth. There are no boats or canoe's kept near this water, presumably to discourage these Indian children attending the school from going near the water, the raft in question was built during the spring to assist in securing a pump which is used to supply water to the school.

15. It will be noted from the statements obtained that it is strictly against the rules of the school for any of the students to leave the playground without permission, and that the girls who did go to the lake were fully aware of this ruling and admit same in their statements.

16. The Inquest in the above regard is scheduled for Thursday June 19th, 1947 at 8:30 P.M. at the Gordon Indian School, it being thought that the Indian Children who will be called to give evidence would do so in a better manner in their own environment.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry,
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical
Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's
presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's
death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be
permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? June 14, 1947.

2. At what time of day? about 2 P.M.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? Mr. Daysh who came to the office and reported to Rev. Wickenden and myself.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? We rushed down to the lake.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of

BRUCE Margaret Pupil No.

of the Gordon's Indian Residential School at Punichy, Sask,

who died at School (drowning) (place) on June 14th 1947

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

SPECIAL NOTE

Right Reverend Bishop Charlebois has made several calls at my office in the last few days for the purpose of discussing the plans of the proposed new Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Sask. I have prepared a rough sketch of the proposed building, which will accommodate approximately 110 children. I prepared this plan after obtaining the necessary information from His Lordship, and I may say that he has approved of the general layout and accommodation as provided for in the sketch plans.

As there is only $25,000 available in this year's estimates for this work it will be possible to make a commencement only of the building, and His Lordship has approved of my suggestion to erect the rear portion of the building, which is somewhat similar to the first unit of the Coqualeetza Institute, this year. There will be sufficient funds to erect this portion of the building and also to provide water, light and drainage for the building.

With reference to the sewage disposal system, water supply and electric lighting plant, Bishop Charlebois informed me that the engineers of the Water Power Branch in Winnipeg are somewhat familiar with this locality, and intimated to me that if they received instructions from Ottawa they would be glad to visit the site of the proposed building and report to the Department on the above mentioned systems. With your approval I will direct a letter to the Dominion Water Power Branch and ask them to give their engineers the necessary authority to visit the site and submit a report on the water, light and sewerage systems for the building when weather conditions will permit.

Owing to the short building season at Sturgeon Landing tenders should be invited as early as possible, and I expect to have the plans and specifications ready by the end of this month.

Architect.

General Clause

All mechanics, labourers, or other persons who perform labour in the construction of the work hereby contracted for, shall be paid such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed for the character or class of work in which they are respectively engaged, and if there be no current rates in such district, then fair and reasonable rates, and shall work such hours as are customary in the trade in the district where the work is carried on, or if there be no custom of the trade as respects hours in the district, then fair and reasonable hours, unless for the protection of life and property, or for other cause shown to the satisfaction of the Minister of Labour, longer hours of service are required. The Minister of Labour may at any time and from time to time determine for the purposes of this contract, what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages, and the current or fair and reasonable hours, and may from time to time rescind, revoke, amend or vary any such decision, provided that his determination and any amendment or variation shall not be operative prior to the period of three months immediately preceding the date thereof. Where there are special circumstances which in the judgment of the Minister of Labour make it expedient that he should do so, he may, in the manner and subject to the provisions hereinabove set forth, decide what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages for overtime, and what is the proper classification of any work for the purposes of wages and hours. Immediately upon receipt of notice of any decision of the Minister of Labour hereunder the contractor shall adjust the wages and hours and classification of work so as to give effect to such decision. In case the contractor shall fail so to do, or to pay to any employee or employees for any services performed or for any hours of labour, wages according to the rates fixed therefor by the Minister of Labour, the Minister of Labour may authorize and direct the Minister to pay any such wages at the rates so fixed and to deduct the amount thereof from any moneys owing by the Government to the contractor and any such payment shall for all purposes as between the contractor and the Government be deemed and taken to be payment to the contractor, and the contractor shall be bound in every particular by any such authority, direction and payment as aforesaid. The powers of the Minister of Labour hereunder shall not be exercised as to any employee or employees where it is established to his satisfaction that an agreement in writing exists and is in effect between the contractor and the class of employees to which such employee or employees belong or the authorized representatives of such class of employees fixing rates of wages, overtime conditions and hours of labour.

Sir,

Re Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing.

This will acknowledge your letter of April 11th asking for an investigation and report on the feasibility of erecting a small hydro-electric power plant and recommendations regarding a water supply and sewage disposal system in connection with the above mentioned school.

I have already written to The Pas inquiring as to the first sailing of the steamer from The Pas to Sturgeon Landing and will arrange to have the necessary survey made at the earliest possible date. If a power plant, water supply and sewage disposal system are to be built it would be most desirable to have this work done by contract, and possibly by the contractor building the school, and in my opinion it will be more economical and facilitate matters a great deal if a complete detail survey is made right at the start. The plans of such a survey would then permit of a general layout or any alternatives that may be later decided upon when preparing estimates of the cost of construction.

I am also trying to arrange to have Bishop Charlebois visit the site at the time of the inspection.

In the fourth paragraph of your letter you ask for estimates of cost and detailed specifications. In order to secure this information it is necessary to obtain from machinery firms in Winnipeg prices on the machinery required, and as this entails a considerable amount of work on the part of the firms in Winnipeg it seems to me that it would be only fair that the Department of Indian Affairs give these firms an opportunity on tendering on the machinery required. Most of these firms are branches of the large Eastern and American firms and I have found their prices compare favourably with those received in the East, and unless they can be given some assurance that they will be given an opportunity of tendering on this work you can hardly expect them to continue to supply quotations.

When submitting my report containing plans, estimates and specifications, I will submit a list of names of firms from whom prices have been received for the various equipment required.

April 11, 1925.

Sir,

Re: Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing.

Enclosed hereto is a copy of a letter which has been received from the Department of Indian Affairs with reference to the proposed Indian residential school near Sturgeon Landing, in which a request is made for a report on the feasibility of erecting a small hydro-electric power plant and recommendations regarding water supply and sewage disposal systems. I shall be obliged if you will arrange to have this report made in accordance with the request of the Indian Department.

We are advised by the Department that Bishop Charlebois has already been in communication with you and that you have arranged to accompany him to the site of this school, for the purpose of obtaining the material for this report.

The report which is now desired would be in the nature of a preliminary investigation to outline the most desirable scheme for supplying the school with power and water. The exact location of the school has not yet been fixed and you should advise on that point, so that the location may be decided upon with due regard both to water supply and sewage disposal, as well as hydro-electric power if this should be decided upon. This scheme appears to be similar to the one now being carried out for the McIntosh school and probably the same conditions will govern construction methods.

The report which you are now asked to prepare will naturally be of a general nature, but any estimates of cost should be very carefully prepared. If the general plan submitted by you is approved by the Indian Department, detailed surveys and estimates will be necessary with specifications for the machinery required; these specifications also should be complete and accurate in detail, as the Indian Department will no doubt buy the machinery themselves, as they have decided to do in the case of the school at McIntosh.

It is probable also that unless this outside work is carried on at the same time as the building of the school that it will have to be done by day labour.

These considerations and other details which you will learn from the Inspector of Indian Agencies at Winnipeg should be of assistance in deciding whether or not to recommend the installation of a hydro-electric development.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Attached hereto is our tender for Indian School at Sturgeon Landing.

It has not been possible for us to visit the site, and as we cannot get any information from the Indian office here, or from the agent at The Pas, or from the Department of Engineers who will choose the site, we are obliged to make the following reservations with respect to our bid.

As the site is uncertain, the distance which gravel will have to be hauled cannot be ascertained. We have therefore allowed for a cost of $5.00 per yard f.o.b. site.

With regard to excavation, Mr. Waddy informs us that not having definite information about the site, the cost of preparing it for the building, and the kind of excavating to be done cannot be gauged. In one place the excavation may be clay and boulders and in the other limestone may have to be blasted. We have therefore allowed the sum of $3195.00 as an upset price for all excavating, which includes the excavating necessary for the future portion of the building, but not including the footings for it.

The transporting of supplies from the docks to Sturgeon Landing is another item which cannot be definitely settled. We have allowed for moving 230 tons at a cost of $1150.00. If there is no roadway to be built, this amount may be ample, but on the other hand, if a road has to be prepared, or bush cleared to make it, an additional cost may be incurred.

These amounts are included as prime cost, and any actual cost above or below the amount stated to be adjusted accordingly.

The specifications do not state if ceiling boards will be required between the metal ceiling and the bottom of the joists. We have not included for them. If they are required, the additional cost will be $350.00.

It is not stated in the specifications or drawings if the sloping portion of the roof which will be exposed in the upper storey is to be covered with plaster or treated as ceilings and covered with metal. Kindly note our tender includes the covering of these surfaces with metal.
Owing to the impossibility of visiting the site, and so arriving at a guaranteed cost, we suggest it will be to the interest of the Department for this work to be done on a commission basis. We offer to carry out all the work for cost, plus a fixed sum of $5,000.00.

In addition to the previous building work done for your Department, we have erected many other structures away from Winnipeg and located at about thirty different points scattered from Fort William to northern Alberta, and therefore have gathered a considerable experience in reaching out of the way places, the economical handling of camps, etc., and will be glad to place ourselves at your disposal in erecting the building at Sturgeon Landing.

We are very gratified indeed to have done so much work for your Department and trust this may be continued in the future.

Yours very truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED.

MEMORANDUM: Mr. Scott.

Tenders were receivable at noon of the 11th day of May for the erection of the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

The following tenders were submitted and found to be regular:

- Claydon Co., Ltd., Winnipeg, $39,500
- P.M. Graham & Ferguson, Moosejaw, $38,000
- Roman Catholic Episcopal Corp. of Keewatin, Le Pas, Man., $31,450
- J. H. Simmons, Ltd., Winnipeg, $30,340
- R. N. Wyatt, Winnipeg, $25,519

Two additional tenders were also submitted one from Edward Sharp, Minnedosa, for $30,812 and which was accompanied by a Bond furnished by the London and Lancashire Guarantee & Accident Co. of Canada. This tender was received on the 12th of May after the others had been opened. The other tender was submitted by S. Brown of Winnipeg and was also opened after the date set forth in the advertisement, the amount of the tender being $25,058. This tender was not accompanied by the required deposit security. A telegram was sent, however, by the Canadian Bank of Commerce of Winnipeg, stating that Victory Bonds to the amount of $3,000 had been deposited there as security covering this tender.

As my estimate of the cost of this building amounted to $30,000 I would recommend that the tender given of R. N. Wyatt of Winnipeg, amounting to $25,519, the lowest regular one be favourable consideration. The amount provided in the estimates for this work this year is $25,000.
